days_plan.itin_title: NEW YORK

visits.text: Glide through America's only all-water cavern at Penn's Cave, where guided motorboats navigate an underground river through chambers adorned with spectacular limestone formations. This National Register treasure, steeped in Native American legend about a forbidden romance, has enchanted visitors since 1885. Above ground, explore the connected Wildlife Park where black bears, wolves, and mountain lions roam through natural habitats representing Pennsylvania's native fauna.

days_plan.itin_title: Pennsylvania Heritage Trail - Where American History Meets Natural Splendor

visits.text: Explore Chaco Culture National Historical Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site preserving the most remarkable concentration of ancient Pueblo architecture in North America. Between 850 and 1250 CE, Chaco Canyon served as the ceremonial, administrative, and economic center of a vast regional network spanning thousands of square miles. Massive great houses containing hundreds of rooms and multiple stories demonstrate sophisticated engineering and astronomical knowledge.

Visit Pueblo Bonito, the largest and most famous of Chaco's great houses, featuring over 600 rooms arranged in a perfect D-shape aligned to celestial events. The precision construction using millions of carefully shaped sandstone blocks continues to amaze archaeologists and visitors alike. Petroglyphs throughout the canyon document the spiritual and practical knowledge of these ancient peoples.

activities.text: Discover Fajada Butte and the famous Sun Dagger, where spirals carved into rock create a solar calendar marking solstices and equinoxes with remarkable precision. The park's remote location far from light pollution makes it exceptional for stargazing, designated an International Dark Sky Park. Hiking trails connect major ruins while revealing the canyon's stark desert beauty.

days_plan.itin_title: New Mexico Odyssey: Ancient Pueblos, White Deserts and Volcanic Wonders

visits.text: Immerse yourself in three generations of artistic brilliance at the Brandywine Museum of Art, perched along the tranquil banks of the Brandywine River. This world-renowned institution houses the most comprehensive collection of Wyeth family masterworks, from N.C. Wyeth's swashbuckling illustrations to Andrew Wyeth's haunting tempera paintings of rural Pennsylvania that defined American realism for a generation.

Journey through the region's agricultural heritage at Longwood Gardens, Pierre du Pont's horticultural masterpiece where 1,077 acres of gardens, woodlands, and meadows showcase nature elevated to high art. Wander through conservatories bursting with tropical orchids, lose yourself in the Italian Water Garden's dancing fountains, and experience evening illuminations that transform the grounds into a magical realm.

activities.text: Follow the scenic Brandywine Valley Wine Trail, where rolling hills draped in vines produce award-winning vintages that rival Napa's finest. Stop at family-owned wineries housed in historic stone barns, sample robust reds and crisp whites, and discover why this pastoral corner of Pennsylvania has emerged as a premier viticultural destination.

days_plan.itin_title: Pennsylvania Heritage Trail - Where American History Meets Natural Splendor

visits.text: Discover the mountain village of Chama, nestled high in the Southern Rockies of northern New Mexico where outdoor adventures await in every season. The Edward Sargent Wildlife Management Area offers excellent opportunities for hunting, Nordic skiing, and snowshoeing through pristine mountain terrain. The surrounding wilderness provides a genuine escape into high-altitude landscapes far from urban development.

Explore Heron Lake State Park, where spectacular mountain scenery surrounds a quiet reservoir perfect for hiking, cross-country skiing, and ice fishing during winter months. The lake's no-wake policy ensures peaceful conditions for kayaking and sailing in warmer seasons. Nearby El Vado Lake State Park provides prime winter birdwatching opportunities, particularly for observing bald eagles and other migratory species.

activities.text: Experience the authentic mountain town atmosphere of downtown Chama, where locally-owned businesses serve visitors seeking genuine New Mexico character away from tourist crowds. The village serves as a gateway to vast wilderness areas spanning the Colorado border, offering access to some of the most remote landscapes in the American Southwest.

days_plan.itin_title: MINNESOTA -THE BEST PLACES !

visits.text: Stroll through Charleston's Historic District, where cobblestone streets wind past pastel-colored antebellum homes adorned with flower-filled window boxes. Rainbow Row's iconic facades and the Battery's waterfront promenade showcase architectural treasures spanning centuries. Every corner reveals ornate iron gates, hidden courtyards, and perfectly preserved Southern elegance.

Take a harbor boat tour to Fort Sumter National Monument, where the first shots of the Civil War were fired in 1861. The journey across Charleston Harbor offers stunning views of the city skyline and the Ravenel Bridge, with frequent dolphin sightings along the way. Explore the massive brick fortifications, examine historic cannons, and climb the ramparts for sweeping coastal panoramas.

Explore Magnolia Plantation and Gardens, home to some of the oldest public gardens in America where ancient live oaks frame romantic bridges, winding pathways, and reflective ponds. The Audubon Swamp Garden features haunting cypress trees, boardwalks over still green waters, and abundant wildlife including alligators and countless bird species. The historic Garden Train offers a relaxed way to tour these enchanting grounds.

Discover Middleton Place, featuring the oldest landscaped gardens in America with terraced lawns sweeping toward the Ashley River beneath massive oaks trailing Spanish moss. The perfectly sculpted hedges, secret pathways, and seasonal blooms create living works of art unchanged for centuries. The Stableyards present heritage animal breeds and demonstrations of 18th-century plantation life.

activities.text: Visit Boone Hall Plantation, entering through the legendary Avenue of Oaks where dozens of massive live oaks draped in Spanish moss create an unforgettable natural cathedral. The preserved brick slave cabins along Slave Street contain powerful exhibits presenting the history of enslaved people. The plantation home, gardens of climbing roses, and working orchards complete this profound historical experience.

Stand in awe beneath the Angel Oak Tree, a natural monument estimated to be centuries old with limbs stretching so far they touch the ground before curving skyward again. This massive specimen creates its own cathedral of leaves and branches on Johns Island. The surrounding park provides a peaceful setting for contemplating one of nature's most impressive creations.

Tour the Middleton Place House Museum, filled with original furniture, portraits, and artifacts chronicling the prominent Middleton family and the people who lived and worked on the plantation. The serene riverside setting and meticulously maintained gardens offer hours of peaceful exploration through one of the most meaningful historic sites in the South.

days_plan.itin_title: South Carolina Grand Tour: Coastal Elegance to Mountain Serenity
South Carolina Grand Tour: Coastal Elegance to Mountain Serenity

visits.text: Rock City Gardens — Explore this 1930s attraction atop Lookout Mountain featuring massive rock formations, gardens, and views across seven states from Lovers Leap. The Swing-A-Long Bridge spans a 55-meter gorge while Ruby Falls cascades 44 meters underground.

Tennessee Aquarium — Discover freshwater and saltwater ecosystems in North America's largest aquarium housing 12,000 animals. The $45 million complex features two buildings exploring river to ocean environments.

Walnut Street Bridge — Walk across this 732-meter pedestrian bridge built in 1891 as one of the world's longest spanning structures. The bridge connects downtown to North Shore arts district offering river and mountain views.

Hunter Museum of American Art — View American art from Colonial to contemporary in this clifftop museum. The 1904 classical mansion and 1975 brutalist addition house works by Mary Cassatt, Ansel Adams, and regional artists.

Jour 1: Descend 1,120 feet beneath Lookout Mountain to witness Ruby Falls, America's tallest and deepest underground waterfall, cascading 145 feet through a cavern adorned with spectacular geological formations. This natural wonder, discovered in 1928, has captivated millions with its dramatic illumination and the journey through ancient cave passages carved over countless millennia by patient water.

Jour 1: Wander the enchanted pathways of Rock City Gardens atop Lookout Mountain, where massive ancient rock formations, lush gardens, and whimsical fairytale scenes create one of the South's most beloved attractions since 1932. The famous Lover's Leap overlook offers views across seven states on clear days, while the 4,100-foot trail winds through crevices, over swing-a-long bridges, and past hundreds of native plant species.

Jour 1: Experience one of America's finest aquariums at the Tennessee Aquarium in downtown Chattanooga, home to over 12,000 animals representing 800 species in what's considered the most diverse freshwater collection in the United States. Two interconnected buildings-River Journey and Ocean Journey-immerse visitors in aquatic ecosystems from Appalachian streams to tropical coral reefs, while the IMAX theater brings nature documentaries to stunning life.

Jour 2: Step back in time at the Tennessee Valley Railroad Museum, where restored vintage locomotives and passenger cars offer an authentic glimpse into the golden age of rail travel. Board a heritage train for the Missionary Ridge excursion along original railroad lines, learning the history of regional rail transport while experiencing one of the few remaining turntables in operation worldwide.

Jour 2: Hike into the dramatic gorges of the Cumberland Plateau at Signal Mountain, where wooded trails lead to glistening lakes, cascading waterfalls, and the spectacular Signal Point overlook with sweeping views of the Tennessee River's Grand Canyon. The Cumberland Trail connects to some of the region's most scenic spots including Julia Falls and the crystalline waters of Ruby Lake.

Rock City Gardens — Explorez cette attraction des années 1930 au sommet de Lookout Mountain avec d'immenses formations rocheuses, des jardins et des vues sur sept états depuis Lovers Leap. Le Swing-A-Long Bridge enjambe une gorge de 55 mètres tandis que Ruby Falls cascade sur 44 mètres sous terre.

Tennessee Aquarium — Découvrez les écosystèmes d'eau douce et d'eau salée dans le plus grand aquarium d'Amérique du Nord abritant 12 000 animaux. Le complexe de 45 millions de dollars comprend deux bâtiments explorant les environnements de la rivière à l'océan.

Walnut Street Bridge — Traversez ce pont piétonnier de 732 mètres construit en 1891 comme l'une des structures à travée les plus longues du monde. Le pont relie le centre-ville au quartier artistique de North Shore offrant des vues sur la rivière et les montagnes.

Hunter Museum of American Art — Admirez l'art américain de l'époque coloniale à contemporaine dans ce musée au sommet d'une falaise. Le manoir classique de 1904 et l'ajout brutaliste de 1975 abritent des œuvres de Mary Cassatt, Ansel Adams et d'artistes régionaux.

activities.text: Jour 1: Ride the steepest passenger railway in the world aboard the Lookout Mountain Incline Railway, climbing nearly a mile at grades approaching 73% through forests that blaze with color in autumn. Since 1895, this engineering marvel has carried visitors to breathtaking views of Chattanooga, the Tennessee River, and the Cumberland Plateau stretching to the horizon.
Riverfront dining — Enjoy farm-to-table Southern cuisine at restaurants overlooking the Tennessee River. The revitalized waterfront features local ingredients and mountain views.

Incline Railway ride — Montez à bord du chemin de fer de passagers le plus raide du monde grimpant une pente de 72,7% sur Lookout Mountain. Le téléphérique de 1895 offre des vues panoramiques sur Chattanooga et la rivière Tennessee.

Riverfront dining — Savourez la cuisine du Sud de la ferme à la table dans des restaurants surplombant la rivière Tennessee. Le front de mer revitalisé propose des ingrédients locaux et des vues sur les montagnes.

visits.text: Clearwater Beach - Sugar Sand and Turquoise Water: Consistently rated among America's best beaches, this Gulf Coast gem offers powdery white sand and the calm, crystal-clear water the region is famous for.

Clearwater Marine Aquarium - Home of Winter the Dolphin: Made famous by the 'Dolphin Tale' films, this rescue facility rehabilitates marine animals while educating visitors about ocean conservation. Meet the animals that inspired the movies.
Pier 60 - Sunset Celebration Capital of Florida: This famous pier extends into the Gulf of Mexico, hosting nightly sunset celebrations with street performers, artisans, and spectacular views.

Caladesi Island State Park - Florida's Most Pristine Beach: Accessible only by boat, this Gulf island remains one of the last undeveloped barrier islands in Florida, offering unspoiled beaches and nature trails.

activities.text: Sunset at Pier 60 - A Nightly Festival: Join locals and visitors for the daily celebration of Florida's legendary Gulf Coast sunsets, complete with entertainment and crafts.

days_plan.itin_title: Florida Unveiled: From Pristine Barrier Islands to Tropical Keys - The Ultimate Sunshine State Adventure
Florida Unveiled: From Pristine Barrier Islands to Tropical Keys - The Ultimate Sunshine State Adventure

visits.text: Experience Clemson's charming college-town atmosphere, where the walkable downtown centers on College Avenue with its shops, cafes, and historic character. Outside major university events, the area maintains a relaxed pace perfect for leisurely exploration. The Clemson Area African American Museum presents important regional history through thoughtful exhibits.

Visit Clemson University's beautiful campus, where historic buildings blend with modern facilities amid landscaped grounds. Memorial Stadium and other landmarks reflect the university's prominent role in South Carolina culture. The campus provides pleasant walking paths and architectural interest for visitors exploring the Upstate.

activities.text: Browse local boutiques and galleries reflecting the creative energy of this academic community. The downtown district offers an authentic college-town experience with regional character. Clemson's position near both mountain wilderness and larger cities makes it an excellent base for exploring the Upstate region.

days_plan.itin_title: South Carolina Grand Tour: Coastal Elegance to Mountain Serenity

visits.text: Cocoa Beach - The Authentic Florida Surf Town: This laid-back community has never strayed from its beach-town roots. From Ron Jon Surf Shop to classic Florida motels, the area welcomes visitors to experience genuine coastal living.

Ron Jon Surf Shop - The World's Most Famous Surf Shop: This 52,000-square-foot temple to beach culture operates 24 hours a day, 365 days a year, selling everything from surfboards to souvenirs across two floors.

activities.text: Surfing the Space Coast - Catch Your First Wave: Consistent Atlantic swells make Cocoa Beach one of the best places in Florida to learn surfing, with numerous schools offering lessons for all ages and skill levels.

Rocket Launch Viewing from the Beach - Front Row to Space: Many beachfront locations offer unobstructed views of launches from Kennedy Space Center, combining beach time with the spectacle of spaceflight.

days_plan.itin_title: Florida Unveiled: From Pristine Barrier Islands to Tropical Keys - The Ultimate Sunshine State Adventure

visits.text: Garden of the Gods — Hike among towering red sandstone formations rising 90 meters against Pikes Peak's snowy backdrop. The 526-hectare public park features dramatic fins, balanced rocks, and spires formed 280 million years ago, now free to explore year-round.

Pikes Peak — Drive or ride the cog railway to the 4,302-meter summit that inspired Katharine Lee Bates to write America the Beautiful in 1893. The panoramic views encompass seven states on clear days from this iconic Colorado fourteener.

United States Air Force Academy — Tour this prestigious military academy's 7,258-hectare campus featuring the iconic Cadet Chapel with 17 aluminum spires rising 46 meters. The 1962 modernist masterpiece houses Protestant, Catholic, Jewish, and Buddhist worship spaces.

Manitou Cliff Dwellings — Explore Ancestral Puebloan structures relocated and reconstructed in 1906 beneath red sandstone cliffs. While not original to this location, the dwellings provide accessible examples of 800-year-old architectural techniques.

Garden of the Gods — Randonnée parmi les imposantes formations de grès rouge s'élevant à 90 mètres sur fond enneigé de Pikes Peak. Le parc public de 526 hectares présente des ailettes spectaculaires, des roches en équilibre et des flèches formées il y a 280 millions d'années, maintenant libre d'exploration toute l'année.

Pikes Peak — Conduisez ou prenez le train à crémaillère jusqu'au sommet de 4 302 mètres qui a inspiré Katharine Lee Bates à écrire America the Beautiful en 1893. Les vues panoramiques englobent sept États par temps clair depuis ce fourteener emblématique du Colorado.

United States Air Force Academy — Visitez le campus de 7 258 hectares de cette prestigieuse académie militaire présentant l'emblématique Cadet Chapel avec 17 flèches d'aluminium s'élevant à 46 mètres. Ce chef-d'œuvre moderniste de 1962 abrite des espaces de culte protestant, catholique, juif et bouddhiste.

Manitou Cliff Dwellings — Explorez les structures des Pueblos ancestraux déplacées et reconstruites en 1906 sous des falaises de grès rouge. Bien qu'elles ne soient pas originaires de cet endroit, les habitations troglodytiques offrent des exemples accessibles de techniques architecturales vieilles de 800 ans.

activities.text: Manitou Springs exploration — Browse art galleries, crystal shops, and cafes in this bohemian mountain town famous for natural mineral springs. Eight public fountains dispense carbonated spring water with varying mineral contents and flavors.

Cave of the Winds tour — Descend into limestone caverns formed millions of years ago featuring stalactites, stalagmites, and crystalline formations. The discovery tour winds through narrow passages revealing underground wonders beneath Williams Canyon.

Sunset at Garden of the Gods — Watch the rocks glow brilliant red and orange as the setting sun illuminates the iron oxide-rich sandstone. The magic hour creates ideal conditions for landscape photography with Pikes Peak backdrop.

Exploration de Manitou Springs — Parcourez les galeries d'art, boutiques de cristaux et cafés de cette ville de montagne bohème célèbre pour ses sources minérales naturelles. Huit fontaines publiques distribuent de l'eau de source gazéifiée avec des teneurs et saveurs minérales variées.

Visite de Cave of the Winds — Descendez dans des cavernes calcaires formées il y a des millions d'années présentant stalactites, stalagmites et formations cristallines. La visite découverte serpente à travers des passages étroits révélant des merveilles souterraines sous Williams Canyon.

Coucher de soleil au Garden of the Gods — Observez les roches briller d'un rouge et orange éclatants lorsque le soleil couchant illumine le grès riche en oxyde de fer. L'heure magique crée des conditions idéales pour la photographie de paysage avec Pikes Peak en toile de fond.

days_plan.itin_title: COLORADO: ROCKY MOUNTAIN PEAKS AND WILD WEST MINING TOWNS

visits.text: Jour 1: Kenai River Corridor - The world-famous Kenai River flows from Kenai Lake through Cooper Landing and on to the Cook Inlet, supporting legendary salmon runs that attract anglers from around the globe. The river's turquoise waters, colored by glacial flour, wind through a forested valley with mountain views.
Jour 1: Kenai Lake - This 24-mile-long glacial lake fills a stunning mountain-framed basin, offering scenic beauty and recreational opportunities including boating, paddling, and shoreline hiking.

Jour 2: Kenai Peninsula Fisheries - The rivers and lakes of this region support some of the world's most productive salmon fisheries, with five Pacific salmon species returning in runs that can number in the millions. The Kenai River holds the world record for king salmon at 97 pounds, drawing anglers seeking trophy catches.

Jour 2: Russian River Confluence - The junction of the Russian and Kenai rivers creates one of Alaska's most popular fishing destinations, with sockeye salmon runs so abundant that combat fishing, with anglers standing shoulder to shoulder, has become a cultural phenomenon.

activities.text: Jour 1: Scenic Kenai River Float - Gentle rafting trips drift through the upper Kenai River canyon between Kenai Lake and Skilak Lake, passing through pristine wilderness with opportunities to observe eagles, moose, bears, and spawning salmon depending on the season. Guides share information about the region's natural and human history.

Jour 2: Guided Salmon Fishing - Professional guides provide boats, equipment, and expertise for pursuing king salmon (May-July), sockeye salmon (June-August), and silver salmon (August-September) on the Kenai River and its tributaries.
Jour 2: Trout and Char Fishing - Beyond the famous salmon runs, the region supports excellent populations of rainbow trout and Dolly Varden char, with fishing opportunities throughout the season.

days_plan.itin_title: Alaska Ultimate Wilderness Circuit - National Parks, Glaciers & Coastal Treasures
Alaska Ultimate Wilderness Circuit - National Parks, Glaciers & Coastal Treasures

visits.text: Jour 1: Wrangell-St. Elias National Park Visitor Center - The primary information facility for America's largest national park, this complex introduces the 13.2-million-acre wilderness through exhibits on the region's volcanic geology, massive glaciers, and historic copper mining heritage. The center serves as the gateway to understanding this UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Jour 1: Ahtna Cultural Center - Adjacent to the visitor center, this museum preserves and shares the heritage of the Ahtna Athabascan people who have inhabited the Copper River basin for thousands of years. Exhibits include a traditional fish wheel demonstrating the ingenious technology used to harvest salmon runs.

Jour 2: Copper River Basin Wilderness - This remote region offers access to some of Alaska's most pristine river systems, flowing through valleys flanked by glaciated peaks exceeding 16,000 feet. The watershed supports all five species of Pacific salmon, making it world-renowned among fisheries biologists and anglers alike.

activities.text: Jour 1: Copper River Valley Orientation - The tiny community of Copper Center sits at the junction of the Copper and Klutina rivers, surrounded by the Wrangell, Chugach, and Alaska mountain ranges. This strategic location has made it a crossroads for indigenous traders, gold seekers, and modern travelers alike.

Jour 2: Copper River Rafting - Float trips through this wilderness basin range from calm scenic journeys suitable for families to challenging whitewater adventures. The glacially-fed rivers wind through landscapes of extraordinary beauty, with wildlife viewing opportunities throughout.

Jour 2: Salmon Fishing Expeditions - The Copper River produces some of the world's most prized salmon, with king, sockeye, and silver runs occurring throughout summer. Guided excursions provide equipment and expertise, with catch processing and shipping services available.

Jour 2: Klutina River Fishing - Tributary streams offer additional angling opportunities in more intimate settings, with runs of salmon and resident populations of rainbow trout and Dolly Varden char.

visits.text: Descend into America's industrial past at Cornwall Iron Furnace, one of the nation's only surviving charcoal-fueled ironmaking complexes. This National Historic Landmark District, established in 1742, preserves the massive Gothic Revival buildings where iron ore was transformed into cannons, stoves, and pig iron that helped build a young nation. Tour the original furnace stack and discover the brutal labor that forged America's iron age.

visits.text: Crater Lake National Park — Marvel at America's deepest lake filling the caldera of Mount Mazama volcano that collapsed 7,700 years ago. The 594-meter-deep lake's impossibly blue water results from exceptional purity and depth absorbing all colors except blue.

Rim Drive — Circle the lake on this 53-kilometer scenic road climbing to over 2,100 meters with 30 viewpoints. The summer-only drive showcases constantly changing perspectives of Wizard Island, Phantom Ship, and surrounding peaks.

Wizard Island — Photograph this 230-meter cinder cone rising from the lake's west side, created by volcanic eruptions after the caldera formed. Boat tours allow hiking to the summit crater during summer months.

Watchman Peak Trail — Hike 1.6 kilometers to this fire lookout offering the best sunset views over Crater Lake. The relatively easy trail climbs 128 meters to panoramic vistas encompassing the entire caldera.

Crater Lake National Park — Émerveillez-vous devant le lac le plus profond d'Amérique remplissant la caldeira du volcan Mount Mazama qui s'est effondré il y a 7 700 ans. L'eau incroyablement bleue du lac de 594 mètres de profondeur résulte d'une pureté exceptionnelle et d'une profondeur absorbant toutes les couleurs sauf le bleu.

Rim Drive — Faites le tour du lac sur cette route panoramique de 53 kilomètres grimpant à plus de 2 100 mètres avec 30 points de vue. Cette route praticable uniquement en été offre des perspectives constamment changeantes de Wizard Island, Phantom Ship et des pics environnants.

Wizard Island — Photographiez ce cône de scories de 230 mètres s'élevant du côté ouest du lac, créé par des éruptions volcaniques après la formation de la caldeira. Les excursions en bateau permettent la randonnée jusqu'au cratère sommital pendant les mois d'été.

Sentier de Watchman Peak — Randonnée de 1,6 kilomètres jusqu'à ce poste de guet offrant les meilleures vues de coucher de soleil sur Crater Lake. Le sentier relativement facile grimpe de 128 mètres vers des vues panoramiques englobant toute la caldeira.

activities.text: Crater Lake Lodge visit — Stop at this 1915 rustic lodge perched on the caldera rim with floor-to-ceiling windows framing lake views. The National Historic Landmark preserves original stone fireplaces and craftsman-style architecture.

Stargazing at dark sky — Observe the Milky Way arcing overhead in one of America's darkest national parks. The high elevation and remote location create exceptional conditions for astronomy and meteor shower viewing.

Ranger talk — Attend evening programs explaining the volcanic geology, formation, and unique ecology of Crater Lake. Rangers share the Klamath tribe's legend of Llao and Skell battling to create the sacred lake.

Visite du Crater Lake Lodge — Arrêtez-vous à ce lodge rustique de 1915 perché sur le rebord de la caldeira avec des fenêtres du sol au plafond encadrant les vues sur le lac. Ce Monument Historique National préserve les cheminées en pierre d'origine et l'architecture de style artisan.

Observation des étoiles sous ciel sombre — Observez la Voie lactée qui s'arc-boute au-dessus dans l'un des parcs nationaux les plus sombres d'Amérique. L'altitude élevée et l'emplacement isolé créent des conditions exceptionnelles pour l'astronomie et l'observation des pluies de météores.

Causerie de garde forestier — Assistez aux programmes du soir expliquant la géologie volcanique, la formation et l'écologie unique de Crater Lake. Les gardes forestiers partagent la légende de la tribu Klamath sur Llao et Skell se battant pour créer le lac sacré.

visits.text: Crystal River National Wildlife Refuge - The Manatee Capital of the World: Every winter, hundreds of manatees gather in the warm spring waters here, creating the most accessible manatee-watching experience on Earth.

Three Sisters Springs - Snorkel with Manatees: This unique opportunity allows swimmers to enter the water with these gentle giants, observing them feeding, resting, and socializing in their natural winter habitat.

activities.text: Manatee Snorkeling Tours - Face to Face with Florida's State Marine Mammal: Licensed operators guide small groups into the springs for close encounters with manatees, an experience unavailable anywhere else on the planet.
Kings Bay Kayaking - Paddle Through Crystal Waters: Explore the spring-fed bay and its network of tributaries where manatees, dolphins, and sea turtles share the remarkably clear waters.

visits.text: Discover Cumberland Island, Georgia's largest and wildest barrier island where 17 miles of pristine beaches stretch beneath towering dunes and maritime forests of moss-draped oaks. Wild horses descended from colonial-era stock roam freely across 36,000 acres of protected wilderness, creating unforgettable encounters along empty shorelines. The island remains deliberately undeveloped, accessible only by ferry from St. Marys.

Explore the haunting Dungeness Ruins, crumbling remains of Thomas Carnegie's Gilded Age mansion slowly being reclaimed by resurrection ferns and climbing vines. The grand Plum Orchard Mansion showcases meticulously preserved Carnegie-era architecture and furnishings. The historic First African Baptist Church and Stafford Plantation cemetery document the island's complex history of enslaved people and freed African Americans.

activities.text: Hike or bike over 50 miles of trails winding through moss-draped maritime forest, past salt marshes teeming with wildlife, and along windswept beaches where loggerhead sea turtles nest each summer. Limited ferry capacity and minimal facilities preserve the island's remote, mysterious character for those willing to plan ahead.

visits.text: Explore the Dallas Museum of Art and the adjacent Nasher Sculpture Center, showcasing world-class collections spanning 5,000 years of human creativity. The city boasts the largest urban arts district in the United States, offering exceptional cultural experiences for art enthusiasts and casual visitors alike. These neighboring institutions create a comprehensive artistic journey through both traditional and contemporary works.

Visit the Sixth Floor Museum at Dealey Plaza, housed in the former Texas School Book Depository from which President John F. Kennedy was assassinated in 1963. The museum provides a detailed and moving account of the president's life, death, and legacy through historical exhibits, photographs, and artifacts. This landmark site offers profound insights into one of America's most significant historical events.

activities.text: Discover the Perot Museum of Nature and Science, a striking architectural landmark featuring interactive exhibits on everything from dinosaurs to DNA and space exploration. Families and science enthusiasts will find hours of engaging educational entertainment across multiple floors of cutting-edge displays. The museum's dynamic approach makes complex scientific concepts accessible and exciting for all ages.

Stroll through the Dallas Arboretum and Botanical Garden, a 66-acre oasis on the shores of White Rock Lake featuring seasonal flower displays and themed garden areas. The Swiss Avenue Historic District nearby showcases magnificent 19th-century Victorian and neoclassical architecture. The vibrant Deep Ellum neighborhood offers excellent nightlife, live music venues, and eclectic street art.

days_plan.itin_title: Texas Discovery: From Vibrant Cities to Desert Wilderness

visits.text: Daytona Beach - The World's Most Famous Beach: Twenty-three miles of hard-packed white sand have earned this Atlantic destination its legendary status. This is one of the few beaches where you can drive directly onto the sand and park steps from the surf.

Daytona International Speedway - The World Center of Racing: Home to the Daytona 500 and numerous NASCAR events throughout the year, this 2.5-mile tri-oval track also hosts concerts and special events. Tours take visitors behind the scenes of racing history.

Daytona Beach Boardwalk and Pier - Classic Americana: This oceanfront landmark features arcades, rides, shops, and restaurants stretching along the shore, anchored by the historic pier extending into the Atlantic.

activities.text: Beach Driving - A Florida Tradition Since 1903: Early automobile pioneers raced on this hard-packed sand, and today visitors can experience the unique thrill of parking their vehicle right on the beach with waves crashing nearby.

visits.text: Death Valley National Park - The Hottest, Driest, Lowest Place in North America: This vast desert wilderness holds the world record for highest reliably recorded air temperature (134°F). Yet within its 3.4 million acres, life persists in remarkable adaptations, and landscapes of surreal beauty unfold.

Badwater Basin - Stand at 282 Feet Below Sea Level: Hexagonal salt flats stretch toward distant mountains at the lowest point in North America. The basin supports a unique ecosystem including the endemic Badwater snail.

Zabriskie Point - Sunrise Over Martian Badlands: These eroded mudstone formations glow gold and amber as first light strikes their contours, creating one of the most photographed desert scenes on Earth.

Mesquite Flat Sand Dunes - Saharan Splendor in California: These undulating dunes near Stovepipe Wells rise up to 100 feet, their pristine surfaces erased and redrawn by desert winds. Dawn and dusk light transforms them into sculptural masterpieces.

activities.text: Artist's Palette - A Mountain Painted in Minerals: This hillside showcases nature's full palette through oxidized metals creating stripes of pink, green, purple, and gold across barren slopes.

Racetrack Playa - The Mystery of the Sailing Stones: Rocks weighing hundreds of pounds leave long tracks across this remote dry lakebed, moved by a rare combination of ice, wind, and water only recently explained by science.

visits.text: Walk in the footsteps of 'The Greatest' at Fighter's Heaven, Muhammad Ali's legendary training camp where the three-time heavyweight champion prepared for his most iconic bouts. This six-acre retreat nestled in the Blue Mountains served as Ali's sanctuary from 1972 to 1981, where he trained for the 'Rumble in the Jungle' and 'Thrilla in Manila.' Now restored as a museum, the rustic facilities preserve Ali's gym, living quarters, and the boulder-lined trails where he honed his lightning reflexes.

days_plan.itin_title: MINNESOTA -THE BEST PLACES !

visits.text: Jour 1: Denali National Park Visitor Center - The primary orientation point for this six-million-acre wilderness preserve, featuring comprehensive exhibits on the park's ecosystems, geology, and the cultural history of the Athabascan people who have inhabited this region for millennia. Rangers provide daily programs and essential information for exploring the park's single 92-mile road.

Jour 1: Denali Park Road (First 15 Miles) - The only section accessible to private vehicles, this scenic drive passes through taiga forest and offers the first glimpses of Denali when skies are clear. Pullouts at Savage River provide hiking access and wildlife viewing opportunities.

Jour 2: Tundra Wilderness Tour (62 miles) - This seven to eight-hour narrated bus journey penetrates deep into Denali's wilderness, crossing Polychrome Pass with its multicolored volcanic formations and descending to the Toklat River basin. The route traverses prime habitat for grizzly bears, wolves, caribou, Dall sheep, and moose, with knowledgeable drivers stopping for wildlife sightings.

Jour 2: Kantishna Experience (92 miles) - The full-day twelve-hour expedition travels the entire length of the park road to the historic mining district of Kantishna. This immersive journey maximizes wildlife viewing opportunities and reaches the most remote accessible areas of the park, with Wonder Lake offering iconic Denali reflections on calm days.

Jour 2: Eielson Visitor Center - Located at mile 66, this sustainable facility perched at 3,500 feet elevation provides panoramic views of Denali and the Muldrow Glacier. Exhibits explain glaciology and the mountain's unique weather patterns that make summit visibility a treasured occurrence.

activities.text: Jour 1: Denali Flightseeing - Aerial tours departing from the park entrance reveal the immense scale of the Alaska Range, with glaciers flowing from Denali's flanks and vast expanses of untouched wilderness stretching to every horizon.

Jour 1: Nenana River Rafting - The Nenana River paralleling the park entrance offers both scenic float trips through pristine canyon scenery and exhilarating Class III-IV whitewater sections through Nenana Canyon.

Jour 1: Guided Wilderness Hiking - Naturalist-led excursions venture into roadless areas of the park, teaching backcountry navigation and wildlife awareness while exploring tundra ecosystems rarely seen by casual visitors.

Jour 2: Transit Bus System - The National Park Service operates a hop-on, hop-off shuttle allowing independent exploration. Visitors can disembark at any point to hike unmarked wilderness routes, then catch a later bus to continue deeper into the park or return to the entrance.

days_plan.itin_title: ALASKA — KENAI FJORDS & DENALI FROM ANCHORAGE
ALASKA — KENAI FJORDS & DENALI FROM ANCHORAGE

visits.text: Red Rocks Park and Amphitheatre — Explore this natural amphitheatre carved into 300-million-year-old red sandstone formations rising 122 meters. The venue has hosted legendary concerts since 1906, with perfect acoustics created by the geological formations flanking the 9,525-capacity seating.

Denver Art Museum — Discover encyclopedic collections in this architectural landmark featuring Daniel Libeskind's 2006 addition clad in titanium. The museum houses 70,000 works including the world's premier Native American art collection and contemporary Western American pieces.

Union Station — Stroll through this Beaux-Arts railway station restored in 2014 as a mixed-use hub featuring restaurants, bars, and boutique hotel. The 1894 Great Hall maintains its historic character with soaring ceilings and vintage chandeliers.

State Capitol Building — Climb to the 13th step marking exactly one mile above sea level and tour this 1894 Colorado granite building topped with 200 ounces of gold leaf. The dome offers 360-degree views across Denver to the Rocky Mountain Front Range.

Great Sand Dunes National Park — Marvel at North America's tallest dunes reaching 230 meters high against the Sangre de Cristo Mountains backdrop. The 78 square kilometers of sand create a surreal desert landscape at 2,438 meters elevation in the San Luis Valley.

Medano Creek — Wade and splash in this seasonal creek flowing along the dune field base from April through June. The unique stream creates beach-like conditions with sand and water in the Rocky Mountains.
Zapata Falls — Hike 0.8 kilometers to this hidden 9-meter waterfall cascading through a narrow rock crevice. The short trail leads to refreshing spray and cool air emanating from the slot canyon.
Denver LoDo warm‑up and gear check; evening at Union Station.
Return across mountain passes with weather‑safe pacing; optional Georgetown stop.
Retour via Peak‑to‑Peak Scenic Byway ; arrêt optionnel à Boulder Pearl Street.
Departure buffer and museums option.

Red Rocks Park and Amphitheatre — Explorez cet amphithéâtre naturel sculpté dans des formations de grès rouge vieilles de 300 millions d'années s'élevant à 122 mètres. Le lieu accueille des concerts légendaires depuis 1906, avec une acoustique parfaite créée par les formations géologiques flanquant les 9 525 places assises.

Denver Art Museum — Découvrez des collections encyclopédiques dans ce monument architectural comprenant l'ajout de Daniel Libeskind de 2006 revêtu de titane. Le musée abrite 70 000 œuvres incluant la première collection mondiale d'art amérindien et des pièces contemporaines de l'Ouest américain.

Union Station — Promenez-vous dans cette gare ferroviaire Beaux-Arts restaurée en 2014 comme hub à usage mixte comprenant restaurants, bars et hôtel-boutique. Le Great Hall de 1894 maintient son caractère historique avec des plafonds voûtés et des lustres vintage.

State Capitol Building — Montez jusqu'à la 13ème marche marquant exactement un mile au-dessus du niveau de la mer et visitez ce bâtiment de 1894 en granit du Colorado surmonté de 200 onces de feuilles d'or. Le dôme offre des vues à 360 degrés sur Denver jusqu'au Front Range des Montagnes Rocheuses.

Great Sand Dunes National Park — Émerveillez-vous devant les plus hautes dunes d'Amérique du Nord atteignant 230 mètres de haut sur fond des montagnes Sangre de Cristo. Les 78 kilomètres carrés de sable créent un paysage désertique surréaliste à 2 438 mètres d'altitude dans la vallée San Luis.

Medano Creek — Pataugez et éclaboussez dans ce ruisseau saisonnier coulant le long de la base du champ de dunes d'avril à juin. Le cours d'eau unique crée des conditions semblables à une plage avec sable et eau dans les montagnes Rocheuses.

Zapata Falls — Randonnez sur 0,8 kilomètre jusqu'à cette cascade cachée de 9 mètres cascadant à travers une étroite crevasse rocheuse. Le court sentier mène aux embruns rafraîchissants et à l'air frais émanant du canyon en fente.
Échauffement à Denver LoDo et vérification de l'équipement ; soirée à Union Station.
Retour par les cols de montagne avec un rythme sécurisé selon la météo ; arrêt optionnel à Georgetown.
Temps de réserve pour le départ et option musées.

activities.text: LoDo neighborhood exploration — Browse galleries, brewpubs, and restaurants in the Lower Downtown Historic District featuring Victorian-era warehouses converted into trendy spaces. The revitalized 19th-century district anchors Denver's craft beer scene.

Craft brewery tasting — Sample IPAs and stouts at one of Denver's 150+ breweries making it America's top craft beer city. The high altitude and pure mountain water create ideal brewing conditions for innovative beer styles.

16th Street Mall stroll — Walk or ride the free shuttle along this mile-long pedestrian promenade linking downtown attractions. Street performers, outdoor cafes, and shops create vibrant urban energy beneath honeylocust trees.

Sand sledding adventure — Rent boards or sleds to slide down towering dunes, a unique Colorado experience combining beach and mountain activities. The soft sand provides safe landings for this unusual desert sport.

Scenic drive to Denver — Journey north through the San Luis Valley and along the Front Range admiring Colorado's diverse landscapes. The return trip showcases the transition from desert to mountains to plains.
Provisioning for altitude and variable mountain weather.
Buffer and departure prep.

Exploration du quartier LoDo — Parcourez les galeries, brasseries et restaurants du Lower Downtown Historic District avec ses entrepôts de l'époque victorienne convertis en espaces branchés. Ce district revitalisé du 19ème siècle est le pilier de la scène bière artisanale de Denver.

Dégustation de brasserie artisanale — Goûtez des IPA et stouts dans l'une des 150+ brasseries de Denver qui en font la capitale américaine de la bière artisanale. L'altitude élevée et l'eau pure de montagne créent des conditions de brassage idéales pour des styles de bière innovants.

Promenade sur 16th Street Mall — Marchez ou prenez la navette gratuite le long de cette promenade piétonne d'un mile reliant les attractions du centre-ville. Artistes de rue, cafés en plein air et boutiques créent une énergie urbaine vibrante sous les féviers d'Amérique.

Aventure de luge sur sable — Louez des planches ou des luges pour glisser le long de dunes imposantes, une expérience unique du Colorado combinant activités de plage et de montagne. Le sable doux offre des atterrissages sécurisés pour ce sport désertique inhabituel.

Route panoramique vers Denver — Voyagez vers le nord à travers la San Luis Valley et le long du Front Range en admirant les paysages diversifiés du Colorado. Le voyage de retour présente la transition du désert aux montagnes puis aux plaines.
Préparatifs pour l'altitude et les conditions météorologiques variables en montagne.

visits.text: Dodge City - Where the Wild West Was Won: Long before Gunsmoke made it famous, Dodge City defined the American frontier, triggered by a stream of Santa Fe Trail voyagers whose wagon ruts still scar the grasslands.

Boot Hill Museum - Relive the Old West's Most Notorious Town: The saloon, jail, and general store bring Dodge City's lawless heyday to life, while an interactive exhibit hall lets visitors feel the floor shake during a simulated buffalo stampede.
Front Street Gunfights - Where Outlaws Met Their Match: Costumed performers recreate the confrontations that made Dodge City legendary, staging shootouts along the historic main street.

Santa Fe Trail Wagon Ruts - Traces of Western Expansion: West of town, follow a walkway and interpretive signs to view some of the most clearly defined wagon ruts along the entire 900-mile Santa Fe Trail.

activities.text: Dodge City Days - Annual Western Celebration: Time your visit for the summer festival featuring rodeos, a longhorn cattle drive through downtown, and a Western parade celebrating the city's heritage.

days_plan.itin_title: Kansas Unveiled: From Tallgrass Prairies to Space Exploration - Discovering America's Heartland

visits.text: Marvel at the creative genius of Henry Chapman Mercer along the Mercer Mile, a trio of extraordinary concrete structures that defy architectural convention. Begin at Fonthill Castle, the archaeologist's fantastical home featuring 44 rooms, 18 fireplaces, and over 900 handcrafted tile designs embedded in ceilings and walls, creating a National Historic Landmark that feels like wandering through a three-dimensional mosaic.

Continue to the towering Mercer Museum, a six-story concrete castle housing 50,000 artifacts representing 60 early American trades and crafts. Gaze up at a complete Conestoga wagon suspended from the ceiling, examine whaling harpoons and gallows, and discover how pre-industrial Americans lived, worked, and created before the machine age transformed daily life.

Complete your Mercer pilgrimage at Moravian Pottery and Tile Works, where artisans still craft decorative tiles using techniques Mercer perfected over a century ago. Watch as skilled hands press clay into historic molds, creating the same Arts and Crafts masterpieces that adorn buildings from Harrisburg's state capitol to Rockefeller's Manhattan mansion.

activities.text: Strike the mysterious boulders of Ringing Rocks Park and listen as they produce bell-like tones that have puzzled scientists for generations. Bring a hammer to this 123-acre geological wonder where diabase rocks sing when struck, then venture onward to witness Bucks County's largest cascade at High Falls.

days_plan.itin_title: Pennsylvania Heritage Trail - Where American History Meets Natural Splendor

visits.text: Dry Tortugas National Park - America's Most Remote National Park: Located 70 miles west of Key West, this small chain of islands requires a ferry or seaplane to reach, rewarding visitors with pristine beaches, exceptional snorkeling, and a massive Civil War fortress.

Fort Jefferson - The Largest Masonry Structure in the Americas: This hexagonal fortress rises from Garden Key, its walls constructed from 16 million bricks yet never completed despite 30 years of construction. Its most famous prisoner was Dr. Samuel Mudd, convicted of conspiracy in Lincoln's assassination.

activities.text: Snorkeling the Pristine Reefs - Caribbean Waters in American Territory: The clear, protected waters surrounding the islands offer some of the best snorkeling in North America, with coral formations and tropical fish rivaling any Caribbean destination.

Camping Under the Stars - Sleep in the Fortress Shadow: Limited primitive camping allows overnight visitors to experience the islands after day-trippers depart, with star-filled skies unspoiled by light pollution.

days_plan.itin_title: NEW YORK

visits.text: Durango & Silverton Narrow Gauge Railroad — Ride this historic coal-fired steam train through 72 kilometers of spectacular San Juan Mountains scenery. The 1882 railroad climbs from Durango to the mining town of Silverton following the Animas River through roadless wilderness.

Mesa Verde National Park — Explore 600 cliff dwellings built by Ancestral Puebloans between 600-1300 CE, including the spectacular Cliff Palace with 150 rooms and 23 kivas. The UNESCO World Heritage Site preserves 5,000 archaeological sites across 21,240 hectares.

Balcony House — Tour this dramatic cliff dwelling accessible only by ladder climbs and crawling through a 3.6-meter tunnel. Rangers guide small groups through 40 rooms built 183 meters above the canyon floor around 1180 CE.
Mesa Verde — Chapin Mesa Museum and ranger‑led dwelling access (ticketed, seasonal).

Durango & Silverton Narrow Gauge Railroad — Voyagez dans ce train à vapeur historique alimenté au charbon à travers 72 kilomètres de paysages spectaculaires des montagnes San Juan. Le chemin de fer de 1882 monte de Durango à la ville minière de Silverton en suivant la rivière Animas à travers une nature sauvage sans routes.

Parc national Mesa Verde — Explorez 600 habitations troglodytiques construites par les Pueblos ancestraux entre 600 et 1300 de notre ère, incluant le spectaculaire Cliff Palace avec 150 pièces et 23 kivas. Le site du patrimoine mondial de l'UNESCO préserve 5 000 sites archéologiques sur 21 240 hectares.

Balcony House — Visitez cette spectaculaire habitation troglodytique accessible seulement par des montées d'échelle et en rampant dans un tunnel de 3,6 mètres. Les gardes guident de petits groupes à travers 40 pièces construites à 183 mètres au-dessus du fond du canyon vers 1180 de notre ère.
Mesa Verde — Musée Chapin Mesa et accès aux habitations avec guide ranger (avec billet, saisonnier).
Black Canyon of the Gunnison — South Rim overlooks from the Visitor Center area and along the rim road.

activities.text: Historic Durango downtown — Browse this preserved Victorian commercial district featuring red brick buildings, saloons, and the Strater Hotel with its Diamond Belle Saloon. The walkable downtown maintains its Wild West character.

Animas River Trail cycling — Bike along 12 kilometers of paved riverside path through Durango offering mountain views and whitewater access. The trail connects parks and attractions while following the river's course.

Southwestern cuisine dinner — Taste green chile, posole, and blue corn enchiladas reflecting the region's Native American and Hispanic heritage. Local restaurants emphasize New Mexican flavors and locally sourced ingredients.

Centre-ville historique de Durango — Parcourez ce district commercial victorien préservé avec ses bâtiments en briques rouges, ses saloons et le Strater Hotel avec son Diamond Belle Saloon. Le centre-ville piétonnier conserve son caractère du Far West.

Cyclisme sur l'Animas River Trail — Faites du vélo le long de 12 kilomètres de sentier pavé au bord de la rivière à travers Durango offrant des vues sur les montagnes et l'accès aux eaux vives. Le sentier relie les parcs et attractions tout en suivant le cours de la rivière.

Dîner de cuisine du Sud-Ouest — Goûtez le piment vert, le posole et les enchiladas au maïs bleu reflétant l'héritage amérindien et hispanique de la région. Les restaurants locaux mettent l'accent sur les saveurs du Nouveau-Mexique et les ingrédients d'origine locale.
Promenade du soir dans le centre historique de Durango.
Photography of near‑vertical schist walls in golden light.

Heart of Vilas County Trail - Scenic hiking and biking path winding through thick pine forests and past crystalline lakes.
Eagle River Chain of Lakes - 28 interconnected lakes forming one of the world's largest freshwater chains, perfect for boating, fishing, and swimming.
Manitowish Waters - Pristine Northwoods destination surrounded by ten wilderness lakes, pine forests, and abundant wildlife.

visits.text: Discover America's oldest continuously operating open-air farmers' market at Easton Farmers' Market, where vendors have gathered along the Delaware River since 1752. Browse stalls overflowing with fresh local produce, artisanal cheeses, and handcrafted goods every Saturday from May through December in scenic Scott Park, continuing a tradition that predates American independence itself.

activities.text: Soar above two millennia of raptors in flight at Hawk Mountain Sanctuary, the world's first refuge dedicated to protecting birds of prey. From spectacular overlooks along the Appalachian flyway, witness the annual autumn migration as thousands of eagles, hawks, and falcons ride thermal currents southward. The hawkwatch season runs August through December, with peak bald eagle sightings in mid-August.

visits.text: Step back in time at the historic Chowan County Courthouse, a remarkable Georgian architectural landmark dating back to 1767 that dominates Edenton's charming downtown skyline. This beautifully preserved building represents one of North Carolina's finest examples of colonial-era civic architecture and offers insight into the region's early American heritage.

Tour the magnificent Penelope Barker House, an exceptional example of Greek Revival-Federal architectural fusion built in 1782. This elegant historic home showcases period artifacts representing life in colonial and early American Edenton, providing visitors with a fascinating window into the town's distinguished past.

activities.text: Enjoy a leisurely stroll through Colonial Waterfront Park while soaking up breathtaking views of Albemarle Sound. The park offers a peaceful setting to appreciate Edenton's scenic waterfront and historic charm. Browse local artworks at the Chowan Arts Council, which highlights the creative talents of regional artists in this picturesque historic community.

visits.text: Door County - Scenic 70-mile peninsula between Lake Michigan and Green Bay, famous for cherry orchards, rocky shorelines, lighthouses, and artsy villages.
Peninsula State Park - 3,776-acre park with dramatic bluffs, scenic trails, and the historic Eagle Bluff Lighthouse overlooking Green Bay.
Eagle Bluff Lighthouse - 1868 lighthouse offering guided tours and panoramic views from atop the limestone cliffs.
Fish Creek - Charming waterfront village with galleries, shops, and scenic harbor perfect for evening strolls.
Door Peninsula Winery - Local winery producing fruit wines from Door County's famous cherry and apple orchards.
Peninsula Players Theatre - America's oldest professional resident summer theater, presenting plays under the stars since 1935.

activities.text: Cherry orchard visit to sample fresh cherries, tangy cherry salsa, homemade cherry pie, and cider donuts at roadside farm markets.
Hiking the bluffs and beaches of Peninsula State Park with views across the emerald waters of Green Bay.

visits.text: Experience pure joy at Knoebels Amusement Resort, America's largest free-admission amusement park tucked into a pristine mountain valley. Family-owned since 1926, this nostalgic treasure features 60 rides including three legendary wooden coasters, an original 1913 carousel, and the acclaimed Haunted Mansion consistently ranked among the nation's best dark rides. Free parking, free admission, and reasonable ride prices make this Golden Ticket Award winner the antidote to modern theme park excess, where generations of families return yearly to recapture the simple magic of summer.

days_plan.itin_title: WISCONSIN, GO TO THE BEST PLACES !

visits.text: Sink your toes into sugar-white sand along the 11 pristine beaches of Presque Isle State Park, a 3,200-acre sandy peninsula curving gracefully into Lake Erie's turquoise waters. This ecological treasure hosts seven distinct ecological zones, from windswept dunes to tranquil lagoons, earning recognition as one of America's premier birding destinations with over 340 species recorded. Linger for legendary sunsets that paint the Great Lake in watercolor washes of gold and crimson.

Discover the 'Niagara of Pennsylvania' at Ricketts Glen State Park, where 22 named waterfalls cascade through an ancient hemlock forest along the Falls Trail. The 7.2-mile loop descends through Ganoga Glen, passing 94-foot Ganoga Falls-the park's tallest cascade-before climbing through Glen Leigh's thundering cataracts. This primeval landscape, preserved since the last Ice Age, ranks among the most beautiful hiking destinations in the eastern United States.

activities.text: Kayak the sheltered lagoons and shoreline of Presque Isle, where crystal-clear waters reveal underwater meadows and sandbars teeming with fish. Paddle past historic lighthouses, glide alongside great blue herons in marshy backwaters, and experience the Great Lakes' ecological diversity from water level.

days_plan.itin_title: Pennsylvania Heritage Trail - Where American History Meets Natural Splendor

visits.text: Essex Steam Train & Riverboat - Journey Through Time on Rails and Water: Board a vintage steam locomotive at the historic 1892 Essex Station for a 2.5-hour round-trip adventure through the Connecticut River Valley. Two operating steam locomotives pull various passenger coaches, including a seasonal open-air car, on a 12-mile journey to Deep River Landing.

Becky Thatcher Riverboat Cruise - Glide Past Castles and Covered Bridges: Transfer to a classic riverboat for a picturesque cruise along the Connecticut River, taking in views of Gillette Castle perched above, the Haddam Swing Bridge, and the ornate Goodspeed Opera House along the tree-lined shores.

Connecticut River Museum - Celebrating 410 Miles of Living History: Housed in the historic Steamboat Dock building in downtown Essex, this museum explores the cultural and natural history of New England's longest river through artwork, memorabilia, interactive exhibits, and guided river cruises.

activities.text: Essex Village - Connecticut's Most Perfect Town: This carefully preserved village consistently ranks among America's most charming small towns, with Federal-era architecture, yacht-filled harbor, and quiet streets that embody New England's maritime heritage.

days_plan.itin_title: Connecticut Unveiled: Maritime Heritage, Ivy League Culture & New England's Hidden Gem
Connecticut Unveiled: Maritime Heritage, Ivy League Culture & New England's Hidden Gem

visits.text: Rocky Mountain National Park — Trail Ridge Road — Drive America's highest continuous paved road cresting at 3,713 meters with 48 miles traversing alpine tundra above treeline. The scenic byway offers panoramic views of snow-capped peaks, mountain lakes, and opportunities to spot elk, bighorn sheep, and marmots.

Bear Lake — Hike around this glacially-carved alpine lake at 2,880 meters elevation surrounded by dramatic peaks. The easy 0.8-mile loop trail offers stunning reflections of Hallett Peak and Flattop Mountain in the crystalline waters.

Alberta Falls — Trek 1.7 miles roundtrip to this cascading 25-foot waterfall thundering through Glacier Gorge. The popular trail winds through subalpine forest with mountain views rewarding the 250-foot elevation gain.

Sprague Lake — Photograph Continental Divide peaks reflected in this accessible mountain lake created by a 1915 dam. The wheelchair-accessible 0.5-mile loop provides classic Rocky Mountain scenery without steep hiking.
Trail Ridge Road status check; Moraine Park wildlife meadows and visitor center exhibits.
Alpine lakes day — Dream/Nymph/Emerald Lake chain or alternative lower‑elevation loops in shoulder seasons.

Rocky Mountain National Park — Trail Ridge Road — Conduisez sur la route pavée continue la plus haute d'Amérique culminant à 3 713 mètres avec 48 miles traversant la toundra alpine au-dessus de la limite des arbres. Cette route panoramique offre des vues panoramiques sur les pics enneigés, les lacs de montagne et des opportunités d'observer élans, mouflons et marmottes.

Bear Lake — Randonnez autour de ce lac alpin sculpté par les glaciers à 2 880 mètres d'altitude entouré de pics spectaculaires. Le sentier en boucle facile de 0,8 mile offre de magnifiques reflets de Hallett Peak et Flattop Mountain dans les eaux cristallines.

Alberta Falls — Parcourez 1,7 miles aller-retour jusqu'à cette cascade de 25 pieds qui gronde à travers Glacier Gorge. Le sentier populaire serpente à travers la forêt subalpine avec des vues montagneuses récompensant les 250 pieds de dénivelé.

Sprague Lake — Photographiez les pics du Continental Divide reflétés dans ce lac de montagne accessible créé par un barrage de 1915. La boucle accessible en fauteuil roulant de 0,5 mile offre un paysage classique des Rocheuses sans randonnée escarpée.
Vérification du statut de Trail Ridge Road ; prairies fauniques de Moraine Park et expositions du centre des visiteurs.
Journée des lacs alpins — chaîne Dream/Nymph/Emerald Lake ou boucles alternatives à basse altitude en saisons intermédiaires.

activities.text: Wildlife watching in Moraine Park — Scan meadows for elk herds numbering 600-800 during fall rutting season when bulls bugle to attract mates. The valley also hosts mule deer, coyotes, and occasional black bears.

Estes Park downtown browsing — Explore this charming mountain town serving as gateway to Rocky Mountain National Park since the early 1900s. Shops sell Western art, outdoor gear, and taffy made on-site at traditional candy stores.

Stanley Hotel tour — Visit the 1909 Colonial Revival hotel that inspired Stephen King's The Shining after his 1974 stay. Ghost tours recount paranormal activity while daytime tours showcase original furnishings and mountain views.
Short lakeside walk near Estes Park.

Observation de la faune à Moraine Park — Scrutez les prairies pour les troupeaux d'élans comptant 600-800 individus durant la saison de brame d'automne quand les mâles brament pour attirer les femelles. La vallée abrite aussi cerfs mulets, coyotes et ours noirs occasionnels.

Flânerie dans le centre-ville d'Estes Park — Explorez cette charmante ville de montagne servant de porte d'entrée au Rocky Mountain National Park depuis le début des années 1900. Les boutiques vendent art western, équipement de plein air et caramels faits sur place dans des confiseries traditionnelles.

Visite du Stanley Hotel — Visitez cet hôtel Colonial Revival de 1909 qui inspira The Shining de Stephen King après son séjour de 1974. Les visites fantômes racontent l'activité paranormale tandis que les visites de jour présentent le mobilier d'origine et les vues montagneuses.
Courte promenade au bord du lac près d'Estes Park.

days_plan.itin_title: NORTHERN CALIFORNIA PARKS — LASSEN VOLCANIC & REDWOOD COUNTRY

visits.text: Eureka Springs Historic Downtown - America's Victorian Village Frozen in Time: Winding through steep Ozark hillsides, this entire downtown district is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. No two streets run parallel as Victorian limestone buildings cascade down ravines, connected by stone stairways and hidden gardens. The town has never had a traffic light.

Thorncrown Chapel - A Glass Cathedral in the Forest: Rising 48 feet through oak and pine woodland, this architectural masterpiece uses 425 windows and over 6,000 square feet of glass to dissolve the boundary between sanctuary and nature. Named the fourth finest building of the 20th century by the American Institute of Architects.

Basin Spring Park - The Healing Waters That Built a Town: Native Americans prized these springs for centuries before Victorian health-seekers arrived in 1879, creating a boomtown virtually overnight. The restored basin now anchors a charming plaza surrounded by galleries and street musicians.

activities.text: Historic Loop Trolley - Narrated Journey Through Living History: Vintage trolleys navigate the town's impossible terrain while guides share tales of the eccentric characters, paranormal legends, and architectural treasures hidden in every hollow.

days_plan.itin_title: Arkansas Unveiled: Mountains, Diamonds & Healing Waters of the Natural State
Arkansas Unveiled: Mountains, Diamonds & Healing Waters of the Natural State

visits.text: Everglades National Park - The River of Grass: This UNESCO World Heritage Site and International Biosphere Reserve protects 1.5 million acres of subtropical wilderness, home to the endangered Florida panther and millions of alligators.

Shark Valley - Fourteen Miles into the Wild: Cycle or tram through sawgrass prairie to an observation tower offering 360-degree views across seemingly endless wetlands teeming with alligators and wading birds.

Anhinga Trail at Royal Palm - Guaranteed Wildlife Encounters: This half-mile boardwalk trail at Royal Palm provides some of the most reliable wildlife viewing in Florida, with alligators, anhingas, herons, and turtles visible year-round.
Flamingo Visitor Center - Where Fresh Water Meets Salt: This southern outpost provides access to Florida Bay's mangrove estuaries, with kayaking, camping, and dolphin-watching opportunities.

activities.text: Airboat Tours - Skimming the River of Grass: These flat-bottomed boats powered by aircraft propellers are the traditional way to explore the Everglades, accessing areas no other vessel can reach.
Backcountry Camping - Sleep Among the Chickees: Platform campsites called 'chickees' allow overnight stays in the heart of the wetlands, an unforgettable wilderness experience.

days_plan.itin_title: Florida Unveiled: From Pristine Barrier Islands to Tropical Keys - The Ultimate Sunshine State Adventure
Florida Unveiled: From Pristine Barrier Islands to Tropical Keys - The Ultimate Sunshine State Adventure

visits.text: Fairbanks — Morris Thompson Cultural & Visitors Center for Alaska Native cultures and travel updates.
Return to Fairbanks along the Parks Highway with pullouts for Alaska Range views.
Buffer and departures.

Jour 1: University of Alaska Museum of the North - This architecturally striking museum houses over 1.4 million artifacts spanning Alaska's natural and cultural heritage. Galleries showcase the state's diverse ecosystems, from Arctic tundra to temperate rainforest, while extensive collections of Alaska Native art and artifacts represent thousands of years of indigenous innovation and artistry. The building's sweeping white facade evokes glacial ice and snow-covered peaks.

Jour 1: Trans-Alaska Pipeline Viewpoint - Witness one of the world's largest pipeline systems at a dedicated viewing area where the 800-mile engineering marvel emerges above ground. Interpretive displays explain how this technological achievement transports crude oil from Prudhoe Bay to Valdez across three mountain ranges, numerous rivers, and permafrost terrain.

Jour 2: Riverboat Discovery - A three-hour voyage aboard an authentic sternwheeler navigates the Chena and Tanana rivers, showcasing Alaska's river heritage. The journey includes stops at a replica Athabascan village demonstrating traditional fishing and survival techniques, and an active dog kennel where champion sled dogs train year-round.

Jour 2: Gold Dredge 8 National Historic District - This preserved gold mining operation features the massive dredge that processed millions of cubic yards of gravel during its 1928-1959 operational period. Visitors can pan for gold in troughs fed with paydirt, keeping any flakes or nuggets discovered.
In Fairbanks, Chris buys some provisions and basic equipment, but refuses to equip himself heavily despite advice from locals.
Fairbanks — Centre culturel et d'accueil Morris Thompson pour les cultures autochtones de l'Alaska et les mises à jour de voyage.
Retour à Fairbanks le long de la Parks Highway avec arrêts pour les vues sur l'Alaska Range.

Jour 1: Interior Alaska Discovery - Fairbanks, Alaska's second-largest city, serves as the commercial hub of the state's vast interior region. Founded during the 1902 gold rush, the city maintains historic sites while serving as a center for aurora research, Arctic science, and indigenous cultural preservation.

Jour 2: Arctic Circle Excursion - Day trips venture 200 miles north along the Dalton Highway to cross the Arctic Circle at latitude 66°33'. This expedition traverses the boreal forest transition into arctic tundra, crossing the Yukon River and entering a landscape of permafrost and endless summer daylight or winter darkness.

Jour 2: Running Reindeer Ranch - Interact with a herd of free-roaming reindeer on a family homestead, learning about these Arctic-adapted ungulates and their importance to northern indigenous cultures.

Jour 2: Sled Dog Demonstrations - Summer visitors can meet champion racing teams and learn about the Iditarod and other long-distance mushing traditions that remain central to Alaskan culture and winter transportation.

Sunken Garden and Grounds - 152 Acres of New England Beauty: Explore rolling hills, serene walking paths through lush woodlands, and the famous Beatrix Farrand-designed Sunken Garden. The grounds achieve peak splendor in autumn when foliage transforms the landscape into a masterpiece.

activities.text: Poetry Festival and Cultural Events - Where Art Meets Nature: The museum hosts the renowned Sunken Garden Poetry Festival each summer, along with year-round lectures, concerts, and educational programs in this sublime setting.

days_plan.itin_title: ROUTE 66 IN 14 DAYS: FROM CHICAGO TO THE PACIFIC

visits.text: Push open the unassuming doors of Muscle Shoals Sound Studio and enter hallowed ground where the magic of American music was forged by four visionary session musicians. This modest building on a busy highway witnessed Cher reinventing herself, Rod Stewart finding his raspy soul, and the Rolling Stones laying down three tracks during a legendary recording session. Stand on the same porch where Mick and Keith posed for photos, or recreate Cher's iconic album cover shot at the entrance to 3614 Jackson Highway.

Experience Frank Lloyd Wright's democratic vision at the Rosenbaum House, the only Wright-designed structure in Alabama and a pristine example of his affordable Usonian concept. Built in 1939 for newlyweds Stanley and Mildred Rosenbaum, every element from built-in furniture to clerestory windows bears the architect's revolutionary touch. The intimate guided tour reveals how Wright believed families should spend less time indoors and more time embracing nature's beauty.

Pay homage to one of history's most remarkable women at Ivy Green, the Tuscumbia birthplace where Helen Keller learned to communicate despite being deaf and blind from infancy. Walk the grounds where teacher Anne Sullivan's patient devotion unlocked a brilliant mind, and visit the pump where Helen first connected the sign for water to the cool liquid flowing over her hands. The preserved family home and gardens offer profound insight into the determination that made Keller a global advocate for the disabled.

activities.text: Dig into golden-fried Southern comfort at Champy's, a roadside institution where chicken is cooked to order and arrives crackling hot in red plastic baskets. The no-frills atmosphere of melamine tables and checkered tablecloths sets the stage for seriously good eating, from succulent bone-in pieces to tangy coleslaw and buttery baked beans. Check out the vintage jukebox and neon signs while you lick your fingers clean.

Cap your Shoals exploration with refined seasonal cuisine at Odette, Florence's destination restaurant where locally sourced ingredients meet Southern flair in an elegant yet relaxed setting. The charcuterie board is legendary, with over a dozen artisanal cheeses, house-pickled vegetables, and cured meats that the server recites from memory like poetry. Reserve a table on the terrace for golden-hour dining.

Rest your head at the GunRunner Boutique Hotel, a gloriously quirky retreat carved from a former car showroom where an original Harley guards the stairway. Each of the ten suites pays tribute to local legends, from the Sam Phillips room honoring the Sun Records founder to spaces celebrating Muscle Shoals musicians and Billy Reid fashion. Guitars wait to be strummed, the rooftop terrace beckons for nightcaps, and the central bar feels like a rockstar's private living room.

days_plan.itin_title: Alabama Deep South Discovery - Civil Rights, Music Heritage & Gulf Coast Paradise

visits.text: Embrace the relaxed, bohemian atmosphere of Folly Beach, where wide sandy shores, gentle waves, and colorful surf shops create an irresistible coastal vibe. The fishing pier provides perfect sunrise viewing as the sky transforms into a pastel masterpiece reflected on the water. This barrier island maintains an authentic beach town character distinct from more developed coastal destinations.

Explore the Lighthouse Inlet Heritage Preserve at the island's northern tip for striking views of the historic Morris Island Lighthouse standing sentinel offshore. Quieter beaches stretch along this protected area, perfect for long contemplative walks. The preserve's maritime forest and salt marsh ecosystems showcase the natural beauty that once defined the entire Carolina coast.

activities.text: Kayak or paddleboard through the salt marshes surrounding Folly Beach, gliding past egrets, dolphins, and hidden waterways that reveal the Lowcountry's ecological richness. The island's surf breaks attract wave riders, while the funky downtown area invites evening exploration. Folly's laid-back energy blends natural beauty with creative spirit in equal measure.

visits.text: Fort Lauderdale - The Venice of America: Over 300 miles of navigable waterways have earned Fort Lauderdale its nickname, with yacht-lined canals and waterfront mansions creating a unique urban landscape.
Las Olas Boulevard - Fort Lauderdale's Downtown Heartbeat: This tree-lined thoroughfare extends from downtown to the beach, lined with boutiques, galleries, restaurants, and sidewalk cafes.

Fort Lauderdale Beach - Where Families Replaced Spring Breakers: The wide, clean beach along A1A has evolved from its wild spring break reputation into a family-friendly destination with excellent hotels and restaurants.

Biscayne National Park - 95% Water, 100% Wonder: Florida's second-largest national park protects pristine coral reefs, mangrove shorelines, and Elliott Key, the largest island in the park's 173,000 acres.

activities.text: Water Taxi - Cruise the Canals: Hop aboard water taxis that navigate Fort Lauderdale's intricate canal system, connecting waterfront restaurants, shops, and attractions throughout the city.
Biscayne Snorkeling and Diving Tours - Explore Underwater Paradise: Boat tours depart daily from the Biscayne Institute for snorkeling adventures over coral reefs and dives to underwater wrecks.

days_plan.itin_title: Florida Unveiled: From Pristine Barrier Islands to Tropical Keys - The Ultimate Sunshine State Adventure
Florida Unveiled: From Pristine Barrier Islands to Tropical Keys - The Ultimate Sunshine State Adventure

visits.text: Fort Myers and Sanibel Island - Gateway to Island Paradise: This Southwest Florida region combines historic Edison and Ford estates with some of the most beautiful barrier island beaches in the state.

Edison and Ford Winter Estates - Where Genius Took Vacations: Thomas Edison and Henry Ford were neighbors in Fort Myers, and their adjacent estates now form a 20-acre museum showcasing inventions, gardens, and the friendship between two of history's greatest innovators.

Sanibel Island - World-Famous Shelling Destination: The island's unique east-west orientation acts as a net for Gulf shells, creating what collectors call the 'Sanibel Stoop' as visitors bend to gather treasures along the shore.

J.N. 'Ding' Darling National Wildlife Refuge - 6,400 Acres of Protected Paradise: This wildlife sanctuary covers nearly half of Sanibel Island, protecting crucial habitat for roseate spoonbills, alligators, and hundreds of other species.

activities.text: Fort Myers Beach - Tiki Bars and Gulf Sunsets: This laid-back beach town offers classic Florida experiences with seafood shacks, tourist shops, and miles of sandy shoreline.

days_plan.itin_title: Florida Unveiled: From Pristine Barrier Islands to Tropical Keys - The Ultimate Sunshine State Adventure

visits.text: Fort Smith National Historic Site - Where the Wild West Met Justice: Walk the grounds where 'Hanging Judge' Isaac Parker presided over the lawless frontier, sentencing 160 outlaws to the gallows including notorious figures like Cherokee Bill. The reconstructed courtroom, jail cells, and gallows bring the brutal justice of the 1870s-1890s to vivid life.

Trail of Tears Overlook at Belle Point - Sacred Ground of Sorrow: Stand at the confluence of the Arkansas and Poteau Rivers where thousands of Cherokee, Choctaw, Creek, Chickasaw, and Seminole people passed during their forced removal from ancestral homelands. Interpretive exhibits honor this dark chapter with dignity and remembrance.

Historic Garrison Avenue - The Longest Main Street in America: Stroll this 5-mile boulevard where Victorian-era architecture houses independent boutiques, galleries, and eateries in buildings that once served soldiers, settlers, and frontier justice.

activities.text: U.S. Marshals Museum - Legends of Law Enforcement: This striking museum overlooking the Arkansas River chronicles 225 years of the nation's oldest federal law enforcement agency through interactive exhibits and artifacts from famous cases.

days_plan.itin_title: Arkansas Unveiled: Mountains, Diamonds & Healing Waters of the Natural State
