days_plan.itin_title: MINNESOTA -THE BEST PLACES !

visits.text: Step back in time to experience America's oldest and largest Amish settlement in Lancaster County, where horse-drawn buggies clip-clop along country lanes and windmills spin above quilted farmland stretching to the horizon. Witness a way of life unchanged for centuries as Plain families tend their fields without electricity, raise magnificent barns through community effort, and preserve traditions that honor simplicity and faith.

Explore authentic Amish Country through guided tours that offer respectful glimpses into this closed community, from one-room schoolhouses where children learn in German to roadside stands selling quilts, furniture, and preserves crafted by skilled hands. Sample hearty Pennsylvania Dutch cooking-shoofly pie, chicken potpie, and whoopie pies-recipes passed down through generations of devoted cooks.

activities.text: Experience the gentle rhythm of Amish life aboard a traditional buggy ride through the pastoral countryside, where rolling farmland, covered bridges, and centuries-old stone farmhouses create scenes seemingly lifted from another era. Listen as your Plain driver shares stories of community, faith, and the rewards of living close to the land.

days_plan.itin_title: Pennsylvania Heritage Trail - Where American History Meets Natural Splendor

visits.text: Stand at the Caesars Head overlook for endless views of Blue Ridge Mountain ridgelines and valleys stretching to the horizon. This dramatic granite outcrop provides some of the most spectacular mountain scenery in the entire state. The crisp mountain air and panoramic vistas make this a must-visit destination for nature lovers seeking awe-inspiring landscapes.

Hike to Raven Cliff Falls, the tallest waterfall in South Carolina, cascading dramatically over a 420-foot cliff. The approximately five-mile round-trip trail rewards hikers with one of the most impressive natural sights in the region. A suspension bridge on the Dismal Trail loop provides close-up views of the falls that few visitors forget.

activities.text: Squeeze through Devil's Kitchen, a quirky narrow rocky passageway leading toward the overlook that adds adventure to the mountain experience. The rugged trails, peaceful forests, and dramatic rock formations of Caesars Head State Park showcase the Blue Ridge at its finest. This mountain destination reminds visitors why escaping to the highlands feels so rejuvenating.

Explore Landrum's charming downtown, where rolling foothills, sweeping mountain views, and country roads lined with farms create an idyllic setting. Visit Pearson's Falls, a beautiful 90-foot waterfall tucked into a lush nature preserve, and hike the Blue Wall Preserve for stunning mountain panoramas. The area's equestrian culture adds distinctive character to this hidden gem.

days_plan.itin_title: South Carolina Grand Tour: Coastal Elegance to Mountain Serenity

visits.text: Las Vegas Strip — Read the Strip’s layered urban design from neon marquees to mirrored towers; an engineered theater of light and spectacle.
Hoover Dam — Consider Art Deco motifs and interwar megaproject engineering at the Colorado River’s Black Canyon.
Las Vegas Springs Preserve — Desert ecology galleries and trails on the city’s historic water source; ideal orientation to Mojave flora and heat safety.
Return to Las Vegas via Cima Dome Joshua tree woodland; observe recovery areas from recent wildfires and avoid off‑road travel.

Las Vegas Strip — Walk the 6.8-kilometer boulevard lined with mega-resorts recreating world landmarks from the Eiffel Tower to Venetian canals. This entertainment capital features 30 casinos including Bellagio's fountains choreographed to music and the Luxor's 42.3-billion-candlepower sky beam.

Bellagio Conservatory and Botanical Gardens — Marvel at elaborate seasonal displays featuring thousands of flowers, trees, and sculptures. The 13,000-square-foot space transforms five times annually with themes created by 120 horticulturists.

Fremont Street Experience — Discover old Las Vegas under the Viva Vision canopy featuring 12.5 million LED lights creating 360-degree shows. The pedestrian mall in downtown's historic casino district offers vintage neon, street performers, and zip-lining.

Mob Museum — Explore organized crime and law enforcement history in the former 1933 federal courthouse. Interactive exhibits chronicle Las Vegas's mob connections, Prohibition, and the FBI's fight against organized crime.

Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area — Drive the 21-kilometer scenic loop through Mojave Desert landscapes featuring 900-meter red and tan Aztec sandstone cliffs. The 78,000-hectare area protects Joshua trees, desert tortoises, and rock climbing routes.

Calico Hills — Hike among swirling patterns in petrified sand dunes deposited 180 million years ago. The multicolored sandstone creates photographers' paradise with formations glowing brilliant orange and red.

Valley of Fire State Park — Explore Nevada's oldest and largest state park featuring 16,000 hectares of Aztec sandstone transformed red by iron oxide. The formations date to 150 million years ago when dinosaurs roamed shifting sand dunes.

Atlatl Rock — View prehistoric petroglyphs carved by Ancestral Puebloans and Paiute peoples on this sandstone outcrop. The rock art depicts atlatls—spear-throwing devices—along with bighorn sheep and geometric designs.

Great Basin National Park — Explore Nevada's only national park protecting 31,000 hectares from desert to 3,982-meter Wheeler Peak. The park encompasses bristlecone pine groves, Lehman Caves, and dark skies perfect for stargazing.
Lehman Caves — Tour marble caverns decorated with rare shield formations, stalactites, and helictites. The 90-minute guided walk reveals underground chambers carved by water over millions of years.
Bristlecone Pine Grove — Hike among Earth's oldest living organisms, some bristlecone pines exceeding 4,000 years. The gnarled trees survive harsh conditions at high elevation in the Snake Range.
Las Vegas Strip — Lisez le design urbain stratifié du Strip depuis les marquises néon jusqu'aux tours miroitantes ; un théâtre artificiel de lumière et de spectacle.
Hoover Dam — Considérez les motifs Art Déco et l'ingénierie de mégaprojet de l'entre-deux-guerres au Black Canyon de la Colorado River.
Las Vegas Springs Preserve — Galeries d'écologie désertique et sentiers sur la source d'eau historique de la ville ; orientation idéale pour la flore Mojave et la sécurité contre la chaleur.
Retour à Las Vegas via la forêt de Joshua trees de Cima Dome ; observez les zones de récupération après les récents incendies de forêt et évitez les voyages hors route.

activities.text: Night photography walk — Use railings and bridges as leading lines; carry water and avoid peak traffic.
Evening supply run and early lights‑out for pre‑dawn desert starts.
Departure buffer; optional Neon Museum or Downtown Arts District.

Cirque du Soleil show — Witness acrobatic artistry in one of seven permanent Cirque productions performing on the Strip. The Canadian entertainment company revolutionized Las Vegas shows with theatrical circus performances.
Casino buffet experience — Feast at legendary all-you-can-eat buffets offering cuisines from around the world. Las Vegas pioneered the buffet concept in 1946 to keep gamblers on property.

Fountains of Bellagio show — Watch choreographed water jets dance to classical music and contemporary hits. The 8-acre lake features over 1,200 nozzles shooting water up to 140 meters high in performances every 15-30 minutes.

Fire Wave hike — Trek 2.4 kilometers to this swirling sandstone formation resembling frozen waves of red and white rock. The moderate trail reveals one of Valley of Fire's most photographed geological wonders.
Desert wildlife watching — Spot desert bighorn sheep, chuckwallas, and desert tortoises adapted to extreme Mojave conditions. Early morning and late afternoon offer best viewing opportunities.
Loneliest Road drive — Navigate US Route 50 across Nevada's vast emptiness dubbed America's Loneliest Road. The 640-kilometer journey reveals basin and range geography under big skies.
Return to Las Vegas — Complete the Nevada loop returning to the neon oasis. The contrast between wilderness and civilization epitomizes Nevada's diverse character.
Promenade de photographie nocturne — Utilisez les rambardes et ponts comme lignes directrices ; portez de l'eau et évitez les heures de pointe.
Course d'approvisionnement du soir et extinction précoce des lumières pour les départs au désert avant l'aube.

visits.text: Lassen Volcanic National Park - The Only Place on Earth with All Four Volcano Types: Walk through a geothermal wonderland where the earth bubbles, hisses, and steams beneath your feet. This living laboratory showcases plug dome, shield, cinder cone, and composite volcanoes all within park boundaries.

Bumpass Hell - Three Miles into the Largest Hydrothermal Area in the Cascades: Follow the boardwalk trail past roaring fumaroles, bubbling mudpots, and scalding pools painted in otherworldly hues of orange, yellow, and turquoise. The trail honors Kendall Bumpass, who lost a leg when he broke through thin crust into boiling water.

Sulphur Works - Drive-Up Geothermal Theater: Steam vents and bubbling mud pools mere feet from the road offer the easiest access to the park's volcanic activity. The sulfurous smell announces your arrival before you see the first wisp of steam.

activities.text: Lassen Peak Summit Trail - Climb an Active Volcano: This 5-mile round-trip hike ascends 2,000 feet to the 10,457-foot summit, offering 360-degree views of the volcanic landscape. Lassen Peak last erupted in 1915, creating the devastated area still visible today.

days_plan.itin_title: California Unveiled: From Ancient Redwoods to Desert Wonders - The Ultimate Golden State Odyssey
California Unveiled: From Ancient Redwoods to Desert Wonders - The Ultimate Golden State Odyssey

visits.text: Lawrence - The City of Jayhawks: This energetic university town hums with youthful vitality both on and off the University of Kansas campus, blending world-class museums with a walkable downtown district.

KU Natural History Museum - Nationally Recognized Collections: Exhibits spanning dinosaurs, bugs, and mammals have earned this institution acclaim as one of the finest natural history museums in the Midwest.

Robert J. Dole Institute of Politics - Home of the World's Largest Stained-Glass American Flag: This museum gallery honors the Kansas senator's legacy through compelling exhibits on American political history.

Spencer Museum of Art - 45,000 Works Spanning Continents and Eras: One of the region's most comprehensive university art collections showcases pieces from ancient civilizations to contemporary masters.
Massachusetts Street - The Heart of Lawrence: This pedestrian-friendly boulevard buzzes with independent shops, galleries, and entertainment venues in beautifully preserved historic buildings.

Grinter's Sunflower Farm - 40 Acres of Golden Blooms: For over 50 years, this family farm near Lawrence has welcomed visitors to wander through fields of sunflowers during their late August peak, the quintessential Sunflower State experience.

activities.text: Clinton Lake - Clear Waters and Excellent Fishing: This 7,000-acre reservoir offers prime fishing for channel catfish and walleye, with a full-service marina providing 590 boat slips and rentals.

days_plan.itin_title: Kansas Unveiled: From Tallgrass Prairies to Space Exploration - Discovering America's Heartland

visits.text: Deception Pass Bridge — Cross this dramatic 555-meter steel cantilever bridge connecting Whidbey Island to Fidalgo Island 55 meters above churning tidal waters. The 1935 structure frames views of rocky islands and forest-clad cliffs plunging to the sea.

Leavenworth Bavarian Village — Stroll this Alpine-themed town transformed in the 1960s with Bavarian architecture, beer gardens, and German restaurants. The former logging town reinvented itself as a tourist destination in the Cascade Mountains.

Waterfront Park — Walk along the Wenatchee River through this landscaped park featuring traditional German gazebos and gardens. The park hosts festivals year-round from Oktoberfest to Christmas lighting ceremonies.

Nutcracker Museum — View over 7,000 nutcrackers from around the world in this unique collection spanning six rooms. Examples range from medieval functional tools to ornate Bavarian figures and modern artistic interpretations.
Fremont Lookout sunrise hike
Drive to Leavenworth
Wine tasting at WineGirl Wines
Walk at Lake Wenatchee
Hike to Colchuck Lake

Pont de Deception Pass — Traversez ce pont cantilever en acier spectaculaire de 555 mètres reliant Whidbey Island à Fidalgo Island à 55 mètres au-dessus des eaux de marée tumultueuses. La structure de 1935 encadre les vues sur les îles rocheuses et les falaises boisées plongeant vers la mer.

Village bavarois de Leavenworth — Promenez-vous dans cette ville à thème alpin transformée dans les années 1960 avec une architecture bavaroise, des jardins à bière et des restaurants allemands. L'ancienne ville forestière s'est réinventée comme destination touristique dans les montagnes Cascade.

Waterfront Park — Marchez le long de la rivière Wenatchee à travers ce parc paysager avec des kiosques et jardins allemands traditionnels. Le parc accueille des festivals toute l'année, de l'Oktoberfest aux cérémonies d'illumination de Noël.

Musée du Casse-noix — Admirez plus de 7 000 casse-noix du monde entier dans cette collection unique répartie sur six salles. Les exemples vont des outils fonctionnels médiévaux aux figures bavaroises ornées et aux interprétations artistiques modernes.

activities.text: German cuisine sampling — Feast on schnitzel, bratwurst, spätzle, and apple strudel at authentic Bavarian restaurants complete with lederhosen-clad servers. Beer gardens serve German imports and local craft brews in festive atmosphere.

Icicle Gorge Trail hiking — Trek along the cascading Icicle Creek through old-growth forest and granite canyons. The relatively easy 4-mile trail offers swimming holes and dramatic mountain scenery in the Alpine Lakes Wilderness.

Wine tasting at local wineries — Sample Riesling, Chardonnay, and Pinot Noir at tasting rooms surrounding Leavenworth. The Cascade foothills' elevation and temperature variations create favorable growing conditions.

Dégustation de cuisine allemande — Régalez-vous de schnitzel, bratwurst, spätzle et strudel aux pommes dans des restaurants bavarois authentiques avec des serveurs en lederhosen. Les jardins à bière servent des importations allemandes et des bières artisanales locales dans une atmosphère festive.

Randonnée sur le sentier Icicle Gorge — Parcourez le long du creek Icicle en cascade à travers une forêt ancienne et des canyons de granit. Le sentier relativement facile de 4 miles offre des trous de baignade et des paysages montagneux spectaculaires dans le Alpine Lakes Wilderness.

Dégustation de vins dans les vignobles locaux — Dégustez du Riesling, Chardonnay et Pinot Noir dans les salles de dégustation autour de Leavenworth. L'altitude et les variations de température des contreforts des Cascade créent des conditions de croissance favorables.

visits.text: Discover the Davidson County Historical Museum, housed in an elegant 19th-century Greek Revival building that provides an excellent opportunity to learn about Lexington's rich history and culture. The museum's fascinating exhibits chronicle the development of this charming Piedmont community through artifacts and historical displays.

Admire the stunning collection of works at the Bob Timberlake Gallery, celebrating one of North Carolina's most beloved artists. The gallery showcases Timberlake's masterful paintings capturing the essence of Southern rural life and the natural beauty of the Carolina landscape.

activities.text: Experience Lexington's lively winery scene, which offers plenty of opportunities to sample excellent local wines. The serene atmosphere at Childress Vineyards provides the perfect setting for tasting award-winning dry white wines while enjoying the beautiful rolling Piedmont countryside that surrounds this celebrated vineyard.

visits.text: Liberal - Dorothy's Other Kansas Home: This southwestern Kansas town offers another immersive Wizard of Oz experience, competing with Wamego for fans of the beloved story.

Dorothy's House and the Land of Oz - Follow the Yellow Brick Road: Dorothy herself leads your whirlwind tour through this attraction, meeting the Scarecrow, Tin Man, and Cowardly Lion on the magical path to the Wizard.
Dorothy's Farmhouse - Where the Tornado Touched Down: Tour the recreated Kansas farmhouse, imagining the moment young Dorothy was swept away to the magical Land of Oz.
Oz Memorabilia Museum - Decades of Oz Collectibles: Browse extensive displays of Wizard of Oz merchandise, props, and artifacts spanning the beloved story's long history.

activities.text: Pancake Race - Liberal's Quirky Tradition: Each Shrove Tuesday, Liberal hosts an international pancake race, competing against Olney, England, in a tradition dating to 1950.

visits.text: Lindsborg - More Swedish Than Sweden: Visitors from Scandinavia themselves say this Kansas town feels more authentically Swedish than modern Sweden, thanks to its traditional festivities and architecture.

Coronado Heights - A Castle Overlooking the Prairie: Climb this 300-foot-tall bluff crowned with a castle-like stone shelter for panoramic views across the Kansas landscape that Spanish conquistadors once traversed.

Wild Dala Horses - A Herd of Painted Wooden Creatures: The Swedish Dala horse tradition inspired these colorful sculptures scattered throughout Lindsborg, each painted with unique designs waiting to be discovered.
Hemslöjd Swedish Gift Shop - Take Home a Piece of Sweden: Browse traditional Swedish crafts, including personalized Dala-shaped house signs, at this authentic Scandinavian emporium.

activities.text: Swedish Heritage Walking Tour - Discover Little Sweden: Explore the architecture, shops, and traditions that have made this Kansas town a living tribute to Scandinavian culture.

days_plan.itin_title: Kansas Unveiled: From Tallgrass Prairies to Space Exploration - Discovering America's Heartland

visits.text: Litchfield Hills - Connecticut's Most Pristine Countryside: Quiet country roads wind through this rural region where small towns seem lifted straight from a painting. The famous Litchfield town green exemplifies New England charm, surrounded by 18th-century homes and historic churches.

Lake Waramaug - A Glacial Jewel Shared by Three Towns: This idyllic lake stretches across Kent, Warren, and New Preston, its shores lined with forests, farms, and a state park offering swimming, hiking, and spectacular fall foliage viewing.

West Cornwall Covered Bridge - The Most Photographed Span in Connecticut: This beloved 1864 covered bridge carries traffic across the Housatonic River in a scene that defines New England's romantic appeal, especially when autumn colors reflect in the waters below.

activities.text: Housatonic River Paddling - Whitewater to Flatwater Adventures: The Housatonic offers paddling for all skill levels, from challenging rapids at Rattlesnake in Falls Village and Bull's Bridge in Kent to gentle flows through Cornwall's meadows and farms.

Eagle Landing State Park - Winter Wildlife Spectacle: Visit Haddam's riverside park where bald eagles congregate from December through March to nest and fish along the riverbank, one of New England's premier eagle-watching destinations.

Connecticut Wine Trail Northwest - Vineyard Hopping in the Hills: Several wineries dot the Litchfield Hills region, including Connecticut Valley Winery with award-winning varietals and Sharpe Hill Vineyard featuring a Zagat-rated restaurant amid rolling countryside.

days_plan.itin_title: Connecticut Unveiled: Maritime Heritage, Ivy League Culture & New England's Hidden Gem
Connecticut Unveiled: Maritime Heritage, Ivy League Culture & New England's Hidden Gem

visits.text: Little Rock — River Market District and Clinton Library.
Return south via scenic AR‑7; stop at Cliff House Inn overlook.
Departure day buffer.

Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site - Where Nine Teenagers Changed America Forever: Stand before the very doors where, in 1957, nine brave African-American students challenged segregation and altered the course of American history. Federal troops lined these steps as the world watched democracy tested. The preserved halls and powerful visitor center exhibits tell one of the Civil Rights Movement's most pivotal stories.

Clinton Presidential Library & Museum - Inside the Glass Bridge of American Politics: This striking cantilevered structure jutting over the Arkansas River houses a full-scale Oval Office replica and the largest archival collection of any U.S. presidency. Explore the defining moments of the 1990s through immersive exhibits spanning two terms that shaped modern America.

The Old Mill at T.R. Pugh Memorial Park - Hollywood's Secret Arkansas Star: This enchanting 1933 watermill gained immortality in the opening scene of 'Gone with the Wind.' Hidden among its rustic stones and cascading waters, observe the wildlife and fairy-tale landscapes that continue to draw photographers and filmmakers to this magical corner of Little Rock.
Little Rock: Thelma, a suffocated housewife, and Louise, a tired waitress, prepare a simple weekend car trip to escape their burdensome daily routine.
Roadside bar near Little Rock: Thelma is assaulted in the parking lot, Louise defends her and kills her attacker, turning their getaway into a flight from the law.
Little Rock — Quartier River Market et Bibliothèque Clinton.

Walk or cycle as the river flows beneath your feet.

BETWEEN SAN FRANCISCO, YOSEMITE, DEATH VALLEY, JOSHUA TREE, LOS ANGELES

visits.text: Stand atop Lookout Mountain at Rock City Gardens, a remarkable natural park where ancient rock formations, lush gardens, and whimsical stone pathways lead to Lover's Leap overlook with views extending across seven states. The 180-foot suspension bridge provides exhilarating passage above forested ravines while cave grottos reveal fairytale scenes tucked into the mountain's mysterious recesses. Towering sandstone cliffs and carefully cultivated gardens create unforgettable vistas.

Descend into the mountain at Ruby Falls, where an underground pathway leads to a spectacular 145-foot waterfall cascading within an ancient limestone cavern. The illuminated cave formations and thundering waters create a subterranean spectacle unlike anything above ground. Guided tours reveal the geological history of this remarkable natural wonder.

activities.text: Visit the dramatically positioned Covenant College, whose Gothic Revival stone buildings rise castle-like from the clifftops with commanding views across Georgia, Tennessee, and Alabama. Sunset Rock offers photographers ideal conditions for capturing the Blue Ridge Mountains bathed in golden evening light.

days_plan.itin_title: Georgia Grand Circle: Mountains, Historic Cities and Golden Isles

visits.text: Bandelier National Monument — Ancestral Pueblo cliff dwellings, Frijoles Canyon, and petroglyph walks.
Bandelier National Monument — habitations troglodytiques des Pueblos ancestraux, Frijoles Canyon et promenades pétroglyphes.

Visit the Los Alamos History Museum, which chronicles the town's remarkable transformation from a remote homesteading outpost to the epicenter of scientific research during World War II and the Cold War. The exhibits document how this isolated mesa became home to the Manhattan Project and changed the course of world history. Personal stories and artifacts illuminate the human dimension of this extraordinary chapter.

Explore the Bradbury Science Museum at Los Alamos National Laboratory, offering deeper insights into the development of atomic science and the Laboratory's ongoing research programs. Interactive exhibits explain complex scientific concepts while presenting the historical context of nuclear research. The museum provides a thoughtful examination of both the achievements and ethical considerations surrounding atomic energy.

days_plan.itin_title: NEW MEXICO HIGH DESERT LOOP — SANTA FE, BANDELIER, VALLES CALDERA & TAOS
New Mexico Complete: From Mountain Villages to Desert Wonders

activities.text: Discover Bandelier National Monument, protecting over 33,000 acres of ancestral Puebloan cliff dwellings, petroglyphs, and pristine mountain wilderness where the Rio Grande flows through dramatic canyons. The archaeological sites date back nearly 11,000 years, revealing how ancient peoples adapted to this challenging environment. Hiking trails lead to remarkable cave dwellings that visitors can climb into and explore.

Experience Valles Caldera National Preserve, an 89,000-acre protected area centered on a massive volcanic caldera formed approximately 1.25 million years ago. The vast grassland valley surrounded by forested mountain slopes creates landscapes of extraordinary beauty. Elk herds graze across the caldera floor, visible from scenic overlooks along the preserve's rim.

visits.text: Los Angeles - The Entertainment Capital of the World: This sprawling metropolis of 4 million (13 million in the metro area) has shaped global culture through film, television, music, and art. From celebrity-studded Beverly Hills to artsy Silver Lake, each neighborhood has its own distinct identity.

Hollywood Walk of Fame - 2,700 Stars and Counting: This sidewalk tribute stretching 1.3 miles along Hollywood Boulevard has honored entertainment icons since 1960. The handprints and footprints at the TCL Chinese Theatre add another layer of celebrity worship.

Griffith Observatory - Where LA Meets the Cosmos: This Art Deco landmark on the slopes of Mount Hollywood offers free admission, planetarium shows, and the most iconic view of the Hollywood Sign. The observatory has appeared in countless films from Rebel Without a Cause to La La Land.

The Getty Center - A Hilltop Temple to Art: This billion-dollar campus designed by Richard Meier houses masterpieces spanning antiquity to the present, all with sweeping views from the Santa Monica Mountains to downtown. Admission is free; only parking costs.

Venice Beach Boardwalk - California's Counterculture Catwalk: Street performers, bodybuilders at Muscle Beach, muralists, fortune tellers, and every variety of California eccentric parade along this two-mile ocean-front circus.

Venice Beach Boardwalk — Immerse yourself in the electric atmosphere of this iconic promenade where Muscle Beach bodybuilders, eccentric street artists and tie-dye vendors create a permanent spectacle. Skaters defy gravity in the historic skate park.

Getty Center — Explore this museum complex perched on a Brentwood hill designed by Richard Meier and opened in 1997. The European paintings collection rivals Robert Irwin's gardens and panoramic views of glittering Los Angeles.

Hollywood Walk of Fame — Walk Hollywood Boulevard searching for the 2,700 terrazzo and brass stars honoring entertainment icons since 1960. The neighboring Chinese Theatre displays handprints and footprints of Hollywood legends.

Griffith Observatory — Admire the spectacular panorama of Los Angeles from this 1935 Art Deco building overlooking Hollywood. Free public telescopes allow observation of planets and stars while the planetarium projects immersive cosmic shows.
Journey to Los Angeles and discovery of Santa Monica Pier
Los Angeles: return to Charlie's life, meeting with Dr. Bruner and realization that money matters less than the rediscovered relationship with Raymond.
Los Angeles / Santa Ana station: Raymond returns to the institution, while Charlie promises to come see him again, finally accepting his brother as he is.
In Los Angeles, Chris tries to resume a more normal life with work and housing, but quickly feels trapped and hits the road again.

activities.text: Santa Monica Pier - Where Route 66 Meets the Pacific: This iconic pier marks the official end of the Mother Road, featuring a solar-powered Ferris wheel, historic carousel, and views stretching to Malibu.

The Last Bookstore - A Cathedral of Literature: This downtown maze of tunnels, archways, and flying books occupies a former bank building, creating one of the world's most photographed independent bookstores.

The Broad - Contemporary Art for Everyone: This striking honeycomb-clad museum houses over 2,000 works of postwar and contemporary art, including Yayoi Kusama's famous Infinity Mirrored Room. Free tickets.

Brunch at Grand Central Market — Taste authentic tacos, steaming ramen and artisanal coffee in this historic 1917 food market in the heart of Downtown. The multicultural stalls reflect Los Angeles' culinary diversity in a preserved architectural setting.

Shopping on Rodeo Drive — Window shop along this luxurious Beverly Hills artery concentrating Chanel, Gucci and Prada in architectural statement boutiques. The glamorous atmosphere and majestic palm trees embody the Hollywood California dream.

Sunset at Santa Monica Pier — End your road trip on this century-old pier opened in 1909 with its solar Ferris wheel and 1922 carousel. The sun blazing over the Pacific while neon lights illuminate perfectly concludes the coastal adventure.

visits.text: Explore Ocmulgee Mounds National Historical Park, where massive earthen ceremonial mounds constructed over 1,000 years ago preserve evidence of sophisticated Native American civilization in the American Southeast. The reconstructed earth lodge contains an original clay floor where ancient councils gathered around a central fire pit. Museum exhibits display artifacts spanning 17,000 years of human habitation along the Ocmulgee River.

Discover Macon's rich musical heritage at the Tubman Museum, one of the largest museums in America dedicated to African American art, history, and culture. The city served as birthplace to music legends Little Richard and Otis Redding, whose influences still resonate through local venues and festivals. The Allman Brothers Band Museum preserves memorabilia from Southern rock's most influential group.

activities.text: Tour the opulent Hay House, a stunning Italian Renaissance Revival mansion featuring original 19th-century furnishings and technological innovations ahead of their time. The Grand Opera House, with its plush red velvet interior, hosts performances in a magnificently restored 1884 theater. Window-shop along Cherry Street's indie boutiques in the revitalized downtown district.

visits.text: Madeline Island - Largest of the Apostle Islands, accessible by ferry from Bayfield. Rich Ojibwe heritage and peaceful island atmosphere.
Big Bay State Park - Raw, untamed 2,418-acre wilderness with 4 miles of Lake Superior shoreline, rugged sandstone cliffs, and empty beaches.
Bay View Trail - Accessible hiking path offering gorgeous Lake Superior vistas from atop the sandstone bluffs.
Big Bay Lagoon - Calm, protected waters perfect for kayaking beneath towering pines with views of distant sandstone cliffs.
Stockton Island - Remote island wilderness offering primitive camping, pristine beaches, and black bear viewing opportunities.

activities.text: Bluff-top picnic at Point Area under the pines, gazing at Lake Superior's sparkling waters and distant sandstone formations.

days_plan.itin_title: Wisconsin's Lakeland Wonders & Hidden Waterfalls - From Glacial Trails to Island Escapes

visits.text: Stroll through Madison's remarkably preserved antebellum district, where grand 19th-century mansions line oak-shaded streets virtually unchanged since the Civil War. Sherman's army famously spared this elegant town during the March to the Sea, preserving architectural treasures including Heritage Hall and the historic Rogers House. Manicured gardens, decorative fountains, and refined Southern storefronts create timeless elegance.

Visit Rose Cottage, built by Adeline Rose after she gained her freedom, offering moving insights into African American history in the antebellum South. The Steffen Thomas Museum showcases bold folk art in striking contrast to the town's refined classical architecture. Antique shops throughout the walkable historic district contain fascinating treasures from centuries past.

activities.text: Experience Madison's genteel Southern hospitality while exploring the town's carefully preserved heritage spanning two centuries of American history. The intimate scale and exceptional preservation make this one of Georgia's most photographically rewarding destinations for lovers of historic architecture.

visits.text: Hammonasset Beach State Park - Connecticut's Largest Shoreline Park: This pristine 2-mile stretch of protected coastline draws beachgoers to sunbathe on sandy shores, swim in Long Island Sound's gentle surf, and stroll the historic boardwalk. The park's network of walking paths, fishing piers, and wildlife viewing areas remain open year-round.

Meigs Point Nature Center - Where Land Meets Sea: Located on the park's southern end, this facility features a turtle habitat and ten themed gardens showcasing native plant species. The surrounding wetlands and tidal pools provide excellent birdwatching opportunities.

activities.text: Long Island Sound Sunset - Nature's Nightly Masterpiece: The park's western-facing shoreline offers spectacular sunset views across the sound, with colors reflecting off gentle waves as day turns to dusk.

visits.text: Drive the scenic Turquoise Trail, a 50-mile National Scenic Byway connecting Cedar Crest to Cerrillos through dramatic high desert landscapes dotted with old mining towns turned artist colonies. The route passes through terrain rich in turquoise deposits that have been mined for centuries by indigenous peoples and later settlers. Each small community along the highway offers unique galleries, studios, and roadside attractions.

Explore Madrid, a former coal mining town transformed into a vibrant art village where creative spirits have established galleries, studios, and unique shops in restored Victorian-era buildings. The town maintains a deliberately off-grid character with limited cell service, encouraging visitors to disconnect and appreciate the artistic atmosphere. Horseback riding excursions through the surrounding high desert landscape provide adventure beyond the galleries.

days_plan.itin_title: CHRIS'S JOURNEY - INTO THE WILD
CHRIS'S JOURNEY - INTO THE WILD

visits.text: Getty Villa — Explore this spectacular recreation of a 1st century Roman villa housing J. Paul Getty's collection of Greek and Roman antiquities. The 44,000 works displayed in the peristyle gardens and galleries evoke Herculaneum.

El Matador State Beach — Descend the steep stairs to this wild cove hidden between sculpted cliffs and rock arches. The geological formations create sea caves and natural pools at low tide, a photographer's paradise.

Malibu Pier — Stroll along this historic 230-meter pier built in 1905, anchor point of the Malibu surfer lifestyle. Malibu Farm restaurant serves farm-to-table cuisine while dolphins and sea lions patrol the crystal-clear waters.

Adamson House — Visit this 1929 Spanish-Moorish residence adorned with 3,000 colorful Malibu Potteries ceramic tiles. The artisanal azulejos decorate fountains, stairs and patios of this property listed as a historic monument overlooking Surfrider Beach.

activities.text: Hiking at Solstice Canyon — Explore the shaded trails of this coastal canyon leading to the romantic ruins of the Roberts Ranch House destroyed by fire in 1982. The Tropical Terrace Trail crosses an unexpected tropical oasis with waterfalls and ferns.

Seafood lunch at Nobu Malibu — Savor chef Nobuyuki Matsuhisa's Japanese-Peruvian fusion cuisine on the glass terrace directly overlooking the Pacific. The black cod miso is legendary and the people-watching opportunities unmatched.

Surf session at Surfrider Beach — Learn to surf at this legendary spot with long, regular waves, birthplace of modern California surfing in the 1960s. Local schools provide equipment and coach beginners on this beach classified as a World Surfing Reserve.

days_plan.itin_title: CALIFORNIA: PACIFIC COAST HIGHWAY FROM SAN FRANCISCO TO LOS ANGELES

visits.text: Mammoth Mountain - California's Legendary Ski Destination: This volcanic peak rises to 11,053 feet, receiving an average 400 inches of annual snowfall that fuels one of America's longest ski seasons, often extending into June or July.

Devils Postpile National Monument - Nature's Perfect Geometry: These 60-foot columns of basalt, formed by cooling lava 100,000 years ago, display hexagonal symmetry so precise it appears engineered. The nearby 101-foot Rainbow Falls completes the geological wonderland.

Mammoth Lakes Basin - Alpine Paradise at 9,000 Feet: Five crystal lakes fill glacier-carved bowls beneath towering Sierra peaks, offering swimming, fishing, and hiking amid some of California's most pristine mountain scenery.

activities.text: Mammoth Mountain Gondola - Rise Above the Sierra: Even in summer, the gondola whisks visitors to 11,053 feet for 360-degree views spanning from the White Mountains to Yosemite's high country.

Hot Creek Geological Site - Geothermal Springs Meet Trout Stream: Hot springs bubble up through a creek renowned for fly fishing, creating swirling patterns where cold and hot water mix against a backdrop of jagged peaks.

days_plan.itin_title: California Unveiled: From Ancient Redwoods to Desert Wonders - The Ultimate Golden State Odyssey
California Unveiled: From Ancient Redwoods to Desert Wonders - The Ultimate Golden State Odyssey

visits.text: Mammoth Spring State Park - Where 9 Million Gallons Surge Hourly from the Earth: One of America's largest springs creates an instant river from a 10-acre basin of impossibly blue water. The Mammoth Spring discharges enough crystal-clear flow every day to supply a city of 300,000 people, maintaining a constant 58°F year-round.

Historic Frisco Depot - Gateway to the Ozarks: This restored 1886 railway station recalls the era when Mammoth Spring served as a resort destination for Victorian travelers seeking the spring's legendary waters. The depot now houses exhibits on regional history and railroad heritage.

activities.text: Spring Lake Dam & Spillway - Watch a River Being Born: The spring's outflow creates Spring River, famous for trout fishing. Walk the dam and watch millions of gallons cascade over the spillway every hour, feeding one of the Ozarks' finest cold-water fisheries.

Spring River Water Trail - Float the Ozarks' Clearest Stream: Beginning at the spring's outlet, this designated water trail offers gentle paddling through pristine Ozark scenery, past towering bluffs and through swimming holes.

days_plan.itin_title: Arkansas Unveiled: Mountains, Diamonds & Healing Waters of the Natural State
Arkansas Unveiled: Mountains, Diamonds & Healing Waters of the Natural State

visits.text: Flint Hills Scenic Byway to Manhattan — Konza Prairie Nature Trail overlooks and Flint Hills Discovery Center exhibits.

Manhattan and the Flint Hills - Gateway to America's Last Tallgrass Prairie: This university town serves as the perfect launching point for exploring the vast grasslands that once covered 170 million acres of North America.

Flint Hills Discovery Center - Interactive Gateway to the Prairie: This state-of-the-art facility immerses visitors in the ecology, history, and culture of the Flint Hills through hands-on exhibits, films, and programming.

Konza Prairie Biological Station - Hike Through Living History: A network of nature trails crisscrosses this 8,600-acre research prairie, offering intimate encounters with the tallgrass ecosystem that once dominated the continent.

Tallgrass Prairie National Preserve - 11,000 Acres of Protected Prairie: Ranger-guided tours and the Southwind Nature Trail lead visitors through this remarkable preserve to bison pastures and scenic overlooks, one of the last places to experience what pioneers encountered crossing the Great Plains.

Flint Hills National Scenic Byway - 47 Miles of Prairie Splendor: This designated scenic route winds through pastoral landscapes where cattle and cowboys still roam, much as they have for over a century.
Route panoramique des Flint Hills vers Manhattan — points de vue du sentier nature de Konza Prairie et expositions du Centre de découverte des Flint Hills.

visits.text: Mashantucket Pequot Museum & Research Center - The Largest Native American Museum in the World: This tribally owned 308,000-square-foot complex brings the story of the Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation to life through immersive multisensory experiences. The incredibly realistic Pequot Village recreation transports visitors to pre-contact New England life.

185-Foot Glass and Stone Observation Tower - Views Across Southern New England: Rise above the surrounding landscape for panoramic views of the Connecticut wilderness, wetlands, and coastline stretching to Long Island Sound (reopening early spring 2025 after renovations).

Permanent Galleries and Dioramas - 10,000 Years of History: Two levels situated below ground house extensive exhibits on regional Native American history, from the Ice Age to the present, through films, interactive programs, archival materials, and meticulously crafted dioramas.

activities.text: Connecticut Wine Trail - Sample Award-Winning New England Wines: Thirty-three member wineries spread across the state offer tastings of varietals uniquely influenced by Connecticut's terroir. Saltwater Farm Vineyard near Stonington adds briny coastal notes to its wines, while farms like Bishop's Orchards combine vineyards with markets and bakeries.

days_plan.itin_title: Connecticut Unveiled: Maritime Heritage, Ivy League Culture & New England's Hidden Gem
Connecticut Unveiled: Maritime Heritage, Ivy League Culture & New England's Hidden Gem

visits.text: Jour 1: McCarthy Road - The 60-mile gravel route from Chitina to McCarthy follows the abandoned Copper River & Northwestern Railway bed, crossing the Kuskulana and Gilahina trestle bridges. This adventurous drive takes approximately 3.5 hours and requires vehicles permitted for unpaved roads, passing through pristine wilderness with views of surrounding glaciers and peaks.

Jour 1: McCarthy Historic District - This remote outpost at the end of the road was once a bustling supply town for the Kennicott copper mines. Today the small community maintains its frontier character, accessible only by footbridge across the Kennicott River, with no running water, limited electricity, and a population that swells slightly in summer.

Jour 2: Kennicott Mines National Historic Landmark - This remarkably preserved ghost town represents one of the most significant early 20th-century copper mining operations in North America. The fourteen-story concentration mill and surrounding structures cling to the mountainside above the Kennicott Glacier, abandoned in 1938 when ore deposits were exhausted. Ranger-led and private tours explore the industrial complex's haunting red buildings.

Jour 2: Root Glacier - A short hike from Kennicott leads to one of Alaska's most accessible glaciers, where visitors can walk onto the ice without technical equipment. The glacier's surface features crevasses, meltwater streams, and ice caves that shift and change throughout the summer season.

activities.text: Jour 1: Air Taxi from Chitina - Bush planes offer a scenic 30-minute alternative to the rough road, flying over glaciers, peaks, and abandoned railway infrastructure before landing on the gravel strip near McCarthy. This aerial approach provides stunning perspectives on Wrangell-St. Elias's vast wilderness.

Jour 2: Guided Glacier Hiking - Naturalist guides lead excursions onto Root Glacier, providing crampons and instruction for safe travel across the ice. Extended trips venture deeper into the glacier's blue ice formations and seracs.
Jour 2: Ice Climbing - The glacier's features provide natural climbing terrain, with professional guides offering instruction for beginners and challenging routes for experienced climbers.

Jour 2: Wrangell-St. Elias Flightseeing - Aerial tours reveal the park's staggering scale, with nine of North America's sixteen highest peaks, countless glaciers, and active volcanoes visible from above. Flights may include glacier landings for an immersive wilderness experience.
Jour 2: Nizina River Rafting - Whitewater and scenic float trips explore the wild rivers draining the Wrangell Mountains, passing through canyons and along glacial moraines rarely seen by visitors.

visits.text: Gypsum Hills Scenic Byway - Red Rock Country in Kansas: This 42-mile route reveals a landscape of flat mesas, deep canyons, and rusty buttes complementing green cedar trees and prairie grasses-scenery that defies Kansas stereotypes.

Carry Nation Home - The Hatchet-Wielding Temperance Leader's Story: In Medicine Lodge, learn about the remarkable woman who smashed law-breaking saloons across Kansas and beyond in her crusade against alcohol.
Lake Coldwater - Oasis in the Red Hills: Cool off with swimming, boating, and fishing at this scenic lake, keeping watch for wintering bald eagles, migrating white pelicans, and ospreys.
Gyp Hills Guest Ranch - Authentic Ranch Experience: Ride horses across hilly pastures, assist with livestock chores, catch fish, or simply absorb the dramatic Red Hills scenery.

activities.text: Red Hills Photography - Capture Kansas's Hidden Landscape: The rusty tones of the Gypsum Hills create stunning photographic opportunities, especially during golden hour when the rocks seem to glow.

days_plan.itin_title: Kansas Unveiled: From Tallgrass Prairies to Space Exploration - Discovering America's Heartland

visits.text: Jack Daniel's Distillery — Tour America's oldest registered distillery producing Tennessee whiskey since 1866 in Lynchburg. The process using charcoal mellowing distinguishes Tennessee whiskey from bourbon, with water from Cave Spring never varying in temperature.

Graceland — Explore Elvis Presley's 13.8-acre estate featuring the mansion, car museum, and two custom jets. The King's 1957 purchase became his permanent residence until his 1977 death, now welcoming 600,000 annual visitors.

Sun Studio — Stand where Elvis, Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis, and B.B. King recorded in this unassuming building. Sam Phillips launched rock and roll here in the 1950s with the Million Dollar Quartet session immortalized in photographs.

National Civil Rights Museum — Learn about the American civil rights movement in the Lorraine Motel where Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in 1968. The museum chronicles the struggle from slavery through modern times.

Jour 1: Step through the gates of Graceland, the legendary 13.8-acre estate where Elvis Presley lived, created, and ultimately found his final resting place. This magnificent mansion, added to the National Register of Historic Places, draws over 600,000 devoted pilgrims annually who come to walk the same halls where the King of Rock 'n' Roll entertained, recorded, and lived his extraordinary life. The Elvis Entourage VIP Tour reveals not just the opulent mansion but also his remarkable car collection, iconic jumpsuits, and private aircraft across the sprawling entertainment complex.

Jour 1: Enter the humble brick building where rock 'n' roll was born at Sun Studio, the most famous recording studio in the world. Within these acoustically perfect walls, Elvis cut his first record, Johnny Cash found his sound, and legends like Jerry Lee Lewis and Roy Orbison launched careers that would reshape American music forever. Even modern icons like U2 and Bob Dylan have made pilgrimages here to record where it all began.

Jour 1: Immerse yourself in the powerful story of America's civil rights struggle at the National Civil Rights Museum, located at the very Lorraine Motel where Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in 1968. This world-class museum walks visitors through the complete arc of the movement, from Rosa Parks' defiant bus ride to the tragedy of Dr. King's final moments, preserved in the exact room where he spent his last night.

Jour 2: Discover the musical diversity that emerged from Memphis at the Rock 'n' Soul Museum, a Smithsonian Institution affiliate that celebrates the musicians who overcame racial barriers and socioeconomic challenges to create the sounds that united America. Through rare recordings, vintage instruments, and compelling exhibits, witness how Black and white artists together forged the Memphis sound that would conquer the world.

Jour 2: Ascend the world's tallest freestanding elevator 28 stories to the apex of the Memphis Pyramid, now transformed into the extraordinary Bass Pro Shop at the Pyramid. This 32-story glass structure houses not just a retail experience but an aquarium, bowling alley, and the award-winning Big Cypress Lodge, with an observation deck offering 300-foot-high panoramic views across Memphis and the mighty Mississippi River.

Jour 2: Witness one of Memphis's most beloved traditions at the grand Peabody Hotel, where every day at 11 AM and 5 PM, a family of mallard ducks makes their ceremonial march from the rooftop palace to the lobby fountain. This charming ritual, begun in the 1930s, has become one of the South's most endearing spectacles as the well-trained fowl waddle down the red carpet to the delight of gathered crowds.
Beale Street (musical heritage, daytime scouting)
Stax Museum of American Soul Music

National Civil Rights Museum — Apprenez sur le mouvement des droits civiques américain dans le Lorraine Motel où Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. fut assassiné en 1968. Le musée retrace la lutte de l'esclavage aux temps modernes.

Distillerie Jack Daniel's — Visitez la plus ancienne distillerie enregistrée d'Amérique produisant du whiskey du Tennessee depuis 1866 à Lynchburg. Le processus utilisant l'adoucissement au charbon de bois distingue le whiskey du Tennessee du bourbon, avec l'eau de Cave Spring dont la température ne varie jamais.

Graceland — Explorez le domaine de 13,8 acres d'Elvis Presley comprenant le manoir, le musée automobile et deux jets personnalisés. L'achat de 1957 du King devint sa résidence permanente jusqu'à sa mort en 1977, accueillant maintenant 600 000 visiteurs annuels.

Sun Studio — Tenez-vous là où Elvis, Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis et B.B. King ont enregistré dans ce bâtiment sans prétention. Sam Phillips a lancé le rock and roll ici dans les années 1950 avec la session du Million Dollar Quartet immortalisée en photographies.

activities.text: Beale Street blues — Experience live music on this historic street where W.C. Handy pioneered blues music. Neon signs illuminate clubs offering authentic Memphis blues and rock.
Memphis BBQ — Savor dry-rubbed ribs at legendary joints like Central BBQ or Rendezvous. Memphis style emphasizes slow-smoked pork with tangy tomato-based sauce served on the side.

Jour 1: Stroll the neon-lit blocks of Beale Street as the sun sets and the blues begin to wail from every doorway of this legendary entertainment district. This three-block stretch pulses with the sounds that shaped American music-delta blues, jazz, rock 'n' roll, and R&B pouring from historic clubs where legends once played and new talents still emerge nightly.

Jour 2: Experience an authentic Memphis blues night at the original BB King's Blues Club on Beale Street, where the spirit of the legendary bluesman lives on through nightly performances by world-class musicians carrying the torch of the genre he helped define.

days_plan.itin_title: MINNESOTA -THE BEST PLACES !

visits.text: Art Deco Historic District — Stroll Ocean Drive admiring 800+ pastel-hued buildings from the 1920s-1940s representing the world's largest concentration of Art Deco architecture. Streamline Moderne hotels feature terrazzo floors, porthole windows, and geometric facades in pink, turquoise, and yellow.

Vizcaya Museum and Gardens — Explore this Italian Renaissance-style villa built 1914-1922 for industrialist James Deering. The 34-room mansion overlooks Biscayne Bay surrounded by 10 acres of formal European gardens featuring fountains, sculptures, and native stone grottos.

Wynwood Walls — Discover this outdoor museum showcasing large-scale murals by international street artists on repurposed warehouse walls. The 50+ artworks transformed a warehouse district into Miami's most Instagrammed neighborhood since 2009.

Pérez Art Museum Miami — Visit this striking waterfront museum designed by Herzog & de Meuron featuring contemporary and modern art. The hanging gardens and bay views complement collections focusing on 20th and 21st-century international art.

Blue Spring State Park — Swim with manatees in the crystal-clear 72°F spring water where 300+ endangered manatees winter from November to March. The 2,600-acre park protects these gentle giants in their natural habitat amid cypress swamps.

Daytona International Speedway — Tour the World Center of Racing where the Daytona 500 has crowned NASCAR champions since 1959. The 2.5-mile tri-oval banking rises 31 degrees, creating the thrilling high-speed racing that made Daytona legendary.

Daytona Beach — Drive or walk on 37 kilometers of hard-packed sand where cars have raced since 1903. The wide Atlantic beach permits vehicle access while offering swimming, surfing, and iconic fishing pier views.
Return drive along the Overseas Highway; optional beach stop.
Buffer day for weather contingencies and departures.

South Beach - Where Art Deco Meets the Atlantic: The pastel-hued Art Deco Historic District along Ocean Drive preserves over 800 buildings from the 1920s-40s, creating the world's largest collection of Art Deco architecture steps from white sand beaches.

Downtown Miami - Big City Glamour on Biscayne Bay: Soaring towers, world-class museums, and sophisticated dining define Florida's largest urban center. The Pérez Art Museum, Frost Museum of Science, and Vizcaya Museum provide cultural anchors.

Vizcaya Museum and Gardens - An Italian Renaissance Villa in Florida: This 1916 estate built by industrialist James Deering features 34 decorated rooms filled with European antiques, surrounded by 10 acres of formal gardens overlooking Biscayne Bay.

Little Havana - The Heart of Cuban-American Culture: Calle Ocho (8th Street) pulses with domino games, cigar shops, Latin music, and authentic Cuban cuisine in the neighborhood formed by exiles in the 1950s.

Wynwood Walls - Street Art Goes Mainstream: This outdoor museum showcases massive murals by internationally recognized street artists across warehouse walls, transforming a former industrial district into Miami's hottest art destination.

Lincoln Road Mall - Shopping, Dining, and People-Watching: This mile-long pedestrian promenade features designer boutiques alongside local shops, restaurants with expansive terraces, and South Beach's most vibrant street scene.

Quartier historique Art Déco — Promenez-vous sur Ocean Drive en admirant plus de 800 bâtiments aux teintes pastel des années 1920-1940 représentant la plus grande concentration d'architecture Art Déco au monde. Les hôtels Streamline Moderne présentent des sols en terrazzo, des hublots et des façades géométriques en rose, turquoise et jaune.

Musée et jardins Vizcaya — Explorez cette villa de style Renaissance italienne construite entre 1914 et 1922 pour l'industriel James Deering. Le manoir de 34 pièces surplombe la baie de Biscayne, entouré de 10 acres de jardins européens formels avec fontaines, sculptures et grottes en pierre naturelle.

Wynwood Walls — Découvrez ce musée en plein air présentant des fresques murales à grande échelle réalisées par des artistes de rue internationaux sur des murs d'entrepôts reconvertis. Les plus de 50 œuvres d'art ont transformé un quartier d'entrepôts en quartier le plus photographié de Miami sur Instagram depuis 2009.

Pérez Art Museum Miami — Visitez ce musée saisissant en bord de mer conçu par Herzog & de Meuron présentant de l'art contemporain et moderne. Les jardins suspendus et les vues sur la baie complètent les collections axées sur l'art international des 20e et 21e siècles.

Parc d'État de Blue Spring — Nagez avec les lamantins dans les eaux cristallines de la source à 22°C où plus de 300 lamantins en danger hivernent de novembre à mars. Le parc de 2 600 acres protège ces géants doux dans leur habitat naturel au milieu des marécages de cyprès.

Daytona International Speedway — Visitez le Centre mondial de la course où la Daytona 500 couronne les champions NASCAR depuis 1959. Le tri-ovale de 2,5 miles s'élève à 31 degrés d'inclinaison, créant les courses palpitantes à haute vitesse qui ont rendu Daytona légendaire.

Daytona Beach — Conduisez ou marchez sur 37 kilomètres de sable compact où les voitures courent depuis 1903. La large plage atlantique permet l'accès aux véhicules tout en offrant la natation, le surf et des vues emblématiques sur la jetée de pêche.
Trajet de retour le long de l'Overseas Highway ; arrêt plage optionnel.
Jour de réserve pour les contingences météorologiques et les départs.

activities.text: Cuban lunch in Little Havana — Savor authentic ropa vieja and café cubano at family-owned restaurants along Calle Ocho. This vibrant neighborhood pulses with salsa music, cigar shops, and domino parks where Cuban exiles recreate Havana's atmosphere.

South Beach sunset — Relax on white sand beaches backed by Art Deco hotels as the sun sets over the Atlantic. The wide beach draws sunbathers, volleyball players, and people-watchers to America's most famous oceanfront.

Lincoln Road evening stroll — Browse this pedestrian mall designed by Morris Lapidus in 1960, featuring outdoor cafes, boutiques, and Art Deco cinemas. Street performers and al fresco dining create a European boulevard atmosphere under swaying palms.

Fresh citrus at roadside stand — Sample sweet Florida oranges, tangerines, and grapefruit at family-run fruit stands. The state's famous citrus industry offers fresh-squeezed juices and homemade preserves from grove to glass.
Return drive to Miami — Cruise south through Florida's diverse landscapes from Atlantic beaches to inland wetlands. The journey reveals the state's natural beauty and development contrasts.
Provisioning for reef and swamp outings.
Soirée dans Wynwood ou Little Havana de Miami.
Packing and returns.

Miami's Cultural Mosaic - Every Neighborhood a Different World: From Haitian Little Haiti to Brazilian cafes in North Miami, the city's immigrant communities have created authentic global experiences throughout the metropolitan area.
South Beach Nightlife - Dancing Until Dawn: World-renowned clubs and rooftop bars keep the party going until sunrise along Ocean Drive and Collins Avenue.

Déjeuner cubain à Little Havana — Savourez une authentique ropa vieja et un café cubano dans les restaurants familiaux le long de Calle Ocho. Ce quartier vibrant pulse au rythme de la salsa, des boutiques de cigares et des parcs de dominos où les exilés cubains recréent l'atmosphère de La Havane.

Coucher de soleil à South Beach — Détendez-vous sur les plages de sable blanc bordées d'hôtels Art Déco tandis que le soleil se couche sur l'Atlantique. La large plage attire les amateurs de bronzage, les joueurs de volleyball et les observateurs vers le front de mer le plus célèbre d'Amérique.

Promenade du soir sur Lincoln Road — Parcourez ce centre commercial piétonnier conçu par Morris Lapidus en 1960, avec des cafés en plein air, des boutiques et des cinémas Art Déco. Les artistes de rue et les repas en plein air créent une atmosphère de boulevard européen sous les palmiers qui se balancent.

Agrumes frais au stand routier — Dégustez les douces oranges, mandarines et pamplemousses de Floride dans des stands de fruits familiaux. La célèbre industrie agrumière de l'État offre des jus fraîchement pressés et des conserves maison du verger au verre.

Trajet de retour vers Miami — Roulez vers le sud à travers les paysages diversifiés de Floride des plages atlantiques aux zones humides intérieures. Le voyage révèle les contrastes entre la beauté naturelle de l'État et son développement.
Approvisionnement pour les sorties récif et marécage.

visits.text: Behold the masterwork that redefined architecture at Fallingwater, Frank Lloyd Wright's breathtaking integration of building and nature that seems to float above Bear Run's cascading waters. This UNESCO World Heritage Site, named by the American Institute of Architects as the 'best all-time work of American architecture,' demonstrates Wright's organic philosophy where cantilevered terraces extend directly over the waterfall and native stone walls rise from living rock. Guided tours reveal the ingenious engineering and the privileged life of the Kaufmann family who commissioned this mountain retreat.

Extend your Frank Lloyd Wright pilgrimage to nearby Polymath Park, where you can actually sleep inside Wright-designed homes. The property features Balter House and Mäntylä, both faithful to Wright's vision of harmonizing with the surrounding Laurel Highlands landscape, offering an immersive overnight experience in architectural masterpieces.

days_plan.itin_title: MINNESOTA -THE BEST PLACES !

visits.text: Flathead Lake — Drive along Montana's largest natural freshwater lake west of the Mississippi spanning 490 square kilometers. The glacially-carved lake features cherry orchards, Wild Horse Island, and the Flathead cherry harvest in summer.

National Bison Range — Observe 350-500 bison roaming 7,600 hectares of Palouse prairie and Mission Valley grasslands. The refuge established in 1908 protects these icons of the American West along with elk, pronghorn, and bighorn sheep.

University of Montana campus — Visit this public university founded in 1893 featuring Gothic Revival architecture on 89 hectares. The campus sits in the Missoula Valley surrounded by five mountain ranges.

Smokejumper Visitor Center — Learn about elite firefighters who parachute into remote wildfires at this active smokejumper base. Exhibits explain training, equipment, and the dangerous work protecting Western forests.

activities.text: Missoula downtown — Explore this vibrant college town featuring breweries, farm-to-table restaurants, and outdoor gear shops. The pedestrian-friendly downtown reflects Montana's recreation culture.

Clark Fork River walk — Stroll along riverside trails through Missoula's heart watching fly fishermen cast for trout. The Clark Fork flows through town creating green corridors and recreation opportunities.
Montana craft beer — Sample local brews at Missoula's thriving brewery scene. The city claims more breweries per capita than most American cities, celebrating Montana grains and water.

visits.text: Jour 1: Discover Mobile's cosmopolitan soul along Dauphin Street, where wrought-iron balconies and French Quarter-style architecture recall the city's time as capital of French Louisiana. Boutiques overflow with antiques, local art, and quirky curiosities, while the street's name honors the Dauphin, the French crown prince whose flag once flew over these Gulf shores. Pause at shady Bienville Square and intimate Cathedral Square to watch Mobile life unfold.

Jour 1: Follow the colorful Oyster Trail past a dozen whimsically painted oyster sculptures scattered through downtown, each transformed by a different artist into marine-themed masterpieces. Beyond their charm, the sculptures raise awareness about the oyster gardening program that helps restore Mobile Bay's crucial shellfish populations. Download the map to hunt them all.

Jour 1: Seek out Mobile's vibrant street art scene, from the Heart of Mobile mural perfect for selfies to colorful works tucked down alleys and along warehouse walls. The arts district around Wintzell's Oyster House offers particularly rich hunting grounds for photographers. Each mural adds another layer to this city's creative story.

Jour 1: Immerse yourself in the sequined, feathered extravaganza of Mardi Gras at the Mobile Carnival Museum, celebrating the city's claim as the original American home of Fat Tuesday festivities since 1703. Three floors of galleries showcase impossibly elaborate gowns worn by carnival queens, towering float designs, and the traditions that distinguish Mobile's celebrations from New Orleans' more famous party. The self-guided audio tour brings the magic to life year-round.

Jour 1: Enjoy Gulf Coast cuisine with a view at Dauphin's, perched on the 34th floor of downtown's tallest building where floor-to-ceiling windows survey the city, port, and bay. The Gumbo Z'herb arrives rich with greens, local Conecuh sausage, and smoked meats in a bowl that defines comfort food. Pair it with the Power Greens Salad and fresh thyme-scented lemonade for balance.

Jour 2: Peek behind the columns of the Condé-Charlotte Museum, an elegant downtown mansion that served first as courthouse and jail before becoming a gracious family home filled with antiques and Southern refinement. Guided tours reveal how Mobile's elite lived during the antebellum era, with formal parlors, ornate furnishings, and gardens offering a window into Gulf Coast gentility.

Jour 2: Trace Mobile's layered history at the History Museum of Mobile, where exhibits range from miniature dollhouse-style rooms to elaborate table settings from historic Mardi Gras balls. The Sensational Sixties exhibition captures the decade's fashion revolution, from scandalous bikinis to revolutionary pantsuits that changed how women dressed. The accessible galleries suit all ages.

Jour 2: Enter a world of moss-draped elegance at Historic Oakleigh House, an 1830s Greek Revival masterpiece rising from the heart of the Oakleigh Garden neighborhood. Cotton broker James Roper built this gracious home amid ancient oaks, and hourly tours guide you through rooms preserved with period furniture, family portraits, and stories of Mobile's leading families. The surrounding Washington Square epitomizes Southern charm.

Jour 2: Climb aboard the mighty USS Alabama at Battleship Memorial Park, where a WWII-era warship that served across the Pacific now rests as a floating museum. Explore multiple deck levels from the engine room to the bridge, gaining respect for the sailors who lived and fought in these steel corridors. The adjacent USS Drum submarine offers claustrophobic thrills for those brave enough to squeeze through its hatches.

Jour 2: Examine military aircraft spanning decades of American air power in the Medal of Honor Aircraft Pavilion, where fighters, bombers, and reconnaissance planes tell stories of aerial combat and technological evolution. Tanks and artillery pieces arrayed outdoors complete this comprehensive tribute to those who served.

activities.text: Jour 1: Satisfy your sweet tooth at the Moon Pie store, where the marshmallow-and-chocolate treats beloved as Mardi Gras throws come in every flavor imaginable. These Southern snacks originated in Tennessee but found their spiritual home in Mobile, where catching one flung from a parade float brings pure joy. Stock up on assorted flavors and Moon Pie merchandise.

Jour 1: End your day at Wintzell's Oyster House, the legendary original location where Mobile has slurped bivalves since 1938. The Oysters Rockefeller arrive bubbling with spinach and rich butter sauce, while the West Indies Salad showcases sweet Gulf crab in a simple oil-and-vinegar bath that lets the seafood shine. Quirky signs and decades of character cover every surface.

Jour 2: Drive through Mobile's historic districts to admire architectural styles spanning centuries, from French Colonial cottages to grand Italianate mansions draped in cast-iron lacework. The Mobile Historic Development Commission maps several driving trails that guide you past the city's finest preserved neighborhoods. Keep your camera ready for columned porticos and flower-filled gardens.

visits.text: Cross to the Central Coast; optional Pinnacles detour for talus caves if timing allows.
Big Sur coast — Bixby Creek Bridge viewpoint.

Monterey - Where Marine Science Meets Maritime History: This storied port where John Steinbeck set Cannery Row now houses world-class marine research alongside historic adobes from California's Spanish and Mexican periods.

Monterey Bay Aquarium - One of the World's Great Aquariums: Built inside a former sardine cannery, this institution pioneered living kelp forest exhibits and showcases the extraordinary biodiversity of Monterey Bay's submarine canyon, deeper than the Grand Canyon.

Cannery Row - From Steinbeck's Pages to Tourist Paradise: The sardine canneries immortalized in literature have transformed into shops, restaurants, and galleries, but the waterfront location and historic buildings retain authentic character.

17-Mile Drive - The Most Scenic Private Road in America: This legendary route winds through Del Monte Forest past the gnarled Lone Cypress, pristine beaches, and legendary Pebble Beach Golf Links with Pacific views at every turn.

17-Mile Drive — Travel this private scenic route winding along the Monterey Peninsula since 1881. Century-old cypresses twisted by the wind frame the fairways of Pebble Beach Golf Links and the wild coves battered by the Pacific.

Carmel Mission Basilica — Discover this Franciscan mission founded in 1771 by Father Junípero Serra, the second of the 21 California missions. The Spanish colonial architecture with adobe walls and the Mediterranean garden invite contemplation.

Carmel-by-the-Sea — Explore this bohemian coastal village with streets that have no numbers or commercial signs. Art galleries occupy former dollhouses while literary cafés perpetuate the artistic spirit dear to Jack London.

Point Lobos State Reserve — Hike in this nature reserve nicknamed the jewel of the California park system. Coastal trails reveal turquoise coves where sea lions and sea otters bask among giant kelp forests.
Visit to the elephant seal site in San Simeon

activities.text: Cannery Row waterfront sunset stroll.

Whale Watching in the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary - Giants of the Deep: This underwater canyon creates upwelling that supports year-round whale populations, from gray whales migrating past to resident humpbacks, blue whales, and orcas.
Seafood lunch in Monterey — Taste creamy clam chowder served in sourdough bread on Fisherman's Wharf. Family restaurants prepare freshly caught fish since Monterey was the world capital of sardines.

Visit to Monterey Bay Aquarium — Marvel at the hypnotic ballet of jellyfish and three-story kelp forests in this revolutionary aquarium installed in a former sardine cannery. More than 35,000 marine creatures evolve in their reconstructed habitats.

Kayak trip in the bay — Paddle among sea otters and sea lions in the protected waters of Monterey Bay. Naturalist guides share their knowledge of this marine ecosystem designated as a national sanctuary since 1992.
Promenade au coucher du soleil sur le front de mer de Cannery Row.

visits.text: Jour 1: Step into the Jazz Age at the Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald Museum, the only museum dedicated to America's most glamorous literary couple, set in the Montgomery home they rented during the 1930s. Letters between Scott and Zelda reveal their passionate, turbulent romance, while Zelda's vibrant paintings showcase talents often overshadowed by her husband's fame. The museum captures both the dazzling promise and tragic unraveling of two bright stars of the Roaring Twenties.

Jour 1: Stroll Montgomery's riverfront district, where the Alabama River bends past historic wharves that once bustled with cotton bales bound for Mobile and beyond. The strategic bluff that gave Montgomery its prominence still offers commanding views across the water. Wander up Commerce Street to Court Square Fountain, built on the site of both the city's original water source and, darkly, its slave market.

Jour 1: Prepare your heart for the National Memorial for Peace and Justice, a profound tribute to the thousands of African Americans terrorized and killed by lynching across the American South. Walking through the memorial, the ground slopes away until 800 weathered steel columns hang overhead, each inscribed with names of victims from a single county, the weight of injustice made physical and inescapable. The memorial's stark beauty offers space for grief, reflection, and reckoning.

Jour 1: Continue the emotional journey at the Legacy Museum, housed in a warehouse where enslaved people were once held before auction, now transformed into a searing examination of how slavery's legacy persists. From video testimonies of modern prisoners to holographic figures of enslaved mothers separated from children, the exhibits draw unflinching connections between past and present injustice. Photography is forbidden, making this an experience to be fully present in and carry with you.

Jour 1: Climb Dexter Avenue to the gleaming white dome of the Alabama State Capitol, where the Confederacy was briefly born and where, a century later, Dr. King addressed 25,000 marchers demanding voting rights. The Greek Revival monument offers tours through legislative chambers, the old Supreme Court, and the soaring rotunda. Outside, the Avenue of Flags representing all 50 states surrounds a replica Liberty Bell.

Jour 1: Complete your civil rights pilgrimage at Dexter Avenue King Memorial Baptist Church, where Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. served as pastor from 1954 to 1960, just steps from the seat of Alabama's segregationist government. From this pulpit he launched the Montgomery Bus Boycott after Rosa Parks' arrest, and within these walls strategies for nonviolent resistance took shape. Tours reveal the sanctuary, a powerful mural, and the parsonage where King's family lived.

Jour 2: Find respite in art at the Montgomery Museum of Fine Arts, set amid grassy lawns just outside downtown where galleries showcase everything from American masters to shimmering art glass. The colorful children's gallery and activity area makes this an ideal family stop, while the outdoor sculpture garden invites contemplation among bronzes and blooms. Free admission and parking remove any barrier to cultural enrichment.

Jour 2: Surrender to pecan paradise at Priester's, a roadside institution south of Montgomery where every conceivable pecan creation fills shelves and display cases. Grab a bag of fresh-roasted nuts, a slice of dense pecan pie, or scoop after scoop of praline-studded ice cream before settling into a rocking chair on the shaded porch. Just remember the correct pronunciation is pe-CAHN, not PEE-can, if you want to blend in with the locals.

activities.text: Jour 1: Fuel up on smoky, tender ribs at Dreamland BBQ, a Montgomery institution where families pack communal tables to devour platters of pit-smoked meats. Even if you're watching your waistline, the Smokehouse Cobb salad arrives heaped with enough shredded pork to satisfy your BBQ cravings. The sweet-tangy sauce that made Dreamland famous comes bottled to take home.

Jour 1: Discover Montgomery's contemporary culinary scene at Central, a sophisticated yet approachable destination in the historic Alley warehouse district. The smoked pork belly with tangy peach chutney bridges traditional and modern Southern cooking, while the iconic wedge salad loaded with bacon, candied pecans, and blue cheese dressing is a meal unto itself. The buzzing room draws everyone from lawmakers to artists.

Jour 1: Live your Jazz Age fantasy at the Fitzgerald Museum's Zelda Suite, one of two atmospheric apartments available above the museum through vacation rentals. Fall asleep beneath a portrait of the golden-haired beauty herself, surrounded by reproductions of her paintings and framed love letters to Scott. The 1930s decor feels like visiting a stylish grandmother's home, complete with spacious living areas and a vintage kitchen.

Jour 2: Enjoy a leisurely morning exploring Montgomery's quieter corners before the scenic drive south. The extra time allows for unhurried browsing at Priester's extensive gift shop, where pecan candies, flavored coffees, and Southern cookbooks make perfect edible souvenirs. The rocking chairs practically insist you sit a spell.
