visits.text: Mount Magazine State Park - Standing Atop Arkansas's Rooftop: At 2,753 feet, Arkansas's highest peak commands views spanning 50 miles across the Petit Jean River Valley to distant blue ridges. The dual summits-Signal Hill and Mossback Ridge-frame a highland plateau of rare flora, hang-gliding launches, and endless sky.

Cameron Bluff Overlook - The Grandest View in the Natural State: Gaze across a sea of forested ridges from this heart-stopping precipice where the mountain drops away into void. On clear days, visibility extends to the Boston Mountains of the Ozarks.

activities.text: Hang Gliding Capital of the Mid-South - Soar with Eagles: Consistent thermals rising from the valley floor make Mount Magazine legendary among pilots. Tandem flights offer beginners the chance to experience human flight above spectacular terrain.

Rim Trail System - 15 Miles of Cliff-Edge Adventure: Multiple interconnected paths trace the mountain's dramatic edges, ranging from easy strolls to rugged backcountry routes through boulder fields and rare endemic plant communities.

days_plan.itin_title: Arkansas Unveiled: Mountains, Diamonds & Healing Waters of the Natural State
Arkansas Unveiled: Mountains, Diamonds & Healing Waters of the Natural State

visits.text: Mount Nebo State Park - The Flat-Topped Giant with Endless Views: Rising 1,350 feet above the Arkansas River Valley, this isolated mesa offers rim trails skirting dramatic cliff edges with unobstructed panoramas across the valley to distant mountain ranges. Originally developed as a resort escape in the 1880s, the mountaintop retains its peaceful, time-forgotten atmosphere.

Sunrise Point & Sunset Point - Bookend Your Day with Spectacle: Strategic overlooks on opposite sides of the mesa capture the valley's transformation from dawn's first light to twilight's final glow, as mist rises from the river far below.

activities.text: Bench Road Trail - Walk the Historic Rim: This 3.5-mile path circles the mountain's edge, originally carved as a carriage road for Victorian-era visitors, now offering continuous cliff-edge views and access to rustic CCC-built structures.
Gum Springs Trail to Valley Floor - Descend into the Wild: For the adventurous, this challenging 1.5-mile trail drops 1,000 feet through dense forest to spring-fed pools at the mountain's base.

days_plan.itin_title: Arkansas Unveiled: Mountains, Diamonds & Healing Waters of the Natural State
Arkansas Unveiled: Mountains, Diamonds & Healing Waters of the Natural State

visits.text: Mount Rainier National Park — Paradise — Hike wildflower meadows beneath the 4,392-meter active volcano dominating the Cascade Range. The Paradise area receives 17 meters of average annual snowfall and offers stunning views of Rainier's 26 named glaciers.

Paradise Inn — Visit this 1916 National Historic Landmark built from Alaska cedar with massive exposed beams and stone fireplaces. The rustic mountain lodge exemplifies National Park Service architecture designed to harmonize with natural surroundings.

Nisqually Vista Trail — Walk this 1.2-mile loop offering close views of the Nisqually Glacier descending from Rainier's summit. Interpretive signs explain glacial geology and climate change impacts on these shrinking ice rivers.

Reflection Lakes — Photograph Mount Rainier mirrored in alpine lakes along the Stevens Canyon Road. On calm days, the 4,392-meter peak creates perfect reflections framed by subalpine fir and mountain hemlock.

Parc national du Mont Rainier — Paradise — Randonnez dans les prairies de fleurs sauvages sous le volcan actif de 4 392 mètres dominant la chaîne Cascade. La zone Paradise reçoit 17 mètres de chute de neige annuelle moyenne et offre des vues magnifiques sur les 26 glaciers nommés de Rainier.

Paradise Inn — Visitez ce monument historique national de 1916 construit en cèdre d'Alaska avec d'énormes poutres apparentes et des cheminées en pierre. Le lodge de montagne rustique illustre l'architecture du Service des parcs nationaux conçue pour s'harmoniser avec l'environnement naturel.

Sentier Nisqually Vista — Parcourez cette boucle de 1,2 mile offrant des vues rapprochées du glacier Nisqually descendant du sommet de Rainier. Des panneaux d'interprétation expliquent la géologie glaciaire et les impacts du changement climatique sur ces rivières de glace qui rétrécissent.

Lacs Reflection — Photographiez le Mont Rainier reflété dans les lacs alpins le long de la Stevens Canyon Road. Par temps calme, le pic de 4 392 mètres crée des reflets parfaits encadrés par des sapins subalpins et des pruches de montagne.

activities.text: Wildlife watching — Scan meadows for black bears, mountain goats, and marmots while keeping eyes skyward for Clark's nutcrackers and gray jays. The park protects 65 mammal species and 182 bird species.

Sunrise viewpoint visit — Drive to the park's highest accessible point at 1,950 meters for expansive views across the Cascade volcanoes. On clear days, Mount Adams, Mount Hood, and even Mount Baker appear on the horizon.

Evening campfire program — Attend ranger-led programs explaining Rainier's volcanic history, glacial dynamics, and ecosystem. The evening talks occur in amphitheaters throughout the park during summer months.

Observation de la faune — Scrutez les prairies à la recherche d'ours noirs, de chèvres de montagne et de marmottes tout en gardant les yeux levés vers le ciel pour apercevoir les cassenoix de Clark et les geais gris. Le parc protège 65 espèces de mammifères et 182 espèces d'oiseaux.

Visite du point de vue au lever du soleil — Conduisez jusqu'au point le plus élevé accessible du parc à 1 950 mètres pour des vues panoramiques sur les volcans de la chaîne des Cascades. Par temps clair, le Mount Adams, le Mount Hood et même le Mount Baker apparaissent à l'horizon.

Programme de feu de camp en soirée — Assistez aux programmes dirigés par les gardes forestiers expliquant l'histoire volcanique de Rainier, la dynamique glaciaire et l'écosystème. Les conférences du soir ont lieu dans les amphithéâtres du parc pendant les mois d'été.

days_plan.itin_title: WASHINGTON: FROM SEATTLE'S COFFEE CULTURE TO MOUNT RAINIER'S GLACIERS

visits.text: Drive north via the Mackinac Bridge (8 km suspension span over the Straits) to Michigan’s Upper Peninsula; quick lighthouse and fort era viewpoints en route.
Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore — Miners Castle Overlook and Sand Point; multicolored Cambrian–Ordovician sandstone carved by frost and surf.
Pictured Rocks Cruise or Kayak (conditions permitting) — View cathedral‑like arches (Lovers Leap), streaked mineral seeps, and narrow sea caves from the waterline.
Munising Falls & Miners Falls — Accessible glen with seasonal ice curtains; short trail to a 12‑meter plunge through boreal forest.
Grand Sable Dunes — High parabolic dunes sliding toward Lake Superior; log debris marks historic storm lines on the beach below.

Conduire vers le nord via le Mackinac Bridge (portée suspendue de 8 km au-dessus des détroits) vers la péninsule supérieure du Michigan ; points de vue rapides sur les phares et forts de l'époque en route.
Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore — Miners Castle Overlook et Sand Point ; grès multicolore du Cambrien-Ordovicien sculpté par le gel et les vagues.

Croisière ou kayak Pictured Rocks (conditions permettant) — Observer les arches semblables à des cathédrales (Lovers Leap), les suintements minéraux striés et les grottes marines étroites depuis la ligne de flottaison.
Munising Falls et Miners Falls — Vallon accessible avec rideaux de glace saisonniers ; court sentier vers une chute de 12 mètres à travers la forêt boréale.
Grand Sable Dunes — Hautes dunes paraboliques glissant vers le lac Supérieur ; débris de bois marquent les lignes de tempête historiques sur la plage en contrebas.

activities.text: Evening lakeshore walk; consider a night-sky session under low light pollution.
Local whitefish tasting in town; visit small outfitters for maps and weather.
Promenade du soir au bord du lac ; envisager une session d'observation du ciel nocturne sous une faible pollution lumineuse.
Dégustation de corégone local en ville ; visiter les petits équipementiers pour cartes et météo.

days_plan.itin_title: GREAT LAKES EAST — SHORES AND DUNES OF MICHIGAN
GREAT LAKES EAST — SHORES AND DUNES OF MICHIGAN

visits.text: Crater of Diamonds State Park - The Only Diamond Mine on Earth Where You Keep What You Find: Dig through 95-million-year-old volcanic soil where diamonds still surface after every rain. Over 35,000 diamonds have been unearthed here since 1906, including the 'Strawn-Wagner Diamond'-one of only three stones in existence graded perfect. Beyond diamonds, hunters discover amethysts, garnets, jasper, and over 40 other minerals.

activities.text: Diamond Prospecting - Your Chance at Forever: Rent equipment and learn techniques from park staff, then spend hours sifting through the plowed 37.5-acre search field. Diamonds appear as small, greasy-looking pebbles-and every visitor has the same chance at discovery.

Diamond Discovery Center - From Rough Stone to Brilliant Gem: Exhibits explain the volcanic geology that deposited these treasures, display record-breaking finds, and offer identification services for your discoveries.

days_plan.itin_title: Arkansas Unveiled: Mountains, Diamonds & Healing Waters of the Natural State
Arkansas Unveiled: Mountains, Diamonds & Healing Waters of the Natural State

visits.text: Experience the vibrant energy of Myrtle Beach, where golden sands stretch for miles along the Atlantic and the famous boardwalk pulses with vacation excitement. The iconic SkyWheel observation wheel provides panoramic views of the coastline, while sunrise paints the sky in cotton-candy hues above the rolling waves. This classic American beach destination delivers sun-soaked fun for visitors of all ages.

Explore Broadway at the Beach, a sprawling entertainment district featuring waterfront attractions, live entertainment venues, and diverse dining options. The complex includes family-friendly activities ranging from aquarium visits to interactive experiences. Evening brings the boardwalk to life with arcades, shops, and the glow of neon reflecting off the ocean.

activities.text: Visit North Myrtle Beach, the birthplace of Shag dancing and a community maintaining its connection to this beloved regional tradition. The Beach Shagger's National Hall of Fame celebrates the dance's history, while venues around Ocean Drive keep the tradition alive with regular gatherings. Barefoot Landing offers waterfront shopping and dining in a more relaxed setting than the main beach strip.

days_plan.itin_title: South Carolina Grand Tour: Coastal Elegance to Mountain Serenity

visits.text: Gillette Castle State Park - A Medieval Fantasy Overlooking the River: Explore the extraordinary 24-room mansion of Connecticut-born actor William Hooker Gillette, featuring 47 unique doors each designed by the eccentric thespian and crafted by local artisans. This medieval-style stone castle offers stunning terrace views of the Connecticut River winding through the valley below.

Mystic Seaport Museum - America's Leading Maritime Museum: Step aboard the country's largest collection of historic vessels, from majestic tall ships to humble tugboats, in this 19-acre living history museum. Working craftsmen demonstrate traditional boat-building techniques in authentic 19th-century buildings recreating a New England coastal village.

Mystic Aquarium - Encounter Ocean Life Up Close: Meet beluga whales, penguins, sea lions, and thousands of marine species in this world-renowned facility dedicated to ocean education and conservation. Interactive exhibits and animal encounters bring the underwater world to life.

Mystic River Bascule Bridge - Engineering Marvel Since 1922: This historic drawbridge rises regularly to allow tall-masted vessels passage along the Mystic River, a spectacle that has defined the town's character for over a century.

activities.text: Downtown Mystic - 80+ Independent Shops and Galleries: Wander the charming downtown district filled with clothing boutiques, artisanal candy stores, art galleries, and waterfront patios offering views of the harbor.

Mystic Pizza - The Setting That Launched a Thousand Pies: This actual pizzeria inspired the 1988 Julia Roberts romantic comedy of the same name. Browse film memorabilia while enjoying the famous pies that put this small town on the Hollywood map.

days_plan.itin_title: Connecticut Unveiled: Maritime Heritage, Ivy League Culture & New England's Hidden Gem
Connecticut Unveiled: Maritime Heritage, Ivy League Culture & New England's Hidden Gem

visits.text: Napa Valley - The World's Most Famous Wine Address: This 30-mile valley produces wines that have triumphed over French competitors in blind tastings, forever changing global perceptions of California viticulture. Over 400 wineries, 95% family-owned, dot the landscape from valley floor to mountain slopes.

Silverado Trail - The Quieter Path Through Wine Country: This scenic alternative to Highway 29 winds past historic estates and boutique producers, offering a more intimate wine country experience away from the crowds.

Oxbow Public Market - Napa's Culinary Heart: This indoor marketplace showcases the region's artisanal food producers, from oyster bars to olive oil specialists, chocolatiers to charcuterie masters, all celebrating Northern California's bounty.

activities.text: Hot Air Balloon Over the Vineyards - Drift Above a Patchwork of Vines: Morning launches float silently over mist-shrouded valleys as the sun illuminates thousands of acres of perfectly aligned grapevines stretching to distant mountain ridges.

Napa Valley Wine Train - Vintage Rails Through Vintage Vines: This restored 1915 Pullman dining car travels 36 miles through the heart of wine country, offering multi-course meals paired with local wines as the landscape glides past mahogany-framed windows.

days_plan.itin_title: California Unveiled: From Ancient Redwoods to Desert Wonders - The Ultimate Golden State Odyssey
California Unveiled: From Ancient Redwoods to Desert Wonders - The Ultimate Golden State Odyssey

visits.text: Naples Pier — Walk this 305-meter fishing pier extending into the Gulf of Mexico, a Naples landmark since 1888. Anglers catch snook and tarpon while dolphins play in the surf and shorebirds patrol the white sand beaches.

Corkscrew Swamp Sanctuary — Follow a 3.7-kilometer boardwalk through America's largest old-growth bald cypress forest, featuring trees over 500 years old. The Audubon sanctuary protects wood storks, alligators, and the endangered Florida panther.

Fifth Avenue South — Browse upscale boutiques, galleries, and sidewalk cafes in this Mediterranean-style shopping district. Royal palms and flowering plants line the pedestrian-friendly streets of Naples' cultural heart.

Naples Botanical Garden — Explore 170 acres showcasing plants from tropical climates worldwide, including Caribbean, Brazilian, and Asian gardens. Water features, orchid displays, and butterfly gardens create serene landscapes designed by renowned landscape architects.
Naples - The Paradise Coast Lives Up to Its Name: Sugary white sand, glimmering blue-green water, and spectacular sunsets define this sophisticated Gulf Coast destination.

Naples Botanical Garden - 170 Acres of Global Flora: This world-class garden showcases plant communities from around the world, from Brazilian rainforest to Caribbean islands, across beautifully designed landscapes.
Historic Naples Pier - Sunset Central: This 1,000-foot fishing pier extending into the Gulf has anchored Naples since 1888, offering spectacular sunset views and excellent fishing.
Fifth Avenue South - Sophisticated Strolling: Naples' premier shopping and dining district features upscale boutiques, galleries, and restaurants along a beautifully landscaped promenade.

Jetée de Naples — Promenez-vous sur cette jetée de pêche de 305 mètres s'étendant dans le Golfe du Mexique, un monument de Naples depuis 1888. Les pêcheurs attrapent du brochet et du tarpon tandis que les dauphins jouent dans les vagues et que les oiseaux de rivage patrouillent sur les plages de sable blanc.

Sanctuaire du marais Corkscrew — Suivez une passerelle de 3,7 kilomètres à travers la plus grande forêt de cyprès chauves anciens d'Amérique, avec des arbres de plus de 500 ans. Le sanctuaire Audubon protège les cigognes des bois, les alligators et la panthère de Floride en danger.

Fifth Avenue South — Parcourez les boutiques haut de gamme, galeries et cafés en terrasse dans ce quartier commerçant de style méditerranéen. Les palmiers royaux et les plantes fleuries bordent les rues piétonnes du cœur culturel de Naples.

Jardin botanique de Naples — Explorez 170 acres présentant des plantes de climats tropicaux du monde entier, incluant des jardins caribéens, brésiliens et asiatiques. Les jeux d'eau, expositions d'orchidées et jardins de papillons créent des paysages sereins conçus par des architectes paysagistes renommés.

activities.text: Shelling on Sanibel Island — Search for shells on beaches ranked among America's best for shell collecting. The island's east-west orientation catches shells from the Gulf Stream, including rare junonia and lion's paw specimens.

Sunset dolphin cruise — Glide through calm Gulf waters watching bottlenose dolphins feed and play during golden hour. Captains navigate to prime viewing spots while explaining marine ecosystems and local history.

Fresh Gulf seafood dinner — Dine on grouper, snapper, and stone crab at waterfront restaurants serving daily catches. Naples' culinary scene combines Florida seafood with sophisticated preparations and Gulf sunset views.

Everglades City Access - Gateway to the Ten Thousand Islands: This nearby outpost provides boat access to the western Everglades, where a maze of mangrove islands shelters manatees, dolphins, and countless bird species.

Collecte de coquillages sur l'île Sanibel — Cherchez des coquillages sur des plages classées parmi les meilleures d'Amérique pour la collecte de coquillages. L'orientation est-ouest de l'île attrape les coquillages du Gulf Stream, incluant de rares spécimens de junonia et de patte de lion.

Croisière dauphins au coucher du soleil — Glissez sur les eaux calmes du Golfe en observant les grands dauphins se nourrir et jouer pendant l'heure dorée. Les capitaines naviguent vers les meilleurs spots d'observation tout en expliquant les écosystèmes marins et l'histoire locale.

Dîner de fruits de mer frais du Golfe — Dînez de mérou, vivaneau et crabe des rochers dans des restaurants au bord de l'eau servant les prises du jour. La scène culinaire de Naples combine les fruits de mer de Floride avec des préparations sophistiquées et des vues sur le coucher de soleil du Golfe.

days_plan.itin_title: FLORIDA: EVERGLADES WILDERNESS TO ART DECO MIAMI GLAMOUR
Florida Unveiled: From Pristine Barrier Islands to Tropical Keys - The Ultimate Sunshine State Adventure

visits.text: Wander the enchanting lanes of Wickford Village, a perfectly preserved Colonial fishing village where 18th-century homes and weathered sea captains' cottages line narrow streets unchanged for centuries. This quaint New England gem invites leisurely exploration of antique shops, artisan galleries, and boutiques housed in historic buildings, all overlooking the sheltered harbor where fishing boats still bob at anchor. The village's authentic charm provides a peaceful escape into Rhode Island's maritime heritage.

Sink your toes into the golden sands of Narragansett Bay's exceptional beaches, where 147 miles of coastline form New England's largest estuary and premier summer playground. The pristine strands of Narragansett Town Beach attract sun-seekers with gentle waves and soft sand, while Matunuck Beach State Park and Roger W. Wheeler State Beach offer family-friendly swimming and spectacular coastal scenery. These waters have drawn visitors for generations to experience Rhode Island's legendary beach culture.

activities.text: Explore the diverse ecosystems of Narragansett Bay by kayak, paddling through salt marshes alive with wading birds, around rocky outcroppings where seals haul out to sun themselves, and past historic lighthouses that have guided mariners for centuries. Local outfitters provide equipment and guided tours that reveal the hidden corners of this remarkable estuary.

days_plan.itin_title: Rhode Island's Gilded Shores & Colonial Treasures - America's Smallest State, Grandest Discoveries

visits.text: Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum — Explore the history of country music through artifacts, recordings, and exhibits spanning 350,000 square feet. The $37 million facility opened in 2001 houses Elvis's gold Cadillac, Hank Williams's Martin guitar, and Taylor Swift's rhinestone stage outfits.

Ryman Auditorium — Tour the Mother Church of Country Music, a 1892 tabernacle turned concert hall that hosted the Grand Ole Opry from 1943-1974. The intimate 2,362-seat venue offers unparalleled acoustics and preserves pews where legends performed.

Broadway Honky Tonks — Experience live music pouring from three-story bars lining lower Broadway. The neon-lit strip features Tootsie's Orchid Lounge, Robert's Western World, and other venues offering free country music from 10am to 3am.

Parthenon in Centennial Park — Marvel at this full-scale replica of the Athens Parthenon built for Tennessee's 1897 Centennial Exposition. The permanent concrete structure houses an art museum and 13-meter statue of Athena Parthenos.

Grand Ole Opry — Attend a performance at country music's most famous stage, broadcasting live since 1925. The show moved to Opry House in 1974 but maintains traditions of introducing artists and mail-order sponsorships.

Johnny Cash Museum — Discover the Man in Black's life through the world's largest collection of Cash artifacts. The museum chronicles his musical career, activism, and personal struggles across 18,000 square feet.

Frist Art Museum — Explore rotating exhibitions in this Art Deco former post office built in 1934. The museum presents diverse art from antiquities to contemporary without maintaining a permanent collection.

Tennessee State Capitol — Tour this 1859 Greek Revival building designed by William Strickland who is buried in its walls. The National Historic Landmark sits prominently on a hill above downtown offering city views.
Fall Creek Falls State Park — Hike to Tennessee's highest waterfall plunging 78 meters into a gorge. The 11,000-hectare park features multiple waterfalls, caves, and Cumberland Plateau scenery.

Andrew Jackson's Hermitage — Tour the mansion and plantation of the seventh US president who lived here 1804-1845. The 445-hectare estate preserves Greek Revival architecture, slave quarters, and Jackson's tomb.

Belle Meade Plantation — Explore this antebellum plantation famous for thoroughbred horses and bourbon. The 1853 Greek Revival mansion offers tours explaining Southern plantation life and horse breeding.

Jour 1: Trace the complete story of America's most beloved musical genre at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, one of the world's largest museums dedicated to the preservation and celebration of country music. Four floors of exhibits showcase rare instruments, iconic costumes, handwritten lyrics, and multimedia presentations honoring the legends who shaped the Nashville Sound from its Appalachian roots to today's chart-topping artists.

Jour 1: Stand in the sacred Assembly Room of the Ryman Auditorium, the 'Mother Church of Country Music' where the Grand Ole Opry broadcast for 31 years and where countless careers were launched under its iconic stained-glass windows. This National Historic Landmark witnessed Johnny Cash meeting June Carter, Hank Williams bringing audiences to tears, and generations of artists achieving their dreams on its hallowed stage.

Jour 1: Explore the life and legacy of the Man in Black at the Johnny Cash Museum, housing the world's largest collection of Johnny Cash artifacts and memorabilia. From his humble Arkansas beginnings through his struggles with addiction to his triumphant later career, the museum presents an intimate portrait of an American icon through personal items, handwritten letters, and rare recordings.

Jour 2: Experience the longest-running radio broadcast in American history at the Grand Ole Opry, the show that made country music famous and continues to showcase the genre's brightest stars every weekend. Since 1925, this legendary program has launched careers, created legends, and brought the joy of country music to millions of listeners and live audiences who witness history being made with every performance.

Jour 2: Journey to Music Row and step inside Studio B, the most famous recording studio in Nashville where Elvis Presley recorded over 200 songs and countless other hits were born. As part of the Country Music Hall of Fame experience, guided tours reveal the surprisingly modest space where billions of dollars worth of music was created, including the actual console and equipment that captured these immortal recordings.

Jour 2: Admire world-class art in a stunning Art Deco setting at the Frist Art Museum, housed in Nashville's magnificent 1934 U.S. Post Office building listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The museum's rotating exhibitions bring masterworks from around the globe to Music City, while the building itself-with its marble floors, ornate ceilings, and period details-stands as a masterpiece of Depression-era architecture.

Jour 3: Squeeze into the intimate confines of the Bluebird Cafe, the legendary 90-seat listening room where Taylor Swift was discovered and countless songwriters have shared their stories in the round. This unassuming venue in a strip mall has launched more careers than any showcase in Nashville, where the rule of respectful silence allows audiences to experience songs the way their creators intended-up close and personal.

Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum — Explorez l'histoire de la musique country à travers des objets, des enregistrements et des expositions s'étendant sur 350 000 pieds carrés. Cette installation de 37 millions de dollars ouverte en 2001 abrite la Cadillac dorée d'Elvis, la guitare Martin de Hank Williams et les tenues de scène serties de strass de Taylor Swift.

Parthenon dans Centennial Park — Admirez cette réplique grandeur nature du Parthénon d'Athènes construite pour l'Exposition du Centenaire du Tennessee en 1897. Cette structure permanente en béton abrite un musée d'art et une statue de 13 mètres d'Athéna Parthénos.

Ryman Auditorium — Visitez l'Église Mère de la Musique Country, un tabernacle de 1892 transformé en salle de concert qui a accueilli le Grand Ole Opry de 1943 à 1974. Cette salle intime de 2 362 places offre une acoustique inégalée et préserve les bancs où les légendes se sont produites.

Broadway Honky Tonks — Découvrez la musique live qui s'échappe des bars de trois étages bordant le bas de Broadway. Cette bande illuminée au néon comprend le Tootsie's Orchid Lounge, le Robert's Western World et d'autres lieux offrant de la musique country gratuite de 10h à 3h du matin.

Grand Ole Opry — Assistez à une représentation sur la scène la plus célèbre de la musique country, diffusée en direct depuis 1925. Le spectacle a déménagé à l'Opry House en 1974 mais maintient les traditions de présentation des artistes et des parrainages par correspondance.

Johnny Cash Museum — Découvrez la vie de l'Homme en Noir à travers la plus grande collection mondiale d'objets de Cash. Le musée retrace sa carrière musicale, son activisme et ses luttes personnelles sur 18 000 pieds carrés.

Frist Art Museum — Explorez les expositions temporaires dans cet ancien bureau de poste Art déco construit en 1934. Le musée présente un art diversifié, de l'antiquité au contemporain, sans maintenir de collection permanente.

Tennessee State Capitol — Visitez ce bâtiment néo-grec de 1859 conçu par William Strickland qui est enterré dans ses murs. Ce monument historique national se dresse en évidence sur une colline au-dessus du centre-ville, offrant des vues sur la ville.

Fall Creek Falls State Park — Randonnez jusqu'à la plus haute cascade du Tennessee plongeant de 78 mètres dans une gorge. Ce parc de 11 000 hectares présente de multiples cascades, grottes et paysages du plateau de Cumberland.

Andrew Jackson's Hermitage — Visitez le manoir et la plantation du septième président américain qui y vécut de 1804 à 1845. Ce domaine de 445 hectares préserve l'architecture Greek Revival, les quartiers d'esclaves et la tombe de Jackson.

Belle Meade Plantation — Explorez cette plantation d'avant-guerre civile célèbre pour ses chevaux pur-sang et son bourbon. Le manoir de style néo-grec de 1853 propose des visites expliquant la vie des plantations du Sud et l'élevage de chevaux.

activities.text: Hot chicken experience — Taste Nashville's signature dish featuring fried chicken coated in cayenne-laced oil at Prince's Hot Chicken Shack or Hattie B's. The spice levels range from mild to shut-the-cluck-up hot.
Music Row exploration — Drive past recording studios where countless hits were produced on this concentrated strip. RCA Studio B, where Elvis recorded over 200 songs, offers tours.

Live music at the Bluebird Cafe — Catch songwriters performing original material in this intimate 90-seat venue. The listening room launched careers of Garth Brooks and Taylor Swift with its famous writers-in-the-round shows.
Gulch neighborhood — Browse boutiques, murals, and restaurants in this revitalized warehouse district. The trendy neighborhood features Instagram-worthy street art and upscale Southern cuisine.
Pedal tavern tour — Join a party bike cruising Nashville streets while sampling local beers. The 15-passenger cycles powered by pedaling passengers create rolling happy hours.
Final Nashville evening — Return to Broadway for last night of honky-tonk music and people-watching. The street comes alive after dark with boot-scootin' crowds and live bands.
Farewell Southern dinner — Celebrate with meat-and-three, fried catfish, or hot chicken one last time. Tennessee cuisine embodies Southern comfort food traditions.

Jour 1: Discover Nashville's vibrant street art scene in The Gulch, a revitalized warehouse district where industrial history meets contemporary cool. The neighborhood's crown jewel is the 'What Lifts You' angel wings mural, one of the most photographed spots in Nashville, surrounded by trendy boutiques, craft cocktail bars, and acclaimed restaurants.

Jour 2: Dive into Nashville's legendary honky-tonk scene along Lower Broadway, where neon signs illuminate a three-block stretch of boot-stomping venues. From the world-famous Tootsies Orchid Lounge, where stars still make surprise appearances, to Robert's Western World, temple of traditional country, and Legend's Corner with its non-stop live music, these bars have launched more careers than any music school.

Jour 3: Cruise the first miles of the historic Natchez Trace Parkway, a 444-mile scenic route following the ancient trail used by Native Americans, early settlers, and post riders through the wilderness. The Tennessee portion offers 100 miles of unhurried driving at 50 mph through pristine forests, past historic sites, and along ridgelines where the modern world fades away.
Journey St. Louis → Nashville via Interstate I-64/I-24
Musical stroll on Broadway (observation of concert venues, without extended stops)
Grand Ole Opry (concert scheduled according to availability)
Discovery of murals (The Gulch: "Wings" by Kelsey Montague)
Live country music session (historic venue or recorded show)

Expérience du hot chicken — Goûtez le plat signature de Nashville composé de poulet frit enrobé d'huile épicée au cayenne chez Prince's Hot Chicken Shack ou Hattie B's. Les niveaux d'épices vont de doux à terriblement piquant.

Exploration de Music Row — Conduisez le long des studios d'enregistrement où d'innombrables succès ont été produits sur cette bande concentrée. RCA Studio B, où Elvis a enregistré plus de 200 chansons, propose des visites.

Musique live au Bluebird Cafe — Assistez aux performances d'auteurs-compositeurs jouant leurs créations originales dans ce lieu intime de 90 places. Cette salle d'écoute a lancé les carrières de Garth Brooks et Taylor Swift avec ses fameux spectacles writers-in-the-round.

Quartier Gulch — Parcourez les boutiques, murales et restaurants de ce quartier d'entrepôts revitalisé. Ce quartier branché présente de l'art de rue digne d'Instagram et une cuisine sudiste haut de gamme.

Tour en taverne à pédales — Rejoignez un vélo de fête parcourant les rues de Nashville tout en dégustant des bières locales. Ces cycles de 15 passagers alimentés par le pédalage des passagers créent des happy hours roulants.

Dernière soirée à Nashville — Retournez sur Broadway pour une dernière nuit de musique honky-tonk et d'observation des gens. La rue s'anime après la tombée de la nuit avec des foules dansantes et des groupes en direct.
Dîner d'adieu du Sud — Célébrez avec un meat-and-three, du poisson-chat frit, ou du poulet piquant une dernière fois. La cuisine du Tennessee incarne les traditions culinaires réconfortantes du Sud.

visits.text: Yale University - One of America's Oldest and Most Prestigious Institutions: Founded with roots dating to the 1640s, this Ivy League campus spans 200 acres featuring buildings from three different centuries. Free student-led walking tours reveal Gothic treasures like Sterling Memorial Library and the iconic Harkness Tower rising 216 feet above the historic campus.

Yale University Art Gallery - The Nation's Oldest University Art Museum: Open since 1836, this world-class institution houses over 300,000 works spanning ancient civilizations to contemporary masters, all with free admission in a stunning Louis Kahn-designed building.

Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History - Newly Renovated Wonder: After four years of extensive renovations reopening in 2024, this museum showcases extraordinary collections including the famous Age of Reptiles mural and dinosaur specimens that have educated visitors for generations.

Marsh Botanical Garden - Eight Acres of Living Laboratory: This university-managed garden features greenhouses, outdoor collections, and research facilities supporting both scientific study and public enjoyment of horticultural diversity.

activities.text: New Haven Pizza Trail - Birthplace of American Pizza Perfection: This college town claims America's finest pizza tradition, with legendary establishments perfecting thin-crust pies since the early 1900s. The famous 'white clam pie' has achieved national recognition, while multiple pizzerias have earned spots on 'best in America' lists.

Louis' Lunch - Where the Hamburger Was Born: This tiny establishment claims to have served America's first hamburger sandwich, still prepared on original vertical cast-iron grills using a century-old recipe that draws pilgrims from around the world.

Long Wharf Food Truck Paradise - Latin American Street Food Hub: A cluster of vendors along Long Wharf Drive serves authentic tacos, empanadas, Cuban plantains, and other Latin American specialties from mobile kitchens.

days_plan.itin_title: Connecticut Unveiled: Maritime Heritage, Ivy League Culture & New England's Hidden Gem
Connecticut Unveiled: Maritime Heritage, Ivy League Culture & New England's Hidden Gem
Connecticut Unveiled: Maritime Heritage, Ivy League Culture & New England's Hidden Gem

visits.text: Stroll through the enchanting brick pathways of Peddler's Village, a nationally recognized destination where 65 unique specialty shops nestle amid 42 acres of meticulously landscaped gardens. From handcrafted jewelry to artisanal foods, this year-round shopping haven transforms with the seasons, hosting beloved festivals that draw visitors from across the Eastern Seaboard.

Stand on hallowed ground at Washington Crossing Historic Park, where on a bitter Christmas night in 1776, General George Washington led 2,400 Continental soldiers across the ice-choked Delaware River to launch a surprise attack that would turn the tide of the Revolution. Explore the 500-acre park's restored 18th-century buildings and walk the same paths where desperate soldiers marched toward destiny at the Battle of Trenton.

Delight families at Sesame Place Philadelphia, the nation's only theme park entirely dedicated to Sesame Street, where beloved characters from Big Bird to Elmo come to life in immersive shows and gentle attractions. This Bucks County treasure offers water rides, parades, and magical character encounters that create lifelong memories for the youngest travelers.

days_plan.itin_title: Pennsylvania Heritage Trail - Where American History Meets Natural Splendor

visits.text: Avery Island Tabasco Factory — Tour the source of Tabasco pepper sauce produced on this salt dome island since 1868. The McIlhenny Company factory processes peppers grown on-site into the iconic sauce shipped worldwide in 195 countries.

Jungle Gardens — Wander through 67 hectares of botanical gardens featuring 900-year-old Buddha statue, bamboo groves, and lagoons. The sanctuary on Avery Island protects snowy egrets nearly hunted to extinction for their plumes in the 1890s.

Shadows-on-the-Teche — Explore this 1834 plantation home preserved by the National Trust for Historic Preservation on Bayou Teche's banks. The Classical Revival mansion retains original furnishings and documents four generations of the Weeks family.

Konriko Rice Mill — Discover how rice is processed at America's oldest operating rice mill and company museum. The 1912 facility explains Louisiana's rice industry history while demonstrating milling equipment still producing Konriko brand rice.

Usine Tabasco d'Avery Island — Visitez la source de la sauce piquante Tabasco produite sur cette île de dôme de sel depuis 1868. L'usine McIlhenny Company traite les piments cultivés sur place pour en faire la sauce iconique expédiée dans le monde entier dans 195 pays.

Jungle Gardens — Promenez-vous dans 67 hectares de jardins botaniques présentant une statue de Bouddha vieille de 900 ans, des bosquets de bambous et des lagunes. Le sanctuaire sur Avery Island protège les aigrettes neigeuses presque chassées jusqu'à l'extinction pour leurs plumes dans les années 1890.

Shadows-on-the-Teche — Explorez cette maison de plantation de 1834 préservée par le National Trust for Historic Preservation sur les rives du Bayou Teche. Le manoir de style néo-classique conserve le mobilier original et documente quatre générations de la famille Weeks.

Rizerie Konriko — Découvrez comment le riz est traité dans la plus ancienne rizerie en activité d'Amérique et son musée d'entreprise. L'installation de 1912 explique l'histoire de l'industrie rizicole de Louisiane tout en démontrant l'équipement de mouture produisant encore le riz de marque Konriko.

activities.text: Bayou Teche paddle — Kayak or canoe down Louisiana's most historic waterway winding through moss-draped cypress swamps. The scenic 201-kilometer bayou offers wildlife viewing and access to Cajun culture along its banks.

Boudin trail food tour — Sample different boudin recipes at specialist shops and gas stations along this unofficial culinary trail. Each establishment claims the best recipe for this essential Cajun sausage served hot from steamers.

New Iberia Main Street — Browse antique shops and cafes in this historic downtown preserving 19th-century commercial buildings. The compact Main Street reflects South Louisiana's French-Spanish heritage in its architecture and culture.

Pagaie sur Bayou Teche — Descendez en kayak ou canoë la voie navigable la plus historique de Louisiane serpentant à travers des marécages de cyprès drapés de mousse. Ce bayou pittoresque de 201 kilomètres offre l'observation de la faune et l'accès à la culture cajun le long de ses rives.

Circuit gastronomique du boudin trail — Goûtez différentes recettes de boudin dans des boutiques spécialisées et stations-service le long de ce circuit culinaire officieux. Chaque établissement revendique la meilleure recette pour cette saucisse cajun essentielle servie chaude dans des étuveuses.

Main Street de New Iberia — Parcourez les boutiques d'antiquités et cafés de ce centre-ville historique préservant les bâtiments commerciaux du 19ème siècle. Cette Main Street compacte reflète l'héritage franco-espagnol du sud de la Louisiane dans son architecture et sa culture.

days_plan.itin_title: LOUISIANA: NEW ORLEANS JAZZ TO CAJUN BAYOU CULTURE AND CUISINE

visits.text: French Quarter — Wander through the Vieux Carré's wrought-iron balconies, pastel Creole cottages, and hidden courtyards dating to the 1700s French colonial era. This National Historic Landmark encompasses 78 square blocks preserving America's most intact collection of 18th and 19th-century architecture.

Jackson Square — Admire the 1794 Spanish colonial plaza dominated by St. Louis Cathedral's triple spires rising since 1850. Street artists, fortune tellers, and musicians perform beneath Andrew Jackson's equestrian statue surrounded by historic Pontalba Buildings.

St. Louis Cathedral — Enter America's oldest continuously active Catholic cathedral, originally built in 1727 and rebuilt after fires in 1788 and 1794. The present structure completed in 1850 features three distinctive steeples visible across the French Quarter.

The Cabildo — Explore this Spanish colonial building where the Louisiana Purchase was signed in 1803, doubling America's size. The museum chronicles New Orleans history from Native American inhabitants through French, Spanish, and American rule.

National WWII Museum — Explore America's official World War II museum across six pavilions chronicling the American experience from Pearl Harbor to VJ Day. The Higgins boat inventor Andrew Higgins' New Orleans connection inspired the museum's 2000 founding.

Garden District — Stroll beneath live oaks draped in Spanish moss past antebellum mansions built by wealthy Americans in the 1850s. Greek Revival, Italianate, and Victorian homes line tree-shaded streets in this National Historic Landmark District.

Lafayette Cemetery No. 1 — Walk among above-ground tombs in this 1833 walled cemetery necessitated by New Orleans' high water table. The picturesque vaults and mausoleums appear in films including Interview with the Vampire and Double Jeopardy.

Audubon Park — Relax in this 140-hectare green space featuring centuries-old live oaks, lagoons, and the Audubon Zoo. The park designed by John Charles Olmsted in 1898 occupies former Étienne de Boré plantation grounds along the Mississippi River.

Barataria Preserve boardwalk — Hike 3.2 kilometers of elevated boardwalks through pristine cypress swamp and hardwood forest. The trails offer close encounters with alligators sunning on banks and turtles basking on logs.

Mardi Gras World — Tour Blaine Kern's working warehouse where massive parade floats are designed and constructed year-round. Visitors can try on costumes and see artists creating the elaborate sculptures used in New Orleans' famous carnival parades.

City Park — Explore America's fifth-largest urban park spanning 530 hectares featuring ancient live oaks over 600 years old. The park houses New Orleans Museum of Art, Botanical Garden, and the largest collection of mature live oaks worldwide.
French Quarter — Creole townhouses with wrought‑iron galleries curve along Jackson Square; St. Louis Cathedral’s triple spires preside over a 1794 basilica interior.
Preservation Hall or Frenchmen Street — Traditional jazz sets in intimate halls; arrive early for queues.
Return to New Orleans via the Atchafalaya Basin levees; optional swamp boardwalks at Barataria Preserve (Jean Lafitte NHP&Preserve).
downtown New Orleans.
Visit to Vue Orleans, panoramic platform and interactive exhibition on the city's culture.
Lunch at Peche restaurant, renowned for its local seafood.
Walk on Bourbon Street and Frenchmen Street to listen to live jazz.
Breakfast at Café du Monde, famous institution for its beignets and café au lait.
Exploration of the French Quarter: Royal Street, antique shops and art galleries.
Lunch at Commander's Palace, historic Creole restaurant.
Mississippi River cruise aboard a paddlewheel boat with jazz music.
Route Natchez → Oak Alley Plantation (via LA-10/LA-1/US-61, Mississippi riverbank)
Oak Alley Plantation — historical tour and slavery exhibitions
The Historic New Orleans Collection (heritage & archives exhibitions)
Garden District — walk among historic houses and Lafayette Cemetery (exterior view)
Arts Quarter/Warehouse District — urban walk and museums of choice
Jackson Square and Mississippi riverfront — final views
Lafayette Cemetery No.1 (exterior visit/depending on access)
New Orleans Jazz Museum (Old U.S. Mint)
Treme & Louis Armstrong Park — heritage walk
Faubourg Marigny & Frenchmen Street — galleries and music (daytime stroll)
Saint Louis Cathedral - oldest active cathedral in the United States

French Quarter — Flânez à travers les balcons en fer forgé du Vieux Carré, les cottages créoles pastel et cours cachées datant de l'ère coloniale française des années 1700. Ce monument historique national englobe 78 pâtés de maisons préservant la collection d'architecture des 18ème et 19ème siècles la plus intacte d'Amérique.

Jackson Square — Admirez la place coloniale espagnole de 1794 dominée par les trois flèches de la Cathédrale Saint-Louis qui s'élèvent depuis 1850. Des artistes de rue, diseuses de bonne aventure et musiciens se produisent sous la statue équestre d'Andrew Jackson entourée des bâtiments historiques Pontalba.

Cathédrale Saint-Louis — Entrez dans la plus ancienne cathédrale catholique continuellement active d'Amérique, construite à l'origine en 1727 et reconstruite après les incendies de 1788 et 1794. La structure actuelle achevée en 1850 présente trois clochers distinctifs visibles à travers le Quartier Français.

Le Cabildo — Explorez ce bâtiment colonial espagnol où la Vente de la Louisiane fut signée en 1803, doublant la taille de l'Amérique. Le musée retrace l'histoire de La Nouvelle-Orléans depuis les habitants amérindiens jusqu'à la domination française, espagnole et américaine.

Musée National de la Seconde Guerre Mondiale — Explorez le musée officiel américain de la Seconde Guerre mondiale à travers six pavillons retraçant l'expérience américaine de Pearl Harbor au Jour de la Victoire sur le Japon. La connexion néo-orléanaise d'Andrew Higgins, inventeur du bateau Higgins, inspira la fondation du musée en 2000.

Garden District — Promenez-vous sous les chênes verts drapés de mousse espagnole devant les demeures d'avant-guerre construites par de riches Américains dans les années 1850. Des maisons de style néo-grec, italianisant et victorien bordent les rues ombragées de ce quartier historique national.

Cimetière Lafayette No. 1 — Marchez parmi les tombes hors-sol dans ce cimetière muré de 1833 nécessité par la nappe phréatique élevée de La Nouvelle-Orléans. Les caveaux et mausolées pittoresques apparaissent dans des films incluant Entretien avec un vampire et Double Jeopardy.

Parc Audubon — Détendez-vous dans cet espace vert de 140 hectares présentant des chênes verts centenaires, des lagunes et le Zoo Audubon. Le parc conçu par John Charles Olmsted en 1898 occupe l'ancien terrain de plantation d'Étienne de Boré le long du fleuve Mississippi.

Promenade de Barataria Preserve — Randonnez sur 3,2 kilomètres de passerelles surélevées à travers un marécage de cyprès vierge et une forêt de feuillus. Les sentiers offrent des rencontres rapprochées avec des alligators se chauffant au soleil sur les berges et des tortues se prélassant sur des troncs.

Mardi Gras World — Visitez l'entrepôt de travail de Blaine Kern où d'énormes chars de parade sont conçus et construits toute l'année. Les visiteurs peuvent essayer des costumes et voir des artistes créer les sculptures élaborées utilisées dans les fameux défilés de carnaval de La Nouvelle-Orléans.

City Park — Explorez le cinquième plus grand parc urbain d'Amérique s'étendant sur 530 hectares et abritant d'anciens chênes verts de plus de 600 ans. Le parc abrite le Musée d'Art de La Nouvelle-Orléans, le Jardin Botanique, et la plus grande collection mondiale de chênes verts matures.
Quartier Français — Maisons créoles avec galeries en fer forgé s'incurvant le long de Jackson Square ; les trois flèches de la Cathédrale Saint-Louis dominent un intérieur de basilique de 1794.
Preservation Hall ou Frenchmen Street — Sets de jazz traditionnel dans des salles intimes ; arrivez tôt pour les files d'attente.
Retour à New Orleans par les levées du bassin Atchafalaya ; promenades optionnelles sur passerelles dans les marécages à Barataria Preserve (Jean Lafitte NHP&Preserve).

activities.text: Bourbon Street evening — Experience the legendary nightlife strip where neon signs illuminate jazz clubs, bars, and restaurants. Live music pours from open doorways while revelers carry go-cups along the pedestrian-friendly street.

Jazz club at Preservation Hall — Hear authentic New Orleans jazz in this intimate venue preserving traditional music since 1961. No drinks or food are served, keeping focus on world-class musicians playing nightly 90-minute sets.

Streetcar ride on St. Charles Avenue — Board the historic green streetcar operating since 1835 along America's oldest continuously operating street railway. The 21-kilometer route passes mansions, Loyola and Tulane universities, and historic neighborhoods.

Creole lunch at Commander's Palace — Dine at this 1893 Victorian mansion serving haute Creole cuisine in the Garden District. The turquoise-and-white landmark mentored Emeril Lagasse and Paul Prudhomme while maintaining tradition of 25-cent martini lunches.

Frenchmen Street music — Discover local jazz, funk, and brass bands at clubs lining this Marigny neighborhood street preferred by New Orleanians. Art vendors set up outside venues creating bohemian atmosphere less touristy than Bourbon Street.

Steamboat Natchez cruise — Board this authentic paddlewheel steamboat for a cruise on the Mississippi River featuring live jazz band and Creole buffet. The 1975 vessel recreates 19th-century riverboat elegance with calliope concerts.

Final French Quarter beignets — Return to Café du Monde for one last order of hot beignets dusted with powdered sugar. The ritual coffee and beignet break provides perfect ending to a Louisiana cultural journey.
Beignet and café au lait stop; riverfront walk on the Moonwalk.
Departure buffer; final po‑boy or gumbo stop.
Stroll through the historic streets of the French Quarter at sunset.
Tarot card reading and discovery of voodoo traditions with a local priestess on Decatur Street.
Route Oak Alley → New Orleans (I-10 East)
Live musical experience (jazz concert, historic venue)
Basketball game at Smoothie King Center (subject to schedule)
Walk on Royal Street & Chartres Street (Creole architecture)
Final views of the Mississippi at the Moonwalk near Jackson Square
Visit to the French Quarter welcome center

Bourbon Street le soir — Découvrez la légendaire artère de la vie nocturne où les enseignes au néon illuminent clubs de jazz, bars et restaurants. La musique live s'échappe des portes ouvertes tandis que les fêtards portent leurs gobelets le long de cette rue conviviale pour les piétons.

Club de jazz au Preservation Hall — Écoutez du jazz authentique de La Nouvelle-Orléans dans ce lieu intime préservant la musique traditionnelle depuis 1961. Aucune boisson ni nourriture n'est servie, gardant l'attention sur les musiciens de classe mondiale jouant des sets nocturnes de 90 minutes.

Trajet en tramway sur St. Charles Avenue — Montez à bord du tramway vert historique fonctionnant depuis 1835 le long de la plus ancienne ligne de tramway continuellement en service d'Amérique. Le parcours de 21 kilomètres passe devant des demeures, les universités Loyola et Tulane, et des quartiers historiques.

Déjeuner créole au Commander's Palace — Dînez dans ce manoir victorien de 1893 servant de la haute cuisine créole dans le Garden District. Ce monument turquoise et blanc a formé Emeril Lagasse et Paul Prudhomme tout en maintenant la tradition des déjeuners martini à 25 cents.

Musique de Frenchmen Street — Découvrez le jazz local, le funk et les fanfares dans les clubs bordant cette rue du quartier Marigny préférée des habitants de La Nouvelle-Orléans. Des vendeurs d'art s'installent devant les lieux créant une atmosphère bohème moins touristique que Bourbon Street.

Croisière Steamboat Natchez — Embarquez sur cet authentique bateau à vapeur à roues à aubes pour une croisière sur le fleuve Mississippi avec un groupe de jazz en direct et un buffet créole. Ce navire de 1975 recrée l'élégance des bateaux fluviaux du XIXe siècle avec des concerts de calliope.

Derniers beignets du French Quarter — Retournez au Café du Monde pour une dernière commande de beignets chauds saupoudrés de sucre glace. Le rituel café et beignet offre une fin parfaite à un voyage culturel en Louisiane.
Arrêt beignet et café au lait ; promenade au bord du fleuve sur le Moonwalk.
Temps tampon de départ ; dernier arrêt po‑boy ou gumbo.

days_plan.itin_title: Deep Louisiana: jazz, Creole history & expeditions in the bayous

visits.text: Statue of Liberty — Marvel at this 93-meter copper monument gifted by France in 1886, designed by Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi with internal structure by Gustave Eiffel. Lady Liberty's crown offers panoramic views of New York Harbor from 81 meters above sea level.

Ellis Island Immigration Museum — Explore the gateway through which 12 million immigrants entered America between 1892 and 1954. The Great Hall with its soaring vaulted ceiling tells poignant stories of hope, struggle, and the American Dream through interactive exhibits.

Brooklyn Bridge — Walk across this engineering marvel completed in 1883, the world's first steel-wire suspension bridge spanning 486 meters. John Roebling's Gothic Revival towers rise 84 meters above the East River, connecting Manhattan to Brooklyn.

One World Observatory — Ascend to the 100th floor of One World Trade Center, the Western Hemisphere's tallest building at 541 meters. The observation deck provides 360-degree views from the memorial pools to the Statue of Liberty.

Letchworth State Park — Marvel at the Grand Canyon of the East where the Genesee River plunges through a 183-meter-deep gorge. Three major waterfalls cascade over ancient rock layers while the gorge walls reveal 340 million years of sedimentary history.

Corning Museum of Glass — Discover 3,500 years of glass artistry in this world-class museum housing 50,000 objects. Live hot-glass demonstrations reveal the magic of glassblowing while contemporary galleries showcase works by Dale Chihuly and other masters.

Watkins Glen State Park — Hike the Gorge Trail ascending 122 meters through 19 waterfalls carved into dramatic rock formations. The 2.4-kilometer trail winds through tunnels behind cascades and past rainbow-misted pools in the narrow glen.

Statue de la Liberté — Admirez ce monument de cuivre de 93 mètres offert par la France en 1886, conçu par Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi avec une structure interne de Gustave Eiffel. La couronne de Lady Liberty offre des vues panoramiques du port de New York depuis 81 mètres au-dessus du niveau de la mer.

Musée de l'Immigration d'Ellis Island — Explorez la porte d'entrée par laquelle 12 millions d'immigrants sont entrés en Amérique entre 1892 et 1954. Le Great Hall avec son plafond voûté élancé raconte des histoires poignantes d'espoir, de lutte et du Rêve Américain à travers des expositions interactives.

Pont de Brooklyn — Traversez à pied cette merveille d'ingénierie achevée en 1883, le premier pont suspendu à câbles d'acier au monde s'étendant sur 486 mètres. Les tours de style néo-gothique de John Roebling s'élèvent à 84 mètres au-dessus de l'East River, reliant Manhattan à Brooklyn.

One World Observatory — Montez au 100e étage du One World Trade Center, le plus haut bâtiment de l'hémisphère occidental avec 541 mètres. Le pont d'observation offre des vues à 360 degrés des bassins commémoratifs à la Statue de la Liberté.

Parc d'État de Letchworth — Émerveillez-vous devant le Grand Canyon de l'Est où la rivière Genesee plonge dans une gorge profonde de 183 mètres. Trois cascades majeures dégringolent sur d'anciennes couches rocheuses tandis que les parois de la gorge révèlent 340 millions d'années d'histoire sédimentaire.

Musée du verre de Corning — Découvrez 3 500 ans d'art verrier dans ce musée de classe mondiale abritant 50 000 objets. Des démonstrations de verre chaud en direct révèlent la magie du soufflage de verre tandis que les galeries contemporaines présentent des œuvres de Dale Chihuly et d'autres maîtres.

Parc d'État de Watkins Glen — Randonnez sur le sentier de la gorge s'élevant de 122 mètres à travers 19 cascades sculptées dans des formations rocheuses spectaculaires. Le sentier de 2,4 kilomètres serpente à travers des tunnels derrière les cascades et past des bassins brumeux arc-en-ciel dans la gorge étroite.

activities.text: Times Square evening stroll — Immerse yourself in the neon-lit spectacle of the Crossroads of the World where 300,000 pedestrians pass daily. Giant LED billboards illuminate Broadway theaters, flagship stores, and street performers creating electric energy until midnight.

Slice at Joe's Pizza — Savor a classic New York slice at this Greenwich Village institution serving since 1975. The thin-crust, coal-oven pizza folded in half represents authentic NYC street food culture at its finest.

Central Park sunset walk — Stroll through Frederick Law Olmsted's 341-hectare masterpiece completed in 1876. The Bethesda Terrace and Bow Bridge offer romantic views as the setting sun casts golden light across the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Reservoir.

Scenic drive through Finger Lakes — Cruise along the shores of Seneca and Cayuga Lakes where vineyard-covered hillsides descend to crystalline waters. Stop at overlooks revealing the long, narrow lakes carved by glaciers over 2 million years.

Farm-to-table dinner — Savor seasonal cuisine prepared with ingredients from surrounding farms and orchards. Regional restaurants showcase New York wines paired with grass-fed beef, artisan cheeses, and heirloom vegetables.

Promenade nocturne à Times Square — Plongez-vous dans le spectacle aux néons du Carrefour du Monde où 300 000 piétons passent quotidiennement. Les panneaux publicitaires LED géants illuminent les théâtres de Broadway, les magasins phares et les artistes de rue créant une énergie électrique jusqu'à minuit.

Part chez Joe's Pizza — Savourez une part new-yorkaise classique dans cette institution de Greenwich Village qui sert depuis 1975. La pizza à pâte fine cuite au four à charbon et pliée en deux représente la culture culinaire de rue authentique de NYC dans toute sa splendeur.

Promenade au coucher de soleil dans Central Park — Flânez dans le chef-d'œuvre de 341 hectares de Frederick Law Olmsted achevé en 1876. La Bethesda Terrace et le Bow Bridge offrent des vues romantiques tandis que le soleil couchant projette une lumière dorée sur le réservoir Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.

Route panoramique à travers les lacs Finger — Roulez le long des rives des lacs Seneca et Cayuga où des collines couvertes de vignobles descendent vers des eaux cristallines. Arrêtez-vous aux belvédères révélant les lacs longs et étroits sculptés par les glaciers il y a plus de 2 millions d'années.

Dîner de la ferme à la table — Savourez une cuisine saisonnière préparée avec des ingrédients provenant des fermes et vergers environnants. Les restaurants régionaux mettent en valeur les vins de New York accompagnés de bœuf nourri à l'herbe, de fromages artisanaux et de légumes anciens.

days_plan.itin_title: NEW YORK: FROM MANHATTAN'S SKYSCRAPERS TO NIAGARA FALLS MAJESTY
NEW YORK: FROM MANHATTAN'S SKYSCRAPERS TO NIAGARA FALLS MAJESTY

visits.text: Three Capes Scenic Route — Navigate this 64-kilometer coastal loop featuring Cape Meares, Cape Lookout, and Cape Kiwanda. Dramatic headlands, sea stacks, and old-growth Sitka spruce forests create one of Oregon's most scenic drives.

Oregon Coast Aquarium — Discover Pacific Northwest marine life in exhibits featuring sea otters, seals, sharks, and jellyfish. The Newport aquarium played a crucial role in rehabilitating Keiko, the orca from Free Willy.

Yaquina Head Outstanding Natural Area — Climb Oregon's tallest lighthouse standing 28 meters and visit tide pools at Cobble Beach. The basalt headland jutting into the Pacific offers seal and whale watching opportunities.

Historic Bayfront — Explore Newport's working waterfront featuring seafood markets, restaurants, and sea lion docks. The fishing fleet and marine science facilities maintain the harbor's maritime character since the 1860s.

Route panoramique des Three Capes — Parcourez cette boucle côtière de 64 kilomètres comprenant Cape Meares, Cape Lookout et Cape Kiwanda. Des promontoires spectaculaires, des aiguilles rocheuses et des forêts d'épicéas de Sitka centenaires créent l'une des routes les plus pittoresques de l'Oregon.

Oregon Coast Aquarium — Découvrez la vie marine du Pacifique Nord-Ouest dans des expositions présentant des loutres de mer, des phoques, des requins et des méduses. L'aquarium de Newport a joué un rôle crucial dans la réhabilitation de Keiko, l'orque de Sauvez Willy.

Yaquina Head Outstanding Natural Area — Grimpez au plus haut phare de l'Oregon s'élevant à 28 mètres et visitez les bassins de marée à Cobble Beach. Le promontoire basaltique s'avançant dans le Pacifique offre des opportunités d'observation des phoques et des baleines.

Bayfront historique — Explorez le front de mer actif de Newport avec ses marchés aux fruits de mer, restaurants et quais aux otaries. La flotte de pêche et les installations de sciences marines maintiennent le caractère maritime du port depuis les années 1860.

Oregon Caves National Monument — Explore this marble cave system formed by acidic water dissolving limestone over millions of years. Guided tours wind through passages featuring stalactites, flowstone, and the Ghost Room chamber.

Cannon Beach — Walk the wide sandy beach dominated by 72-meter Haystack Rock, the third-tallest sea stack in the world. The iconic monolith hosts nesting tufted puffins from April to July and tide pools teeming with marine life.

Ecola State Park — Hike coastal trails offering dramatic Pacific Ocean vistas from forested headlands. The park preserves the site where Lewis and Clark expedition members obtained whale blubber from local tribes in 1806.

Seaside Promenade — Stroll this 2.4-kilometer boardwalk along Seaside's beach where Lewis and Clark boiled seawater to make salt during winter 1806. The turnaround monument marks the expedition's westernmost point.

activities.text: Whale watching — Spot gray whales migrating along the Oregon coast from December through May, with resident whales visible year-round. The headlands offer prime viewing as 20,000 whales pass during spring migration.
Sea lion observation — Watch Steller sea lions hauling out on docks beneath the Yaquina Bay Bridge. Hundreds of these massive marine mammals gather year-round, barking and jostling for space.
Clam chowder tasting — Sample Oregon's famous seafood at Bayfront restaurants serving award-winning chowder made with fresh local clams. Many establishments claim the best chowder on the coast.

Observation des baleines — Repérez les baleines grises migrant le long de la côte de l'Oregon de décembre à mai, avec des baleines résidentes visibles toute l'année. Les promontoires offrent une vue privilégiée alors que 20 000 baleines passent pendant la migration printanière.

Observation des otaries — Observez les otaries de Steller se reposant sur les quais sous le pont Yaquina Bay. Des centaines de ces mammifères marins massifs se rassemblent toute l'année, aboyant et se bousculant pour l'espace.

Dégustation de chaudrée de palourdes — Goûtez les célèbres fruits de mer de l'Oregon dans les restaurants du Bayfront servant une chaudrée primée préparée avec des palourdes locales fraîches. Beaucoup d'établissements revendiquent la meilleure chaudrée de la côte.
Tide pool exploration — Examine sea stars, anemones, hermit crabs, and sea urchins in rocky pools at low tide. Haystack Rock's base reveals diverse intertidal ecosystems during minus tides.

Gallery browsing in Cannon Beach — Explore art galleries showcasing Pacific Northwest landscape paintings, glasswork, and sculptures. The artistic community attracts visitors to boutique shops and studios.
Fresh seafood dinner — Dine on Dungeness crab, Pacific oysters, and salmon at oceanfront restaurants. Cannon Beach restaurants emphasize locally caught seafood with sunset ocean views.

days_plan.itin_title: OREGON: CRATER LAKE SAPPHIRE WATERS TO RUGGED PACIFIC COAST
OREGON : DES EAUX SAPHIR DE CRATER LAKE À LA CÔTE PACIFIQUE SAUVAGE

visits.text: Step into the unimaginable opulence of America's Gilded Age at The Breakers, the crown jewel of Newport's legendary mansion district. This 70-room Italian Renaissance palazzo, built for Cornelius Vanderbilt II between 1893 and 1895, dazzles visitors with gold-leaf ceilings soaring to impossible heights, rare marbles imported from around the world, and diamond-encrusted chandeliers that once illuminated the most lavish parties in American history. Inspired by the palaces of Genoa and Turin, every room reveals the extraordinary craftsmanship and limitless wealth that defined America's most powerful dynasty.

Marvel at the architectural excess of Marble House, where an astonishing 500,000 cubic feet of marble create one of Newport's most refined Gilded Age estates. Commissioned by William Kissam Vanderbilt as a 39th birthday present for his wife Alva, this Beaux-Arts masterpiece draws inspiration from the Petit Trianon at Versailles, featuring a Gothic Room adorned with medieval motifs and a Chinese Tea House on the grounds where the Vanderbilts hosted elaborate garden parties.

Traverse the legendary 3.5-mile Cliff Walk, a National Recreation Trail that traces Newport's dramatic coastline while offering intimate glimpses of the city's most celebrated summer 'cottages.' This unique public walkway, designated a National Historic District, threads between crashing Atlantic waves and the manicured grounds of Gilded Age estates, revealing architectural marvels at every turn. The southern sections challenge adventurous hikers with rocky terrain, while the northern stretch provides accessible paved pathways.

activities.text: Cruise the magnificent Ocean Drive, a 10-mile scenic loop that showcases Newport's stunning Atlantic coastline, historic landmarks, and the summer retreats of America's elite. This legendary route winds past the Kennedy compound, dramatic rocky headlands, and pristine beaches, offering countless opportunities to pull over and photograph the breathtaking seascapes that have inspired artists and captivated visitors for generations.

days_plan.itin_title: Rhode Island's Gilded Shores & Colonial Treasures - America's Smallest State, Grandest Discoveries

visits.text: Niagara Falls State Park — Witness 750,000 gallons of water per second plunging 51 meters over the American Falls and Bridal Veil Falls. America's oldest state park, established in 1885, offers multiple viewing platforms along the Niagara Gorge rim.

Cave of the Winds — Descend 53 meters into the Niagara Gorge to stand within 6 meters of Bridal Veil Falls on the Hurricane Deck. Waterproof ponchos barely protect against the thundering spray and wind gusts reaching 110 km/h.

Maid of the Mist — Board this iconic boat tour operating since 1846 for a close encounter with Horseshoe Falls. The 20-minute voyage navigates the turbulent basin where 3,160 tons of water crash down every second.

Niagara Power Vista — Learn how the falls generate 4.4 million kilowatts of hydroelectric power at this interactive museum overlooking the Robert Moses Power Plant. Exhibits explain how diversion tunnels harness the river's energy while maintaining the falls' flow.

Parc d'État des chutes du Niagara — Observez 750 000 gallons d'eau par seconde plongeant de 51 mètres par-dessus les American Falls et les Bridal Veil Falls. Le plus ancien parc d'État d'Amérique, établi en 1885, offre plusieurs plateformes d'observation le long du bord des gorges du Niagara.

Cave of the Winds — Descendez 53 mètres dans les gorges du Niagara pour vous tenir à 6 mètres des Bridal Veil Falls sur le Hurricane Deck. Les ponchos imperméables protègent à peine contre les embruns tonnants et les rafales de vent atteignant 110 km/h.

Maid of the Mist — Embarquez sur cette excursion en bateau emblématique fonctionnant depuis 1846 pour une rencontre rapprochée avec les chutes Horseshoe. Le voyage de 20 minutes navigue dans le bassin turbulent où 3 160 tonnes d'eau s'écrasent chaque seconde.

Niagara Power Vista — Découvrez comment les chutes génèrent 4,4 millions de kilowatts d'énergie hydroélectrique dans ce musée interactif surplombant la centrale électrique Robert Moses. Les expositions expliquent comment les tunnels de dérivation exploitent l'énergie de la rivière tout en maintenant le débit des chutes.

activities.text: Niagara Gorge hiking — Trek the challenging trails descending into the 91-meter-deep gorge carved by 12,000 years of erosion. The Gorge Trail follows the Niagara River's whitewater rapids past giant boulders and exposed rock layers.

Evening illumination viewing — Watch as 3 billion candlepower of LED lights transform the falls into a rainbow spectacle after sunset. The illumination tradition began in 1860 with primitive searchlights and continues nightly year-round.

Wine tasting on Niagara Wine Trail — Sample ice wines and cold-climate varietals at boutique wineries in the Niagara Escarpment appellation. The moderating lake effect and limestone soils produce exceptional Rieslings and Cabernet Francs.

Randonnée dans les gorges du Niagara — Parcourez les sentiers difficiles descendant dans les gorges profondes de 91 mètres creusées par 12 000 ans d'érosion. Le Gorge Trail suit les rapides d'eau vive de la rivière Niagara passant devant des rochers géants et des couches rocheuses exposées.

Observation de l'illumination nocturne — Regardez comment 3 milliards de candelas de lumières LED transforment les chutes en spectacle arc-en-ciel après le coucher du soleil. La tradition d'illumination a commencé en 1860 avec des projecteurs primitifs et continue chaque nuit toute l'année.

Dégustation de vins sur le Niagara Wine Trail — Dégustez des vins de glace et des cépages de climat froid dans les vignobles boutique de l'appellation Niagara Escarpment. L'effet modérateur du lac et les sols calcaires produisent des Rieslings et des Cabernet Francs exceptionnels.

visits.text: Uncover one of WWII's best-kept secrets at the Manhattan Project National Historical Park in Oak Ridge, where an entire city was built virtually overnight to develop the atomic bomb. This 'Secret City' employed 75,000 workers who had no idea what they were creating, and today's visitors can tour preserved facilities including the K-25 site where uranium was enriched, learning the profound human stories behind this unprecedented scientific achievement.

visits.text: Oakland - San Francisco's Cooler, Edgier Sibling: This diverse city across the bay has emerged as a cultural powerhouse, with thriving arts scenes, innovative cuisine, and proud communities that celebrate authenticity over pretension.

Oakland Museum of California (OMCA) - The State's Story Under One Roof: This unique institution weaves together California's art, history, and natural sciences through immersive galleries and rotating exhibitions exploring the Golden State's identity.

Lake Merritt - America's First Official Wildlife Refuge: This tidal lagoon in the heart of downtown Oakland, designated in 1870, provides sanctuary for migrating birds while offering residents jogging paths, gardens, and waterfront relaxation.

activities.text: Children's Fairyland - Where Storybooks Come to Life: This beloved theme park, opened in 1950, inspired Walt Disney to create Disneyland. Whimsical sets bring fairy tales and nursery rhymes to three-dimensional life for young visitors.

days_plan.itin_title: California Unveiled: From Ancient Redwoods to Desert Wonders - The Ultimate Golden State Odyssey
California Unveiled: From Ancient Redwoods to Desert Wonders - The Ultimate Golden State Odyssey

visits.text: Northwest Kansas Rock Formations - Kansas's Best-Kept Natural Secrets: For decades, travelers sped past these otherworldly geological treasures, but today these Niobrara chalk formations rank among Kansas's most remarkable attractions.

Little Jerusalem Badlands State Park - A Mile-Long City of Stone: Tucked in a valley between Scott City and Oakley, this state's largest Niobrara chalk formation features 100-foot-tall rock faces and pillars. A scenic rim trail circles the towering formations that earned the park its biblical name.

Monument Rocks - 70-Foot Chalk Pillars Rising from the Prairie: The surrounding sprawl of shortgrass prairie makes these Niobrara chalk pillars and natural arches appear even more dramatic, geological sentinels standing watch over the Kansas plains.

Arikaree Breaks - 30 Miles of Yucca-Studded Canyonlands: In the far northwestern reaches of Kansas, these spectacular gullies and bluffs sprawl across the landscape, with Lookout Point providing the best vantage over this unexpected terrain.

activities.text: Chalk Pyramids Trail - Walk Among Ancient Seabed Remnants: These 80-million-year-old formations were deposited when an inland sea covered Kansas, leaving behind the shells and skeletons of marine creatures compressed into chalk.

days_plan.itin_title: Kansas Unveiled: From Tallgrass Prairies to Space Exploration - Discovering America's Heartland
Kansas Unveiled: From Tallgrass Prairies to Space Exploration - Discovering America's Heartland

visits.text: Rainbow Springs State Park - Florida's Fourth Largest Spring: Crystal-clear water in impossible shades of blue and green flows from one of Florida's most beautiful spring heads. The spring-fed Rainbow River maintains a constant cool temperature year-round.

Rainbow River Tubing - Float Through Paradise: Drift downstream on the crystal-clear, spring-fed river, passing beneath canopies of live oaks while fish swim visibly in the sandy bottom below your tube.

activities.text: Paddling the Rainbow River - Kayak Through Living Color: The remarkable clarity of this spring-fed waterway reveals an underwater world of fish, turtles, and aquatic plants that make every paddle stroke a discovery.

days_plan.itin_title: Florida Unveiled: From Pristine Barrier Islands to Tropical Keys - The Ultimate Sunshine State Adventure

visits.text: Enter the Okefenokee Swamp, a 438,000-acre wilderness where glassy blackwater channels wind through ancient cypress and tupelo forests draped in Spanish moss. This vast wetland, one of the largest intact freshwater ecosystems in North America, supports over 600 species including American alligators, river otters, and countless wading birds. The mysterious, primordial atmosphere creates a hauntingly beautiful landscape unlike anywhere else in the country.

Walk the elevated Chesser Island Boardwalk to an observation tower providing panoramic views across endless prairies of floating peat islands and wildlife-rich marshlands. The preserved homestead reveals how hardy pioneers once scratched out existence in this watery wilderness. The visitor center explains the swamp's unique ecology and cultural history.

activities.text: Glide through mirror-calm waters on guided boat tours where experienced naturalists point out alligators basking on logs, herons stalking fish, and turtles sunning on cypress knees. The earthy, mossy scent of the wetlands and calls of countless birds create a sensory immersion in one of America's last great wild places.
