visits.text: Blue Spring State Park - Summer Swimming, Winter Manatee Watching: This remarkable spring offers completely different experiences by season. Summer visitors swim in the constant 72-degree water, while winter brings hundreds of manatees seeking warmth as ocean temperatures drop.

Manatee Viewing Boardwalks - Gentle Giants by the Hundreds: Elevated walkways provide extraordinary views of Florida's beloved marine mammals, with peak season (November-March) bringing the largest congregations anywhere in the state.

activities.text: Spring Head Diving Competition - Local Kids at Play: Watch (or join) as children compete to see who can free dive deepest into the spring's blue depths, a time-honored tradition at this beloved swimming hole.

days_plan.itin_title: Florida Unveiled: From Pristine Barrier Islands to Tropical Keys - The Ultimate Sunshine State Adventure

visits.text: PEZ Visitor Center - 4,000 Square Feet of Candy Nostalgia: Explore the colorful history of the iconic candy brand, first created in 1927 and now producing around 5 billion sweet treats annually. The self-guided tour reveals a product packaging line, the world's largest PEZ dispenser, and an extensive collection of themed dispensers spanning decades of pop culture.

activities.text: Interactive PEZ Experience - Sweet Fun for All Ages: Engage with games throughout the facility, browse the extensive gift shop, and learn how this Austrian-born candy conquered American hearts. The convenient highway location makes it a perfect road trip stop.

days_plan.itin_title: Connecticut Unveiled: Maritime Heritage, Ivy League Culture & New England's Hidden Gem
Connecticut Unveiled: Maritime Heritage, Ivy League Culture & New England's Hidden Gem

visits.text: Kennedy Space Center — Explore NASA's launch headquarters featuring the Space Shuttle Atlantis, Saturn V rocket, and Mission Control. Interactive exhibits chronicle space exploration history while viewing platforms overlook active launch pads on Cape Canaveral.

Rocket Garden — Walk among actual Mercury, Gemini, and Apollo rockets standing vertically as they did before launch. These historic spacecraft carried America's first astronauts into orbit during the 1960s space race.

Astronaut Encounter — Meet veteran astronauts who share firsthand accounts of living and working in space. Q&A sessions offer unique insights into spacewalks, zero gravity, and life aboard the International Space Station.

Walt Disney World Resort - The Most Magical Place on Earth: Four distinct theme parks-Magic Kingdom, EPCOT, Hollywood Studios, and Animal Kingdom-spread across 25,000 acres, making this the world's most-visited vacation resort. Magic Kingdom's iconic Cinderella Castle anchors an experience that has defined family entertainment for over 50 years.

Universal Orlando Resort - Where Movies Come to Life: The Wizarding World of Harry Potter, spread across two parks connected by the Hogwarts Express, offers complete immersion into J.K. Rowling's magical universe. Beyond Potter, attractions based on Transformers, Jurassic World, and The Simpsons thrill visitors of all ages.
SeaWorld Orlando - Marine Life Meets Thrilling Rides: This hybrid theme park combines world-class aquariums and animal encounters with some of Florida's most exhilarating roller coasters.
LEGOLAND Florida - Built for Kids 2-12: Located in nearby Winter Haven, this theme park designed specifically for younger children features over 50 rides, shows, and building experiences.

Kennedy Space Center — Explorez le quartier général de lancement de la NASA avec la navette spatiale Atlantis, la fusée Saturn V et le Centre de contrôle de mission. Des expositions interactives retracent l'histoire de l'exploration spatiale tandis que des plateformes d'observation surplombent les rampes de lancement actives de Cap Canaveral.

Rocket Garden — Promenez-vous parmi de vraies fusées Mercury, Gemini et Apollo dressées verticalement comme elles l'étaient avant le lancement. Ces vaisseaux spatiaux historiques ont transporté les premiers astronautes américains en orbite durant la course à l'espace des années 1960.

Astronaut Encounter — Rencontrez des astronautes vétérans qui partagent leurs récits de première main sur la vie et le travail dans l'espace. Les sessions de questions-réponses offrent des perspectives uniques sur les sorties extravéhiculaires, l'apesanteur et la vie à bord de la Station spatiale internationale.

activities.text: Lunch with an Astronaut — Dine alongside space veterans who recount their missions over a meal. This exclusive experience provides unprecedented access to NASA's heroes in an intimate setting.

Cocoa Beach surfing — Try surfing on this 10-kilometer beach where eleven-time world champion Kelly Slater learned to ride waves. Consistent Atlantic swells and warm waters create ideal conditions for beginners and experts alike.

International Drive evening — Browse outlet malls, entertainment complexes, and restaurants along Orlando's tourism corridor. The 18-kilometer strip offers family entertainment from observation wheels to wax museums.

International Drive - Orlando Beyond the Parks: This 11-mile corridor of attractions includes the Orlando Eye observation wheel, Madame Tussauds, SEA LIFE Aquarium, and countless dining and entertainment options.

Orlando's Diverse Dining Scene - A Global Culinary Journey: The city's melting pot population has created authentic international cuisines from Vietnamese to Puerto Rican, all outside the theme park gates.

Lunch with an Astronaut — Dînez aux côtés de vétérans de l'espace qui racontent leurs missions au cours d'un repas. Cette expérience exclusive offre un accès sans précédent aux héros de la NASA dans un cadre intime.

Surf à Cocoa Beach — Essayez le surf sur cette plage de 10 kilomètres où le champion du monde onze fois Kelly Slater a appris à surfer les vagues. Des houles atlantiques constantes et des eaux chaudes créent des conditions idéales pour les débutants comme pour les experts.

Soirée sur International Drive — Parcourez les centres commerciaux, complexes de divertissement et restaurants le long du corridor touristique d'Orlando. Cette bande de 18 kilomètres offre des divertissements familiaux allant des grandes roues aux musées de cire.

days_plan.itin_title: FLORIDA: EVERGLADES WILDERNESS TO ART DECO MIAMI GLAMOUR
Florida Unveiled: From Pristine Barrier Islands to Tropical Keys - The Ultimate Sunshine State Adventure

visits.text: Discover Padre Island National Seashore, the longest undeveloped barrier island in the world, stretching over 70 miles along the Gulf of Mexico with pristine beaches untouched by commercial development. The protected coastline provides critical nesting habitat for endangered Kemp's ridley sea turtles, with public releases of hatchlings creating unforgettable wildlife encounters during nesting season. The island's wild, windswept beauty offers a serene escape into coastal wilderness.

Explore the diverse ecosystems where Gulf waters meet coastal dunes, grasslands, and tidal flats supporting remarkable biodiversity. The Malaquite Visitor Center provides orientation to the park's natural and cultural history, including the shipwrecks that dot the treacherous coastline. Designated sections allow four-wheel-drive vehicle access to remote beach areas far from crowds.

activities.text: Experience world-class bird watching opportunities, as Padre Island lies along the Central Flyway migration route, attracting hundreds of species throughout the year including rare shorebirds and raptors. Fishing enthusiasts can cast into the surf for redfish, speckled trout, and other Gulf species along miles of accessible shoreline. Swimming, beachcombing, and camping under starlit skies provide classic coastal recreation in an unspoiled natural setting.

visits.text: Drive inland via I‑10; wind farms and Coachella Valley Preserve stop.
Palm Springs Aerial Tramway et visite de l'architecture du milieu du siècle.

Palm Springs - Midcentury Modern Paradise in the Desert: This Sonoran Desert oasis has attracted Hollywood celebrities since the 1930s, its clean-lined architecture and year-round sunshine creating an aesthetic preserved in over 800 documented modernist buildings.

Palm Springs Aerial Tramway - 10 Minutes from Desert Floor to Alpine Forest: The world's largest rotating tramcars climb nearly 6,000 vertical feet to Mount San Jacinto State Park, where temperatures drop 40 degrees and pine forests replace palms.

Palm Springs Art Museum - World-Class in the Desert: This respected institution houses significant collections of modern and contemporary art, Native American artifacts, and glass sculpture, with a satellite architecture museum downtown.
Conduire vers l'intérieur via I-10 ; arrêt aux fermes éoliennes et Coachella Valley Preserve.
Joshua Tree NP — Hidden Valley, Skull Rock, and Cholla Cactus Garden.
Sunrise from Keys View, then return via Yucca Valley arts corridor.

days_plan.itin_title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA COAST & DESERTS — CHANNEL ISLANDS & JOSHUA TREE
SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA COAST & DESERTS — CHANNEL ISLANDS & JOSHUA TREE
California Unveiled: From Ancient Redwoods to Desert Wonders - The Ultimate Golden State Odyssey
CÔTE ET DÉSERTS DE CALIFORNIE DU SUD — CHANNEL ISLANDS ET JOSHUA TREE

activities.text: Midcentury Modern Architecture Tours - The World's Finest Concentration: Preservation groups offer tours of homes designed by legends like Richard Neutra, Albert Frey, and Donald Wexler, many still privately owned but viewable from the street.

Joshua Tree National Park - Where Two Deserts Collide: Just an hour away, this otherworldly landscape of twisted Joshua trees and jumbled boulder piles spans both the Mojave and Colorado deserts, offering world-class rock climbing and surreal photography opportunities.

visits.text: Marvel at Palo Duro Canyon State Park, known as the Grand Canyon of Texas, featuring dramatic landscapes of colorful rock formations, steep mesa walls, and extensive hiking trails stretching over 120 miles long and up to 20 miles wide. The canyon's geological formations display a vivid palette of red, orange, and white hues that become especially stunning at sunrise and sunset. As the nation's second-largest canyon, this natural wonder offers breathtaking vistas at every turn.

Hike the Lighthouse Trail to reach the park's iconic Lighthouse Peak, a towering hoodoo formation that has become the symbol of Palo Duro Canyon. The moderate trail winds through varied terrain showcasing millions of years of geological history carved by the Prairie Dog Town Fork of the Red River. The panoramic views from this landmark reward hikers with some of the most spectacular scenery in all of Texas.

activities.text: Explore the CCC Trail, which provides insights into the remarkable work of the Civilian Conservation Corps during the 1930s, who built much of the park's infrastructure during the Great Depression. Wildlife enthusiasts can observe the Texas state bison herd that has been reintroduced to the park, along with diverse bird species and other native animals. The Pioneer Amphitheater within the park hosts concerts, theatrical performances, and special events throughout the season.

days_plan.itin_title: Texas Discovery: From Vibrant Cities to Desert Wilderness

visits.text: Explore Brookgreen Gardens, where lush pathways wind past one of the finest outdoor sculpture collections in America displayed beneath towering oaks draped in Spanish moss. The gardens blend nature and artistry seamlessly, with hundreds of works ranging from classical to contemporary pieces positioned among reflective pools and manicured lawns. This former rice plantation now serves as a sanctuary of beauty and culture.

Wander through the extensive botanical gardens featuring seasonal blooms, themed garden rooms, and hidden corners perfect for quiet contemplation. The Lowcountry Zoo showcases native wildlife in naturalistic settings, providing insight into regional ecosystems. Brookgreen's combination of art, nature, and history creates hours of peaceful, inspiring exploration.

activities.text: Discover the sculpture garden's shaded paths where art and nature interweave in constantly surprising ways. Each season brings different blooms and shifting light that transform the artistic experience. The gardens' commitment to preserving Lowcountry culture and environment makes this destination both beautiful and meaningful.

days_plan.itin_title: South Carolina Grand Tour: Coastal Elegance to Mountain Serenity

visits.text: Step back nearly 1,000 years at Pecos National Historical Park, where substantial ruins of Pecos Pueblo and a Spanish colonial mission church reveal centuries of cultural interaction and conflict in the American Southwest. The park preserves one of the largest and most important archaeological sites in the region, where the Pecos people built a thriving trade center connecting Plains and Pueblo cultures.

Walk among the massive adobe walls and reconstructed kiva structures that once housed a population of over 2,000 people at the height of Pueblo civilization. The adjacent mission ruins demonstrate Spanish colonial efforts to convert indigenous peoples, creating a layered historical landscape of profound significance for understanding the region's complex heritage.

activities.text: Explore the park's trails connecting archaeological sites with natural landscapes that supported human habitation for thousands of years. Interpretive exhibits explain the daily lives, spiritual practices, and eventual abandonment of this once-great pueblo, whose descendants now live among the Jemez Pueblo people.

visits.text: Petit Jean State Park - Arkansas's First and Most Beloved State Park: Perched atop a flat-topped mountain bearing the name of a legendary French explorer's disguised lover, this park offers 95-foot Cedar Falls plunging into a misty canyon, ancient Native American rock shelters, and Seven Hollows Trail winding through otherworldly geological formations.

Cedar Falls - The Crown Jewel Cascade: Descend into Cedar Creek Canyon to witness water plummeting nearly 100 feet into an emerald pool surrounded by towering bluffs. The 2-mile round-trip hike rewards adventurers with one of Arkansas's most photographed natural wonders.

Rock House Cave & Native American Bluff Shelters - Windows into Ancient Arkansas: Explore shallow caves where indigenous peoples sought shelter thousands of years ago, their presence still visible in mysterious petroglyphs etched into stone walls.

activities.text: Seven Hollows Trail - Journey Through a Wonderland of Stone: This 4.4-mile loop traverses seven distinct geological formations, from slot canyons to natural bridges, through a primeval landscape that feels untouched by time.

Arkansas Unveiled: Mountains, Diamonds & Healing Waters of the Natural State

visits.text: Drive up Delaware Bay to Philadelphia; Independence National Historical Park highlights and Old City cobbles.
Schuylkill River Trail morning walk; departure buffer.

Step back to where democracy took its first breath at Independence National Historical Park, the sacred ground where fifty-six courageous men signed the Declaration of Independence in 1776. Walk through the hallowed Assembly Room of Independence Hall, a UNESCO World Heritage Site where the Constitution was debated and ratified, forever changing the course of human history. Stand before the iconic Liberty Bell with its famous crack, a universal symbol of freedom that once rang to summon citizens for the first public reading of the Declaration.

Ascend the legendary steps immortalized by Rocky Balboa and enter one of America's largest art museums, the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Housing over 240,000 objects spanning 2,000 years of creative expression, from medieval armor to Impressionist masterpieces, every gallery tells a story of human achievement. Don't miss the reconstructed medieval cloister and the stunning collection of American decorative arts that chronicle the nation's artistic evolution.

Discover the legacy of America's most versatile founding father at the Benjamin Franklin Museum, where interactive exhibits bring to life the printer, inventor, diplomat, and philosopher who helped shape a nation. Explore his groundbreaking experiments with electricity, his ingenious inventions like the lightning rod and bifocals, and his pivotal role in securing French support for American independence.
Conduire vers le nord de Delaware Bay jusqu'à Philadelphie ; points forts de l'Independence National Historical Park et pavés de Old City.
Promenade matinale sur le Schuylkill River Trail ; marge pour le départ.

visits.text: Dollywood — Experience Dolly Parton's theme park celebrating Appalachian culture with rides, shows, and craft demonstrations. The 60-hectare park features world-class roller coasters, traditional music, and Southern food opened in 1986.

Roaring Fork Motor Nature Trail — Drive this 9-kilometer one-way loop through old-growth forest past log cabins and mill. The narrow gravel road follows mountain streams with opportunities for short hikes to waterfalls.
Grotto Falls — Hike 4.3 kilometers roundtrip to the only waterfall in the park allowing walking behind the 8-meter cascade. The trail passes through rhododendron thickets and hemlock forests.

Dive into marine wonders at Ripley's Aquarium of the Smokies in Gatlinburg, where a 340-foot underwater tunnel transports visitors through a Caribbean reef teeming with sharks, sea turtles, and tropical fish. Interactive touch tanks, penguin encounters, and one of America's largest collections of exotic sea life make this a must-see attraction for families exploring the Smokies.

Experience pure Appalachian joy at Dollywood, the unique theme park co-owned by Dolly Parton that celebrates the culture, crafts, and music of the Smoky Mountains. Beyond the thrilling coasters-including the award-winning Lightning Rod and Wild Eagle-guests discover traditional craftspeople demonstrating time-honored skills, world-class entertainment, and Southern cuisine that would make any grandmother proud. A vintage steam train carries passengers on a 5-mile journey through the mountains.

Explore the world's largest Titanic museum attraction in Pigeon Forge, where a half-scale replica of the legendary ocean liner houses over 400 artifacts recovered from the actual wreck. Interactive galleries let visitors touch a real iceberg, walk recreated grand staircases, and learn the personal stories of passengers and crew through the most comprehensive collection of Titanic memorabilia ever assembled.

Dollywood — Découvrez le parc à thème de Dolly Parton célébrant la culture des Appalaches avec des manèges, des spectacles et des démonstrations d'artisanat. Ce parc de 60 hectares propose des montagnes russes de classe mondiale, de la musique traditionnelle et de la cuisine du Sud, ouvert en 1986.

Roaring Fork Motor Nature Trail — Parcourez cette boucle à sens unique de 9 kilomètres à travers une forêt primaire, passant devant des cabanes en rondins et un moulin. Cette route étroite en gravier suit les ruisseaux de montagne avec des possibilités de courtes randonnées vers des cascades.

Grotto Falls — Randonnez sur 4,3 kilomètres aller-retour jusqu'à la seule cascade du parc permettant de marcher derrière la chute de 8 mètres. Le sentier traverse des bosquets de rhododendrons et des forêts de pruches.

activities.text: Moonshine tasting — Sample legal Tennessee moonshine at Ole Smoky Distillery or others lining Gatlinburg's main strip. The clear corn liquor once made illegally in mountain stills now drives tourism.
Smoky Mountain pancake breakfast — Fuel up with buttermilk pancakes, country ham, and red-eye gravy at Pancake Pantry or similar institutions. The hearty Southern breakfast tradition sustains hikers.
Pigeon Forge evening show — Attend dinner theater featuring country music, comedy, or magic. The resort town offers family entertainment rivaling Branson, Missouri.

Dégustation de moonshine — Goûtez le moonshine légal du Tennessee à Ole Smoky Distillery ou d'autres établissements bordant le strip principal de Gatlinburg. Cette liqueur de maïs claire, autrefois fabriquée illégalement dans les alambics de montagne, alimente désormais le tourisme.

Petit-déjeuner aux pancakes des Smoky Mountains — Faites le plein avec des pancakes au babeurre, du jambon de campagne et de la sauce red-eye au Pancake Pantry ou dans des établissements similaires. Cette copieuse tradition du petit-déjeuner du Sud soutient les randonneurs.

Spectacle du soir à Pigeon Forge — Assistez à un dîner-théâtre présentant de la musique country, de la comédie ou de la magie. Cette ville de villégiature offre des divertissements familiaux rivalisant avec Branson, Missouri.

Tennessee's Musical Soul & Mountain Majesty - From Memphis Blues to Smoky Mountain Mists

visits.text: Pinnacle Mountain State Park - The Pyramid Rising from the Valley: This striking 1,011-foot cone-shaped summit dominates the horizon west of Little Rock, offering two distinct trails to its rocky apex. The West Summit Trail challenges hikers with boulder-scrambling adventure, while the East Summit provides a gentler ascent through 2,000 acres of pristine Arkansas wilderness.

activities.text: Sunset Summit Experience - Watch the River Valley Ignite in Golden Light: Time your ascent to reach the exposed rock summit as daylight fades, witnessing the Arkansas River Valley transform into a canvas of amber and crimson stretching to distant mountain ridges.

Arboretum & Nature Trails - 70 Acres of Botanical Discovery: Wander through diverse ecosystems from wetlands to hardwood forests, where interpretive trails reveal the flora that earned Arkansas its 'Natural State' designation.

visits.text: Olympic National Park — Hurricane Ridge — Drive the scenic mountain road climbing to 1,631 meters with panoramic views across the Olympic Mountains and Strait of Juan de Fuca. Wildflower meadows bloom July through August while black-tailed deer graze alpine slopes.

Hoh Rainforest — Walk among towering Sitka spruce and western hemlock draped in club moss in one of the contiguous United States' only temperate rainforests. The Hall of Mosses Trail reveals an otherworldly landscape receiving 3.6 meters of annual rainfall.

Ruby Beach — Descend to this dramatic Pacific coastline where sea stacks rise from the surf and driftwood logs litter the wide sandy beach. The Olympic coastal strip preserves 73 miles of wilderness shoreline accessible only by foot.
Ferry or drive around Puget Sound to Port Angeles; Hurricane Ridge viewpoints (weather dependent).

Parc National Olympic — Hurricane Ridge — Parcourez la route de montagne panoramique qui grimpe à 1 631 mètres avec des vues panoramiques sur les Montagnes Olympic et le Détroit de Juan de Fuca. Les prairies de fleurs sauvages fleurissent de juillet à août tandis que les cerfs à queue noire broutent les pentes alpines.

Forêt pluviale de Hoh — Marchez parmi les épicéas de Sitka et les pruches de l'Ouest drapées de mousse en massue dans l'une des seules forêts pluviales tempérées des États-Unis contigus. Le Hall of Mosses Trail révèle un paysage d'un autre monde recevant 3,6 mètres de précipitations annuelles.

Ruby Beach — Descendez vers cette côte pacifique spectaculaire où des cheminées de mer s'élèvent de la houle et des troncs de bois flotté jonchent la large plage sablonneuse. La bande côtière olympique préserve 73 miles de littoral sauvage accessible uniquement à pied.
Ferry ou conduite autour de Puget Sound vers Port Angeles ; points de vue de Hurricane Ridge (selon les conditions météorologiques).
Hoh Rain Forest — couloirs moussus et troncs-pépinières sur de courtes boucles depuis le VC.

activities.text: Sol Duc Hot Springs — Soak in natural mineral pools ranging from 99-104°F surrounded by old-growth forest. The three developed pools fed by underground springs offer relaxation after hiking Olympic trails.

Lake Crescent scenic drive — Navigate the winding highway along this glacially-carved fjord-like lake reaching 190 meters deep. The crystalline blue waters reflect surrounding peaks and forests in this pristine alpine setting.

Port Angeles waterfront dinner — Sample fresh halibut and clam chowder with views across the Strait of Juan de Fuca to Vancouver Island's mountains. The working port town serves as gateway to Olympic National Park.
Rialto Beach tide check and sunset stacks.
Hike to Sunrise Point (easy)
Hike to Hurricane Hill (moderate)

Sources chaudes de Sol Duc — Trempez-vous dans des bassins minéraux naturels allant de 37 à 40°C entourés de forêt ancienne. Les trois bassins aménagés alimentés par des sources souterraines offrent la détente après avoir randonné sur les sentiers olympiques.

Route panoramique du Lac Crescent — Naviguez sur l'autoroute sinueuse le long de ce lac en forme de fjord sculpté par les glaciers atteignant 190 mètres de profondeur. Les eaux bleu cristallin reflètent les pics et forêts environnants dans ce cadre alpin pristine.

Dîner sur le front de mer de Port Angeles — Goûtez du flétan frais et de la chaudrée de palourdes avec vue sur le Détroit de Juan de Fuca vers les montagnes de l'Île de Vancouver. Cette ville portuaire active sert de porte d'entrée au Parc National Olympic.
Rialto Beach vérification des marées et coucher de soleil sur les rochers.

days_plan.itin_title: WASHINGTON: FROM SEATTLE'S COFFEE CULTURE TO MOUNT RAINIER'S GLACIERS
PACIFIC NORTH COAST — OLYMPIC RAINFOREST, COAST & PEAKS
PACIFIC NORTHWEST PARKS — RAINIER, NORTH CASCADES & OLYMPIC FROM SEATTLE
PACIFIC NORTHWEST PARKS — RAINIER, NORTH CASCADES & OLYMPIC FROM SEATTLE
EPIC ROAD TRIP THROUGH WASHINGTON'S NATIONAL PARKS
EPIC ROAD TRIP THROUGH WASHINGTON'S NATIONAL PARKS
EPIC ROAD TRIP THROUGH WASHINGTON'S NATIONAL PARKS

visits.text: Powell's City of Books — Browse the world's largest independent bookstore occupying an entire city block with over 1 million books across color-coded rooms. Founded in 1971, this Portland institution spans 68,000 square feet and stocks new and used books on nine levels.

Washington Park — Explore this 160-hectare urban park containing the International Rose Test Garden with 10,000 rose bushes representing 650 varieties. The 1917 garden crowns Portland as City of Roses with stunning downtown and Mount Hood views.

Portland Japanese Garden — Wander through 12 acres of authentic Japanese landscape design featuring five traditional garden styles. Established in 1963, the hillside gardens offer serene pathways, koi ponds, and tea ceremonies with mountain vistas.

Pittock Mansion — Tour this 1914 French Renaissance château built by Oregonian newspaper founder Henry Pittock. The 16,000-square-foot mansion perched 305 meters above sea level showcases period furnishings and panoramic city views.

Oregon Dunes National Recreation Area — Explore 65 kilometers of coastal sand dunes reaching 152 meters high, the largest expanse of coastal dunes in North America. The 12,700-hectare area offers hiking, sandboarding, and off-road vehicle access.

Heceta Head Lighthouse — Photograph this 1894 lighthouse perched 63 meters above the Pacific Ocean, Oregon's most photographed beacon. The working light station features the keeper's house now operating as a bed and breakfast.

Sea Lion Caves — Descend into America's largest sea cave housing hundreds of Steller sea lions in their natural habitat. The 38-meter-high cavern carved by waves offers close encounters with these marine mammals year-round.

Powell's City of Books — Parcourez la plus grande librairie indépendante au monde occupant un pâté de maisons entier avec plus d'1 million de livres dans des salles codées par couleur. Fondée en 1971, cette institution de Portland s'étend sur 68 000 pieds carrés et stocke des livres neufs et d'occasion sur neuf niveaux.

Washington Park — Explorez ce parc urbain de 160 hectares abritant l'International Rose Test Garden avec 10 000 rosiers représentant 650 variétés. Ce jardin de 1917 couronne Portland comme la Ville des Roses avec de magnifiques vues sur le centre-ville et le Mount Hood.

Portland Japanese Garden — Promenez-vous dans 12 acres de conception paysagère japonaise authentique présentant cinq styles de jardins traditionnels. Établis en 1963, les jardins en flanc de colline offrent des sentiers sereins, des bassins à koï, et des cérémonies du thé avec vues sur les montagnes.

Pittock Mansion — Visitez ce château Renaissance français de 1914 construit par le fondateur du journal Oregonian Henry Pittock. Le manoir de 16 000 pieds carrés perché à 305 mètres au-dessus du niveau de la mer présente un mobilier d'époque et des vues panoramiques sur la ville.

Oregon Dunes National Recreation Area — Explorez 65 kilomètres de dunes côtières atteignant 152 mètres de haut, la plus grande étendue de dunes côtières d'Amérique du Nord. La zone de 12 700 hectares offre randonnée, surf des sables et accès en véhicules tout-terrain.

Phare de Heceta Head — Photographiez ce phare de 1894 perché à 63 mètres au-dessus de l'océan Pacifique, le phare le plus photographié de l'Oregon. La station lumineuse en activité comprend la maison du gardien qui fonctionne maintenant comme un gîte touristique.

Grottes aux Lions de Mer — Descendez dans la plus grande grotte marine d'Amérique abritant des centaines d'otaries de Steller dans leur habitat naturel. La caverne de 38 mètres de haut sculptée par les vagues offre des rencontres rapprochées avec ces mammifères marins toute l'année.

activities.text: Food cart exploration — Sample Portland's famous food truck scene offering cuisine from around the world in outdoor pods. Over 500 carts serve everything from Korean bibimbap to Venezuelan arepas reflecting the city's culinary diversity.

Craft brewery hopping — Visit taprooms in Portland's 70+ breweries earning it the title Beervana. The city pioneered American craft beer movement with innovative IPAs, sours, and barrel-aged specialties.

Pearl District evening stroll — Browse art galleries, boutiques, and restaurants in this revitalized warehouse district. Former industrial buildings now house trendy shops and Powell's Books flagship location.
Scenic coastal drive return — Navigate Highway 101 north past beaches, headlands, and charming coastal towns. The route showcases Oregon's diverse coastline from rocky shores to sandy strands.

Tillamook Creamery tour — Visit this dairy cooperative producing cheese since 1909, now processing 170,000 gallons of milk daily. The visitor center offers cheese samples and ice cream while explaining Oregon's dairy industry.

Final Portland dinner — Celebrate the journey with farm-to-table cuisine at one of Portland's acclaimed restaurants. The city's culinary scene emphasizes Pacific Northwest ingredients and innovative preparations.

Exploration de chariots alimentaires — Découvrez la célèbre scène de food trucks de Portland offrant une cuisine du monde entier dans des pods extérieurs. Plus de 500 chariots servent tout, du bibimbap coréen aux arepas vénézuéliennes, reflétant la diversité culinaire de la ville.

Tournée de brasseries artisanales — Visitez les salles de dégustation des 70+ brasseries de Portland qui lui valent le titre de Beervana. La ville a été pionnière du mouvement américain de la bière artisanale avec des IPA innovantes, des bières sures et des spécialités vieillies en fût.

Promenade nocturne dans le Pearl District — Parcourez les galeries d'art, boutiques et restaurants de ce quartier d'entrepôts revitalisé. D'anciens bâtiments industriels abritent maintenant des magasins branchés et le magasin phare de Powell's Books.

Retour par la route côtière panoramique — Naviguez sur l'autoroute 101 vers le nord en passant par des plages, des promontoires et de charmantes villes côtières. L'itinéraire présente la côte diversifiée de l'Oregon, des rives rocheuses aux étendues de sable.

Visite de la fromagerie Tillamook — Visitez cette coopérative laitière qui produit du fromage depuis 1909 et traite maintenant 170 000 gallons de lait par jour. Le centre d'accueil offre des échantillons de fromage et de la crème glacée tout en expliquant l'industrie laitière de l'Oregon.

Dîner final à Portland — Célébrez le voyage avec une cuisine de la ferme à la table dans l'un des restaurants acclamés de Portland. La scène culinaire de la ville met l'accent sur les ingrédients du Pacifique Nord-Ouest et les préparations innovantes.

NEW ENGLAND MOUNTAINS LOOP — ACADIA & WHITE MOUNTAINS

visits.text: Toast America's brewing heritage at Yuengling, the nation's oldest operating brewery, where fifth-generation family members still craft lager using recipes dating to 1829. Tour the historic Pottsville facility built into the hillside, descend into hand-dug caves where lager once aged naturally in cool darkness, and conclude with samples of freshly brewed classics in the gift shop. This living piece of American history survived Prohibition by producing 'near beer' and ice cream, ensuring the family tradition continues nearly two centuries later.

days_plan.itin_title: Pennsylvania Heritage Trail - Where American History Meets Natural Splendor

visits.text: Jour 1: Immerse yourself in one of America's most authentic Little Italy neighborhoods at Federal Hill, where the aroma of fresh-baked bread and imported Italian delicacies wafts through the streets. This vibrant enclave preserves generations of Italian-American culture through family-owned shops brimming with imported meats, cheeses, and traditional goods that transport visitors straight to the old country. The iconic pinecone archway welcomes you to DePasquale Square, the beating heart of Providence's culinary scene where outdoor cafés spill onto cobblestones beneath twinkling lights.

Jour 1: Step back through centuries of American history along Benefit Street, rightfully dubbed 'The Mile of History' for its extraordinary concentration of Colonial and Victorian architecture. This 1.2-mile stretch showcases one of the nation's densest collections of historic structures, where Georgian mansions stand shoulder-to-shoulder with Federal-era townhouses, each façade telling stories of merchants, sea captains, and founding families who shaped Rhode Island's destiny. Guided tours from the Rhode Island Historical Society reveal the hidden tales behind these meticulously preserved homes.

Jour 1: Wander the ivy-draped campus of Brown University, one of America's prestigious Ivy League institutions founded in 1764, where colonial brick buildings harmonize with cutting-edge modern architecture. Pass through the ceremonial Van Wickle Gates that open only twice yearly for students, admire the treasures within the John Hay Library, and discover the First Baptist Church in America, established by Roger Williams himself. The adjacent Thayer Street pulses with the energy of one of New England's most vibrant college neighborhoods.

Jour 2: Explore the wonders of one of America's oldest zoological parks at Roger Williams Park Zoo, where over 150 species from around the globe inhabit naturalistic habitats across 40 meticulously designed acres. Encounter magnificent moon bears, graceful giraffes, playful red pandas, and bounding kangaroos in this predominantly cage-free environment that prioritizes animal welfare and conservation education. The surrounding 435-acre Roger Williams Park, affectionately called the 'People's Park,' encompasses Rhode Island's only public planetarium and New England's largest glasshouse display garden.

Jour 2: Discover artistic treasures spanning 2,000 years of human creativity at the RISD Museum of Art, the nation's 20th largest art museum and crown jewel of the Rhode Island School of Design. Over 100,000 works fill these galleries, from ancient Egyptian artifacts and medieval armor to Impressionist masterpieces by Degas and Monet that capture light on canvas with breathtaking virtuosity. The museum's collection of Asian art, European decorative arts, and contemporary works ensures hours of aesthetic exploration.

activities.text: Jour 1: Ascend to Prospect Terrace Park as golden hour bathes Providence in amber light, where panoramic views unfold across the city's architectural tapestry from the spires of College Hill to the gleaming towers of downtown. A statue of Roger Williams, Rhode Island's visionary founder, presides over this elevated sanctuary where locals and visitors alike gather to watch spectacular sunsets paint the skyline in hues of rose and gold.

Jour 2: Experience the transformative magic of WaterFire, Providence's signature public art installation where nearly 100 bonfires blaze upon the city's three rivers, their crackling flames reflected in the dark waters below. Created by artist Barnaby Evans in 1995, this multisensory spectacle combines fire, music, and performance art, drawing hundreds of thousands of visitors annually to stroll the riverbanks and witness one of America's most unique urban experiences.

days_plan.itin_title: Rhode Island's Gilded Shores & Colonial Treasures - America's Smallest State, Grandest Discoveries

visits.text: Marvel at Providence Canyon, Georgia's 'Little Grand Canyon' where vivid walls of red, orange, pink, and white sandstone rise dramatically above wildflower-lined trails and pine forests. Poor farming practices in the 1800s triggered erosion that carved these spectacular formations, transforming agricultural failure into geological wonder. The Canyon Loop Trail winds through the colorful gorges offering photographers extraordinary compositions.

Discover rusted vintage automobiles from the 1950s along the quirky White Blaze Trail, abandoned relics slowly being reclaimed by the surrounding forest. Backcountry camping sites allow overnight visitors to experience canyon walls glowing golden at sunrise and sunset. The unexpected southwestern landscape feels transported from Arizona to rural Georgia.

activities.text: Hike through pine-scented woods to remote backcountry campsites where crackling campfires beneath starry skies create unforgettable wilderness experiences. The park's dramatic terrain changes character throughout the day as shifting sunlight paints the multicolored canyon walls in ever-changing hues.

days_plan.itin_title: Georgia Grand Circle: Mountains, Historic Cities and Golden Isles

visits.text: Make pilgrimage to America's most famous weather forecaster at Gobbler's Knob, the hallowed hilltop where Punxsutawney Phil has delivered his groundhog prognostication every February 2nd since 1887. While the legendary rodent and his mate Phyllis-now proud parents of two adorable pups-reside at the Punxsutawney Memorial Library year-round, the true magic happens in the pre-dawn darkness of Groundhog Day when thousands gather to learn if spring will arrive early. Stop at the Visitor Center for official Groundhog Club souvenirs and to meet Phil's Inner Circle, the top-hatted guardians of this beloved American tradition.

activities.text: Climb the rugged stairway to summit at 1,000 Steps, one of the most celebrated milestones along the 85-mile Standing Stone Trail. These jagged stone steps, carved into Jacks Mountain by quarry workers in the 1950s to access the ganister deposits used in silica brick production, reward determined hikers with spectacular views across the Juniata River valley. The challenging ascent through Huntingdon County's wilderness offers a true Pennsylvania Wilds adventure.

days_plan.itin_title: Pennsylvania Heritage Trail - Where American History Meets Natural Splendor

visits.text: Ascend Mount Penn to the Reading Pagoda, a scarlet seven-story Japanese castle that has crowned the city skyline since 1908. Originally built by local eccentric William Witman as a luxury resort that never materialized, this whimsical landmark anchored by 16 tons of bolts now offers 30-mile panoramic views across the Pennsylvania Dutch countryside. Though currently undergoing renovation, the Pagoda remains one of America's most distinctive municipal landmarks and a beloved symbol of Reading's unconventional spirit.

days_plan.itin_title: Pennsylvania Heritage Trail - Where American History Meets Natural Splendor

visits.text: Experience Red River Ski & Summer Area, a family-friendly resort featuring over 60 trails across more than 200 acres of skiable terrain in the heart of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains. The resort operates year-round, offering skiing and snowboarding in winter, plus hiking and mountain activities during summer months. The accessible layout and varied terrain make it popular with families and intermediate skiers.

Discover Enchanted Forest Cross Country Ski Area, a premier Nordic skiing destination offering groomed trails through pristine mountain forest landscapes. The area also welcomes snowshoers and fat bikers seeking peaceful winter wilderness experiences. The path to Greenie Peak provides exceptional snowmobiling adventures through high-altitude terrain with panoramic mountain views.

activities.text: Explore the vibrant mountain town of Red River, where year-round outdoor recreation combines with authentic New Mexico hospitality. Local craft beverages and hearty mountain fare await after days on the slopes or trails. The compact downtown offers convenient access to equipment rentals and all necessary supplies for mountain adventures.

Redding - California's Sunniest Secret with 300+ Days of Brilliance: This underrated gateway to Northern California's wilderness basks in more sunny days than almost anywhere in the state. The striking Sundial Bridge, a gleaming white cable-stayed span designed by Santiago Calatrava, serves as the world's largest working sundial.

Shasta Dam - The Second-Largest Concrete Dam in America: Rising 602 feet above the Sacramento River, this engineering marvel created the spectacular Shasta Lake with its 365 miles of shoreline. Free tours descend into the dam's interior.

Redwood National Park - Where Earth's Tallest Living Giants Touch the Sky: Stand humbled beneath trees that were ancient when Rome was young. These coastal redwoods soar over 350 feet, creating cathedral-like groves where filtered sunlight streams through canopies that have witnessed millennia. A UNESCO World Heritage Site protecting some of the most magnificent forests remaining on Earth.

Jedediah Smith Redwoods State Park - Drive Through a Living Tunnel of Green: Navigate the legendary Howland Hill Road as it winds through primeval old-growth forest so dense the canopy forms a continuous emerald ceiling. Some trees here sprouted before the pyramids were built.

Prairie Creek Redwoods State Park - Where Roosevelt Elk Roam Free: Encounter herds of majestic elk grazing in meadows surrounded by towering redwoods. Fern Canyon, with its 50-foot walls draped in seven species of ferns, served as a filming location for Jurassic Park.
Transfert vers la côte via les forêts de Trinity et la région de la rivière Klamath.
Prairie Creek Redwoods — Boucles du Big Tree et silencieuses comme une cathédrale parmi les arbres anciens.

visits.text: Hoover Dam — Tour this engineering marvel completed in 1936 creating Lake Mead, America's largest reservoir by volume. The 221-meter concrete arch-gravity dam generates 4 billion kilowatt-hours annually while taming the Colorado River.

Lake Mead National Recreation Area — Boat or drive along this 177-kilometer reservoir backed by dramatic desert mountains. The lake created by Hoover Dam offers recreation amid landscapes where ancient civilizations left petroglyphs.

Extraterrestrial Highway — Navigate State Route 375 through remote desert passing the classified Area 51 military base. The 158-kilometer stretch features alien-themed attractions and conspiracy theories about UFO sightings.

National Automobile Museum — Discover 200 vintage cars including Elvis's 1973 Cadillac and John Wayne's Corvette in this world-class collection. The museum showcases automotive history from horseless carriages to modern supercars.

Nevada Museum of Art — Explore contemporary art with focus on landscapes and environment in this architectural landmark. The museum houses the Center for Art + Environment documenting land art and environmental themes.
Truckee Riverwalk — Stroll along this urban trail following the river through downtown past shops, galleries, and public art. The revitalized corridor connects parks and cultural attractions.
Fleischmann Planetarium — Learn about astronomy and space exploration at University of Nevada's planetarium. The facility offers star shows and exhibits explaining the cosmos.

activities.text: Desert scenic drive — Cross Nevada's vast basin and range topography under endless skies. The journey reveals the state's emptiness with occasional ghost towns and roadside diners.
Reno Arch photo — Snap pictures beneath the famous arch proclaiming The Biggest Little City in the World. The neon gateway has welcomed visitors to downtown Reno since 1926.

Casino dinner and gaming — Try your luck at Reno's casinos offering more relaxed atmosphere than Las Vegas. The original Nevada gaming destination maintains old-school charm with affordable table limits.
Downtown Reno revival — Explore the revitalized downtown featuring murals, breweries, and the RiverWalk District. The city reinvented itself beyond gaming with arts and outdoor recreation focus.

Basque cuisine dinner — Savor family-style Basque meals at restaurants preserving sheepherder traditions. Reno's Basque community maintains culinary heritage with multi-course dinners served communally.

days_plan.itin_title: NEVADA: LAS VEGAS NEON LIGHTS TO VALLEY OF FIRE DESERT BEAUTY
NEVADA: LAS VEGAS NEON LIGHTS TO VALLEY OF FIRE DESERT BEAUTY

visits.text: Seneca Falls Women's Rights National Park — Visit the birthplace of the American women's rights movement where the first Women's Rights Convention convened in 1848. The Wesleyan Chapel and Declaration Park commemorate Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Susan B. Anthony, and 100 signers.

George Eastman Museum — Explore the world's oldest museum dedicated to photography and film in Kodak founder George Eastman's 1905 Colonial Revival mansion. The collection spans 400,000 photographs and 28,000 films documenting the evolution of visual media.

High Falls — Stand at the edge of this 29-meter waterfall on the Genesee River that powered Rochester's 19th-century flour mills and breweries. The gorge's Silurian dolostone layers reveal 400 million years of geological history.

Strong National Museum of Play — Discover the world's only collections-based museum devoted solely to play, housing the National Toy Hall of Fame. Interactive exhibits celebrate video games, dolls, and classic toys across 14,000 square meters.

Parc national des droits des femmes de Seneca Falls — Visitez le berceau du mouvement américain des droits des femmes où s'est tenue la première Convention des droits des femmes en 1848. La chapelle Wesleyan et Declaration Park commémorent Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Susan B. Anthony et 100 signataires.

Musée George Eastman — Explorez le plus ancien musée au monde dédié à la photographie et au cinéma dans le manoir de style Colonial Revival de 1905 du fondateur de Kodak, George Eastman. La collection comprend 400 000 photographies et 28 000 films documentant l'évolution des médias visuels.

High Falls — Tenez-vous au bord de cette cascade de 29 mètres sur la rivière Genesee qui alimentait les moulins à farine et brasseries du 19e siècle de Rochester. Les couches de dolomie silurienne de la gorge révèlent 400 millions d'années d'histoire géologique.

Musée national du jeu Strong — Découvrez le seul musée au monde basé sur des collections consacré uniquement au jeu, abritant le Temple de la renommée national du jouet. Les expositions interactives célèbrent les jeux vidéo, les poupées et les jouets classiques sur 14 000 mètres carrés.

activities.text: Public Market browsing — Sample local produce, artisan breads, and ethnic specialties at this indoor-outdoor market operating since 1905. Over 300 vendors gather on Saturdays offering everything from hydroponic greens to Nicaraguan pupusas.

Genesee Riverway Trail cycling — Pedal along this 39-kilometer paved trail following the Genesee River through parks, wetlands, and historic districts. The route passes three waterfalls and connects downtown Rochester to Lake Ontario.

Charlotte Beach sunset — Relax on this sandy Lake Ontario beach where the Genesee River meets the Great Lake. The historic 1905 Dentzel Carousel and pier offer family entertainment as the sun sets over Canadian waters.

Navigation au marché public — Goûtez les produits locaux, les pains artisanaux et les spécialités ethniques dans ce marché intérieur-extérieur fonctionnant depuis 1905. Plus de 300 vendeurs se rassemblent le samedi offrant tout, des légumes verts hydroponiques aux pupusas nicaraguayennes.

Cyclisme sur le Genesee Riverway Trail — Pédalez le long de cette piste pavée de 39 kilomètres qui suit la rivière Genesee à travers les parcs, zones humides et quartiers historiques. Le parcours passe devant trois chutes d'eau et relie le centre-ville de Rochester au lac Ontario.

Coucher de soleil à Charlotte Beach — Détendez-vous sur cette plage de sable du lac Ontario où la rivière Genesee rencontre le Grand Lac. Le carrousel historique Dentzel de 1905 et la jetée offrent des divertissements familiaux tandis que le soleil se couche sur les eaux canadiennes.

days_plan.itin_title: NEW YORK: FROM MANHATTAN'S SKYSCRAPERS TO NIAGARA FALLS MAJESTY

visits.text: Embrace the extraterrestrial atmosphere of Roswell, world-famous for the alleged 1947 UFO incident that transformed this agricultural town into a mecca for alien enthusiasts and curious travelers. The International UFO Museum and Research Center presents exhibits examining the incident, government investigations, and broader questions about extraterrestrial life. The entire downtown district celebrates its otherworldly reputation with themed attractions and memorable photo opportunities.

Discover alien-themed street lights, murals, and memorabilia throughout downtown Roswell, where the community has embraced its unique place in American pop culture. The town offers a lighthearted exploration of one of the most persistent mysteries in modern history, regardless of personal beliefs about what actually occurred in the New Mexico desert.

Embrace the extraterrestrial legacy of Roswell, the small town that captured global attention following a mysterious 1947 incident that has fueled decades of speculation about unidentified flying objects. The International UFO Museum & Research Center presents exhibits examining the original incident, government investigations, and broader questions about extraterrestrial life that continue to fascinate visitors from around the world.

Explore downtown Roswell's UFO-themed attractions, where the community has enthusiastically embraced its otherworldly reputation through alien-themed street lights, murals, and memorabilia scattered throughout the commercial district. While the town maintains a playful approach to its fame, the museums offer serious examination of the incident's historical documentation and its cultural impact. The annual UFO Festival draws enthusiasts from across the globe.

activities.text: Explore beyond the alien attractions to discover Roswell's genuine history as a ranching and agricultural center in southeastern New Mexico. Museums and historic sites document the region's development from frontier territory to modern community, offering context for understanding how an isolated desert town became internationally famous.

Discover Roswell's authentic history as a ranching and agricultural center beyond its extraterrestrial associations, including museums documenting the region's development from frontier territory to modern community. The surrounding high desert landscape provides context for understanding how an isolated town became internationally famous for events that occurred on a remote ranch decades ago.

visits.text: Explore the Person County Museum of History, where comprehensive artifact exhibitions provide a detailed and engaging account of Roxboro's fascinating past. This welcoming museum offers visitors the opportunity to understand the heritage and development of this delightful Person County community through carefully curated displays and historical documents.

activities.text: Relax in the open spaces of Longhurst Park, the ideal environment for outdoor recreation including walking trails and sports facilities. The park provides a refreshing escape where visitors can enjoy the small-town atmosphere that makes Roxboro so charming.

Experience downtown Roxboro's socially charged atmosphere, where the family-friendly Kirby Cultural Arts Complex hosts entertaining stage performances. Browse for unique treasures at local shops while engaging with friendly locals proud to share their community's heritage and hospitality.

visits.text: Discover Ruidoso, a charming mountain village in the Sierra Blanca range where the snow-capped peak dominates the horizon and outdoor recreation opportunities abound in every season. Ski Apache operates as the southernmost ski resort in the United States, featuring 55 trails across 750 skiable acres with stunning views of the surrounding mountain wilderness. The resort's location on Mescalero Apache tribal lands adds cultural significance to the alpine experience.

Experience Ruidoso Winter Park, offering family-friendly snow activities including a mountain coaster and tubing course for those seeking gentler thrills than the ski slopes provide. The accessible location and varied attractions make Ruidoso popular with families and visitors seeking mountain ambiance without extreme sports. Scenic chairlift rides operate during summer months, providing easy access to high-altitude views.

activities.text: Sample New Mexico wines at local tasting rooms and enjoy craft beverages that reflect the state's growing reputation for quality viticulture in high-altitude conditions. The village atmosphere encourages leisurely exploration of shops, galleries, and casual dining establishments. The Inn of the Mountain Gods, an Indigenous-owned resort on Mescalero Apache land, offers gaming entertainment and full-service spa facilities.

visits.text: Sacramento - America's Farm-to-Fork Capital: California's capital city sits at the confluence of the Sacramento and American Rivers, surrounded by the most productive agricultural region on Earth. The historic Old Sacramento Waterfront district preserves Gold Rush-era architecture along wooden boardwalks.

California State Capitol - Where the Golden State Governs: This stunning neoclassical building, completed in 1874, anchors a 40-acre park filled with memorials, gardens, and trees from around the world. Free tours reveal legislative chambers adorned with California history.

Crocker Art Museum - The West's Oldest Public Art Museum: Founded in 1885, this institution houses one of the finest collections of California art, European master drawings, and international ceramics, all within a striking contemporary expansion adjoining the original Victorian Italianate gallery.

activities.text: Old Sacramento Historic District - Step Back to the Gold Rush: Wooden sidewalks, horse-drawn carriages, and restored 1850s buildings create an immersive journey to California's most transformative era. The California State Railroad Museum houses the largest collection of railroad locomotives and cars in North America.

Sacramento Mural Trail - Urban Art Gallery Without Walls: Over 600 murals transform the city into an open-air museum, with new works constantly appearing on buildings throughout downtown and surrounding neighborhoods.

visits.text: Salina - Kansas's Emerging Arts Capital: Even longtime locals discover something new with each visit to this booming downtown, where fresh attractions, murals, and revitalized streetscapes continue transforming the city's core.

Mural at the Mill - 100 Feet of Monumental Art: Australian artist Guido van Helten's stunning work wraps three sides of a flour mill, the first of many murals coordinated by the Salina Kanvas Project that have transformed the city into an open-air gallery.

Salina SculptureTour - 20 Works Dressing Downtown Sidewalks: This rotating outdoor exhibition changes every spring, with pedestrians voting for their favorite sculptures among the works displayed throughout the city center.

The Stiefel Theatre - Art Deco Splendor Under a Neon Spire: This beautifully restored 1931 showpiece hosts live performances beneath its distinctive illuminated tower, a beacon of culture on the Kansas plains.

activities.text: Downtown Salina Walking Tour - Art at Every Turn: Wander the revitalized streetscape discovering murals, sculptures, and the creative energy that has made Salina a destination for art lovers.

visits.text: Walk the legendary San Antonio River Walk, a picturesque network of pathways winding along the San Antonio River below street level, lined with restaurants, shops, and stunning landscaping. This unique urban waterway has become one of the most visited attractions in Texas, offering boat cruises, seasonal festivals, and enchanting nighttime ambiance when thousands of lights reflect on the water. The River Walk perfectly blends historic charm with modern entertainment in the heart of downtown.

Stand before the Alamo, the iconic 18th-century Spanish mission where the famous 1836 battle became a defining moment in Texas independence and American history. The preserved church and grounds now serve as a shrine to the defenders who fell during the siege, attracting millions of visitors annually to learn about this pivotal chapter in Texas heritage. Museum exhibits detail the complex history of the mission and its transformation into a symbol of courage and sacrifice.

activities.text: Explore the San Antonio Missions National Historical Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site encompassing five historic Spanish colonial missions including the Alamo, representing the largest concentration of Spanish colonial missions in North America. Each mission tells a unique story of religious conversion, cultural exchange, and frontier life in the 18th century. The park provides an extraordinary window into the Spanish colonial period that shaped the region's culture.

Discover the Pearl District, a transformed historic brewery complex now hosting a vibrant farmers market, culinary destinations, and artisan shops that have made it a center of San Antonio's food renaissance. Market Square, the largest Mexican market outside Mexico, offers authentic crafts, traditional foods, and cultural experiences celebrating the city's Hispanic heritage. The annual 11-day Fiesta San Antonio celebrates the city's diverse cultures with parades, music, and festivities drawing hundreds of thousands of visitors.

days_plan.itin_title: Texas Discovery: From Vibrant Cities to Desert Wilderness

days_plan.itin_title: ROUTE 66 IN 14 DAYS: FROM CHICAGO TO THE PACIFIC

visits.text: San Diego - America's Finest City: Year-round perfect weather, 70 miles of beaches, and a relaxed vibe distinguish California's second-largest city. From world-class attractions to legendary surf breaks, San Diego delivers coastal California at its best.

San Diego Zoo - One of the World's Great Zoos: This 100-acre facility in Balboa Park houses over 12,000 animals representing 650 species, many in innovative open-air habitats that have set the standard for modern zoos.

Balboa Park - The Smithsonian of the West: This 1,200-acre urban cultural park houses 17 museums, performing arts venues, and the zoo within stunning Spanish Colonial Revival architecture built for the 1915 Panama-California Exposition.

USS Midway Museum - Walk the Deck of a Floating City: This decommissioned aircraft carrier served from 1945 to 1992, and now hosts docent-led tours through living quarters, engine rooms, and a flight deck lined with historic aircraft.

Gaslamp Quarter - Victorian Splendor Meets Urban Energy: Sixteen blocks of restored Victorian architecture house San Diego's premier dining, entertainment, and nightlife district, all walkable from the convention center and waterfront.

activities.text: La Jolla Cove - Sea Lions, Seals, and Snorkeling: This small beach flanked by sandstone cliffs offers some of Southern California's clearest water, with sea lions lounging on nearby rocks and garibaldi (California's state fish) flashing orange in the shallows.

Coronado Beach - Where the Beach Meets the Grand Dame: The iconic Hotel del Coronado has anchored this beach since 1888, its distinctive red turrets rising above some of the finest sand in California.

Cabrillo National Monument - Where European Exploration Began: This point at the tip of Point Loma marks where Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo became the first European to set foot on the West Coast in 1542, with tide pools and panoramic views as bonuses.

Craft Beer Capital of America - 150+ Breweries and Counting: San Diego has emerged as America's premier craft beer destination, with pioneering breweries producing styles from hop-forward IPAs to innovative barrel-aged creations.

days_plan.itin_title: California Unveiled: From Ancient Redwoods to Desert Wonders - The Ultimate Golden State Odyssey

visits.text: Golden Gate corridor — Read the city’s topography from headlands to bay, then prep logistics for mountain travel.
Return to the Bay Area via Highway 1/101 segments; buffer for departures.
San Francisco departure logistics and coastal outlooks.

San Francisco - The City by the Bay: Few cities can match San Francisco's combination of stunning natural setting, architectural beauty, and cultural richness. Forty-three hills provide endless viewpoints over a metropolis surrounded on three sides by water.

Golden Gate Bridge - The World's Most Photographed Bridge: This Art Deco masterpiece stretches 1.7 miles across the Golden Gate strait, its International Orange towers rising 746 feet above swirling currents. Walk or cycle across for views of the Pacific, bay, and city skyline.

Alcatraz Island - America's Most Notorious Prison: This island fortress housed the country's most dangerous criminals from 1934 to 1963, including Al Capone and the Birdman. The audio tour, narrated by former guards and inmates, brings chilling history to life.

Fisherman's Wharf & Pier 39 - Where Sea Lions Rule: Hundreds of California sea lions have claimed the marina's floating docks since 1989, creating one of the city's most beloved (and loudest) attractions. Fresh Dungeness crab awaits at the waterfront.

Chinatown - The Oldest in North America: Established in 1848, this vibrant 24-block neighborhood houses the largest Chinese community outside Asia. The ornate Dragon Gate marks entry to a world of temples, herbal shops, and dim sum parlors.

Golden Gate Bridge — Cross this iconic 2,737-meter suspension bridge inaugurated in 1937, an Art Deco engineering masterpiece designed by Joseph Strauss. Its two 227-meter towers dominate the bay in a distinctive international orange hue.

Alcatraz Island — Explore the former federal prison perched on its rocky island that housed Al Capone and Machine Gun Kelly from 1934 to 1963. The immersive audio guide recreates the oppressive atmosphere of the cells and the legendary escape attempts.

Fisherman's Wharf — Stroll through this lively maritime district where fishermen still unload their daily catches. Sea lions bask noisily on Pier 39 while the smell of fresh crab perfumes the market stalls.

Cable Car — Board a historic streetcar designated a historic monument since 1964, the only cable transport system still operated manually. These wooden cars have climbed the steep slopes of Nob Hill since 1873.
Discovery of the Haight Ashbury neighborhood and its Victorian Painted Ladies houses
Walk on Fisherman's Wharf and Pier 39 with sea lion watching

Cable Cars - The Only Mobile National Historic Landmark: These manually-operated icons have climbed San Francisco's impossible hills since 1873. The Powell-Hyde line delivers passengers to stunning bay views at Lombard Street's famous hairpin turns.

Golden Gate Park - 1,017 Acres of Urban Wonder: Larger than Central Park, this masterpiece of landscape design houses the California Academy of Sciences, de Young Museum, Japanese Tea Garden, and botanical treasures from every continent.

The Painted Ladies - Victorian Perfection at Alamo Square: These pastel-hued 'Seven Sisters' row houses, with the downtown skyline rising behind them, create perhaps San Francisco's most iconic photograph.

Chinatown Walk — Stroll through the oldest Chinese quarter in North America founded in 1848, where red lanterns illuminate Grant Avenue and traditional herbalists stand alongside steaming dim sum. Pass through the Dragon's Gate adorned with golden dragons.

Tasting at Ferry Building Marketplace — Savor Californian artisanal products in this gourmet market housed in the former ferry terminal from 1898. Local cheeses, fresh oysters and roasted coffees will delight your taste buds.

Sunset at Twin Peaks — Climb up these twin hills culminating at 281 meters for a 360° panoramic view of the city. The spectacle is magical in late afternoon when the sun sets the bay ablaze and illuminates the skyscrapers.

visits.text: San Luis Obispo - The Happiest City in America: Nestled between rolling hills and the Pacific, this university town consistently ranks among the nation's happiest and healthiest communities. The Thursday night farmers market transforms downtown into California's best street fair.

Mission San Luis Obispo de Tolosa - The Birthplace of California's Red-Tile Roofs: Founded in 1772, this mission pioneered the clay tile roofing that became synonymous with California architecture after wooden roofs proved vulnerable to fire arrows.

Bubblegum Alley - 70 Feet of Sticky Art: This narrow downtown passage has accumulated chewed gum on its walls since the 1950s, creating a colorful (and slightly gross) folk art installation that's become a must-see oddity.

Paso Robles Wine Country - California's Fastest-Growing Wine Region: Just 30 minutes north, over 200 wineries grow 40 grape varieties in this diverse appellation, from powerful Cabernet Sauvignon to distinctive Rhône-style blends.

Hearst Castle — Explore the extravagant palace with 56 bedrooms and 61 bathrooms built between 1919 and 1947 for press magnate William Randolph Hearst. Architect Julia Morgan created this Hispanic-Moorish fantasy perched on La Cuesta Encantada, the enchanted hill.

Elephant Seal Vista Point — Observe the northern elephant seal colony sprawling lazily on the beaches of Piedras Blancas. These marine mammals that can weigh up to 2 tons have gathered here for molting and breeding since 1990.

Morro Rock — Contemplate this 176-meter volcanic dome emerging majestically from the ocean. Formed 23 million years ago, this volcanic neck sacred to the Chumash shelters nesting peregrine falcons and marks the entrance to the bay.

Mission San Luis Obispo de Tolosa — Visit this mission founded in 1772 by Father Junípero Serra, fifth in the chain of California missions. Its museum traces the tumultuous history of interactions between Franciscans and the native Chumash population.

activities.text: Hearst Castle - The Mountaintop Palace of a Media Baron: William Randolph Hearst's 165-room estate perches above the Pacific at San Simeon, filled with European antiquities and art masterpieces. Multiple tours explore different areas of this California State Park.

Montana de Oro State Park - California's Hidden Coastal Gem: Seven miles of wild coastline, tide pools teeming with life, and bluffs carpeted in golden poppies create one of the state's most underrated natural areas.

Stroll through the Farmers Market — Wander through the Thursday evening farmers market that has transformed Higuera Street into a lively street festival since 1983. Local producers, street musicians and barbecue vendors create a festive atmosphere typically Californian.

Wine tasting in Edna Valley — Wind through the rolling vineyards planted with Pinot Noir and Chardonnay in this renowned wine appellation. Family tasting rooms offer food and wine pairings in a bucolic setting 8 kilometers from downtown.

Hiking to Bishop Peak — Climb to the summit of this 474-meter volcanic peak, highest point of the Nine Sisters. The steep 6.5-kilometer trail rewards the effort with panoramic views of the valley and sparkling ocean.

days_plan.itin_title: California Unveiled: From Ancient Redwoods to Desert Wonders - The Ultimate Golden State Odyssey
CALIFORNIA: PACIFIC COAST HIGHWAY FROM SAN FRANCISCO TO LOS ANGELES

visits.text: Santa Barbara - The American Riviera: Red-tile roofs, white stucco walls, and swaying palms create a Mediterranean atmosphere along this sun-drenched coast. Oprah Winfrey, among many celebrities, chose to call it home.

Mission Santa Barbara - Queen of the Missions: Founded in 1786, this beautifully preserved mission features a striking twin-tower facade and remains an active Franciscan community. The surrounding rose garden and cemetery tell centuries of California history.

Stearns Wharf - The Oldest Working Wharf on the West Coast: Built in 1872, this wooden pier extends into the Santa Barbara Channel, offering shops, restaurants, and sweeping views of the city's palm-lined waterfront and the Channel Islands beyond.

Santa Barbara County Courthouse - The Most Beautiful Public Building in America: This 1929 Spanish Colonial Revival masterpiece features hand-painted ceilings, wrought-iron fixtures, and an observation tower with 360-degree views of the city, mountains, and ocean.

Old Mission Santa Barbara — Discover the queen of California missions founded in 1786, the only one to have remained under continuous Franciscan administration. The neoclassical church with its double-tower facade houses a golden altarpiece and Chumash wall frescoes.

Santa Barbara County Courthouse — Admire this Spanish-Moorish architectural masterpiece completed in 1929 after the destructive 1925 earthquake. The El Mirador clock tower offers a 360° view of the red tile roofs and sparkling Pacific.

State Street — Stroll the main palm-lined shopping artery where designer boutiques, art galleries and fusion restaurants sit alongside Spanish colonial style buildings. The uniform architecture creates a Mediterranean atmosphere unique in California.
Stearns Wharf — Walk along California's oldest wooden pier built in 1872. Artisan shops and the Sea Center aquarium occupy the historic buildings while fishermen and pelicans share the docks.

activities.text: Lotusland - 37 Acres of Botanical Fantasy: This private estate, open by reservation only, showcases the eccentric plant collection of opera singer Madame Ganna Walska, including surreal gardens of euphorbias, cycads, and cacti.

Solvang - A Danish Village in California: This charming town 30 minutes north features authentic Danish architecture, bakeries selling æbleskiver, and windmills transported straight from Scandinavia. Founded by Danish immigrants in 1911.

Wine tasting on the Urban Wine Trail — Explore the thirty or so tasting rooms concentrated in the Funk Zone, a former industrial district converted into an urban wine paradise. Winemakers from Santa Ynez Valley present their award-winning vintages in renovated warehouses.

Beach bike ride — Pedal along the bike path running 5 kilometers of golden sand beaches lined with palm trees. Stop at East Beach for an impromptu beach volleyball match or a surfing session in the gentle waves.

Sunset at Butterfly Beach — Settle in on this exclusive Montecito beach where celebrities blend incognito with locals. The sun plunging into the Pacific behind the Channel Islands creates memorable flaming skies.

days_plan.itin_title: California Unveiled: From Ancient Redwoods to Desert Wonders - The Ultimate Golden State Odyssey
CALIFORNIA: PACIFIC COAST HIGHWAY FROM SAN FRANCISCO TO LOS ANGELES

visits.text: Santa Cruz - California's Original Surf City: This laid-back university town at the northern tip of Monterey Bay has shaped surf culture since the sport arrived on the mainland in 1885. The world-famous break at Steamer Lane draws elite surfers while beginners learn on gentler waves at Cowell's Beach.

Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk - California's Last Remaining Seaside Amusement Park: This 1907 landmark operates two National Historic Landmarks: the 1924 Giant Dipper wooden roller coaster and the 1911 Looff Carousel. Free admission lets visitors soak up the vintage atmosphere without riding.

Natural Bridges State Beach - Where Monarchs Meet the Sea: This coastal park features a dramatic natural stone arch emerging from the surf, and from October through February, eucalyptus groves shelter thousands of migrating monarch butterflies.

activities.text: Mystery Spot - Where Gravity Gets Confused: This roadside attraction has baffled visitors since 1939 with optical illusions and seemingly impossible physical phenomena in a small patch of redwood forest. Kitsch or science experiment? You decide.

California Unveiled: From Ancient Redwoods to Desert Wonders - The Ultimate Golden State Odyssey

visits.text: Santa Fe Plaza — adobe architecture, museums, and art galleries; try green chile stew at sunset.
Return via Chimayó Sanctuary; local weaving villages en route to Santa Fe.
Santa Fe Plaza — architecture adobe, musées et galeries d'art ; goûtez le ragoût de piment vert au coucher du soleil.
Retour via Chimayó Sanctuary ; villages de tissage locaux en route vers Santa Fe.

Marvel at Saint Francis Cathedral Basilica, a magnificent Romanesque Revival structure whose beautiful interior and stunning stained glass windows create an atmosphere of profound peace and artistic grandeur. The cathedral stands as the spiritual heart of Santa Fe and represents one of the finest examples of ecclesiastical architecture in the American Southwest.

Visit the Loretto Chapel, renowned for its mysterious spiral staircase that appears to defy architectural principles, constructed without any central support and using only wooden pegs. Legend attributes its creation to a mysterious carpenter who appeared to answer the sisters' prayers and vanished without payment upon completion. The tiny chapel and its miraculous staircase draw visitors from around the world.

Discover Santa Fe, the state capital and one of America's oldest cities, where 400 years of history blend Spanish colonial, Pueblo, and contemporary influences into a vibrant cultural tapestry. The historic Plaza serves as the heart of the city, surrounded by adobe architecture housing world-class galleries, museums, and artisan shops. Among the oldest churches and houses in the United States stand alongside progressive contemporary spaces.

Experience Meow Wolf, Santa Fe's groundbreaking immersive art installation that has redefined interactive entertainment and artistic expression. This vast, otherworldly environment invites visitors to explore fantastical rooms, hidden passages, and mysterious narratives created by a collective of local artists. The experience represents the counterculture spirit that has attracted creative minds to Santa Fe since the 1960s.

days_plan.itin_title: NEW MEXICO HIGH DESERT LOOP — SANTA FE, BANDELIER, VALLES CALDERA & TAOS
NEW MEXICO HIGH DESERT LOOP — SANTA FE, BANDELIER, VALLES CALDERA & TAOS

activities.text: Stroll through Santa Fe's central Plaza, the historic heart of America's oldest capital city, surrounded by stunning adobe architecture, vibrant street performers, and exceptional artisan galleries. The plaza has served as the city's commercial and cultural center since its founding in 1610, making it one of the most historically significant public spaces in the United States.

Explore the Railyard Park district, where preserved railway heritage meets contemporary arts and culture in a revitalized urban space. Old railway details and industrial architecture provide atmospheric backdrops for galleries, markets, and community gatherings that celebrate Santa Fe's creative spirit.

Sample Santa Fe's celebrated cuisine, which has earned recognition as some of the finest in New Mexico, featuring distinctive chile-forward flavors and innovative interpretations of traditional Southwestern dishes. The city's culinary scene reflects its multicultural heritage, blending Native American, Spanish, Mexican, and contemporary American influences. Farm-to-table dining and historic chile-roasting traditions create unforgettable gastronomic experiences.
