days_plan.itin_title: ROUTE 66 IN 14 DAYS: FROM CHICAGO TO THE PACIFIC

visits.text: Sarasota - Where Beach Vibes Meet Big City Culture: This Gulf Coast gem combines laid-back coastal living with world-class cultural institutions, creating an unusually sophisticated beach destination.

The Ringling - A Compound of Museums Celebrating Art and Circus: John Ringling's legacy includes his massive art collection, the Museum of the Circus, and Ca' d'Zan-his lavish Venetian Gothic mansion overlooking Sarasota Bay.

Siesta Key - America's Best Beach Sand: The quartz crystal sand of Siesta Key Beach stays remarkably cool even in blazing heat, a unique quality that has earned it 'best beach' titles from numerous publications.
Lido Beach - Siesta's Quieter Neighbor: Less crowded but equally beautiful, Lido Key offers a more laid-back alternative with the same stunning Gulf water.

St. Armands Circle - Upscale Shopping in a Garden Setting: This circular shopping district features upscale boutiques, galleries, and restaurants arranged around a beautifully landscaped central park.

activities.text: Siesta Key Village - Beachside Bohemia: Browse surf shops, sample local brews at hole-in-the-wall bars, and soak up the relaxed atmosphere of this beloved beach community.

days_plan.itin_title: Florida Unveiled: From Pristine Barrier Islands to Tropical Keys - The Ultimate Sunshine State Adventure

visits.text: Fall under the spell of Savannah, one of America's most enchanting cities, where cobblestone streets wind past 22 oak-shaded squares draped in Spanish moss beneath grand antebellum mansions. Founded in 1733, the city's original grid plan created the intimate green spaces that define its romantic character today. The blend of architectural styles spanning three centuries creates streetscapes of extraordinary beauty and historical significance.

Explore the hauntingly beautiful Bonaventure Cemetery, where ornate Victorian monuments and moss-draped oaks create an atmosphere of melancholic grandeur overlooking the Wilmington River. The oak-canopied avenue through Wormsloe Historic Site, lined with 400 live oaks planted in the 1890s, ranks among the most photographed roads in the American South. The elegant Mercer-Williams House offers tours through Savannah's storied past.

activities.text: Stroll along River Street where historic cotton warehouses now house eclectic shops, restaurants, and lively entertainment venues overlooking the Savannah River. Sunset paddlewheel cruises offer views of the brick waterfront accompanied by live jazz and Southern cuisine. Ghost tours after dark reveal the city's supernatural reputation as one of America's most haunted destinations.

Wander through the lush landscapes of Forsyth Park, anchored by an iconic 1858 fountain modeled after fountains in Paris and Cusco. The 30-acre park provides a green oasis for picnics, concerts, and people-watching beneath centuries-old trees. The surrounding Victorian district features some of Savannah's finest residential architecture.

days_plan.itin_title: Georgia Grand Circle: Mountains, Historic Cities and Golden Isles

visits.text: Pike Place Market — Explore America's oldest continuously operating public market founded in 1907, where fishmongers toss salmon and vendors sell fresh flowers, artisan cheeses, and local crafts. The nine-acre complex contains over 225 businesses across multiple levels descending toward Elliott Bay.

Space Needle — Ascend 184 meters to the observation deck of Seattle's iconic 1962 World's Fair landmark designed by John Graham & Company. The rotating glass floor and 360-degree views encompass Puget Sound, Mount Rainier, the Cascades, and the Olympic Mountains.

Chihuly Garden and Glass — Marvel at Dale Chihuly's spectacular blown glass sculptures displayed in indoor galleries and outdoor garden beneath the Space Needle. The Glasshouse centerpiece features a 30-meter suspended sculpture of red, orange, and yellow forms.

Seattle Art Museum — Discover collections spanning ancient to contemporary art in this downtown museum founded in 1933. The building by Robert Venturi houses Northwest Coast Native art, European paintings, and contemporary installations across 312,000 square feet.

Museum of Flight — Explore the largest independent air and space museum on the West Coast with over 175 aircraft and spacecraft. Highlights include the original Air Force One, a Concorde, and the Space Shuttle Trainer housed in six connected buildings.

Ballard Locks — Watch boats navigate between Puget Sound and Lake Union through this engineering marvel completed in 1917. The fish ladder allows visitors to observe salmon migrating upstream while ship traffic passes through massive lock chambers.

Fremont neighborhood — Discover Seattle's self-proclaimed Center of the Universe featuring quirky public art including the Fremont Troll sculpture under the Aurora Bridge. Vintage shops, brewpubs, and Sunday markets create bohemian atmosphere.
Seattle waterfront and Pike Place warm‑up; ferry timings for tomorrow.
Return to Seattle; optional museum stop and departure buffer.
Return toward Seattle along Hood Canal or ferry via Bainbridge (schedule‑dependent).
Return trip to Seattle

Pike Place Market — Explorez le plus ancien marché public en activité continue d'Amérique fondé en 1907, où les poissonniers lancent le saumon et les vendeurs vendent des fleurs fraîches, des fromages artisanaux et de l'artisanat local. Le complexe de neuf acres contient plus de 225 commerces sur plusieurs niveaux descendant vers Elliott Bay.

Space Needle — Montez 184 mètres jusqu'à la plateforme d'observation de ce monument emblématique de l'Exposition universelle de 1962 de Seattle, conçu par John Graham & Company. Le plancher de verre rotatif et les vues à 360 degrés englobent Puget Sound, le mont Rainier, les Cascades et les montagnes Olympiques.

Chihuly Garden and Glass — Émerveillez-vous devant les spectaculaires sculptures de verre soufflé de Dale Chihuly exposées dans les galeries intérieures et le jardin extérieur sous la Space Needle. La pièce maîtresse de la Glasshouse présente une sculpture suspendue de 30 mètres aux formes rouges, orange et jaunes.

Seattle Art Museum — Découvrez des collections allant de l'art ancien à l'art contemporain dans ce musée du centre-ville fondé en 1933. Le bâtiment de Robert Venturi abrite l'art amérindien de la côte Nord-Ouest, des peintures européennes et des installations contemporaines sur 312 000 pieds carrés.

Museum of Flight — Explorez le plus grand musée aéronautique et spatial indépendant de la côte ouest avec plus de 175 avions et vaisseaux spatiaux. Les points forts incluent l'Air Force One original, un Concorde, et le simulateur de la navette spatiale abrités dans six bâtiments connectés.

Ballard Locks — Observez les bateaux naviguer entre Puget Sound et Lake Union à travers cette merveille d'ingénierie achevée en 1917. L'échelle à poissons permet aux visiteurs d'observer les saumons remontant le courant tandis que le trafic maritime passe par d'immenses chambres d'écluses.

Quartier de Fremont — Découvrez le centre autoproclamé de l'univers de Seattle avec son art public excentrique incluant la sculpture du Fremont Troll sous l'Aurora Bridge. Les boutiques vintage, brasseries artisanales et marchés dominicaux créent une atmosphère bohème.
Front de mer de Seattle et échauffement à Pike Place ; horaires des ferrys pour demain.
Retour à Seattle ; arrêt optionnel au musée et marge de temps pour le départ.
Retour vers Seattle le long de Hood Canal ou ferry via Bainbridge (selon l'horaire).

activities.text: Original Starbucks visit — Sip coffee at the first Starbucks opened in 1971 at Pike Place Market, maintaining its original brown mermaid logo. The flagship store preserves the company's coffee roasting heritage before global expansion.

Underground Tour — Descend beneath Pioneer Square streets to explore the buried 1890s city preserved after the Great Seattle Fire of 1889. Guided tours reveal original storefronts and sidewalks now one story underground after street levels were raised.

Waterfront evening stroll — Walk along Elliott Bay past the Seattle Great Wheel and ferry terminals as the sun sets behind the Olympic Mountains. The revitalized waterfront features restaurants, shops, and public art with Puget Sound views.

Coffee culture tour — Visit specialty roasters and cafes showcasing Seattle's coffee obsession beyond Starbucks. Third-wave coffee shops emphasize single-origin beans, pour-over methods, and latte art.

Sunset cruise on Puget Sound — Glide past islands, ferries, and container ships as the Olympics turn pink in alpenglow. Evening cruises offer views of the Seattle skyline illuminated against mountain silhouettes.
Ferry timing check for Olympic crossing later in trip.
Time buffer and city dining.

Visite du Starbucks original — Dégustez un café au premier Starbucks ouvert en 1971 au Pike Place Market, conservant son logo original de sirène brune. Le magasin phare préserve l'héritage de torréfaction de café de l'entreprise avant son expansion mondiale.

Underground Tour — Descendez sous les rues de Pioneer Square pour explorer la ville enterrée des années 1890 préservée après le Grand incendie de Seattle de 1889. Les visites guidées révèlent les devantures de magasins et trottoirs originaux maintenant un étage sous terre après que les niveaux de rue ont été surélevés.

Promenade nocturne sur le front de mer — Marchez le long d'Elliott Bay en passant devant la Seattle Great Wheel et les terminaux de ferry alors que le soleil se couche derrière les montagnes Olympiques. Le front de mer revitalisé propose restaurants, boutiques et art public avec vues sur Puget Sound.

Circuit de la culture du café — Visitez des torréfacteurs spécialisés et des cafés mettant en valeur l'obsession de Seattle pour le café au-delà de Starbucks. Les cafés de troisième vague mettent l'accent sur les grains d'origine unique, les méthodes de versement et l'art du latte.

Croisière au coucher du soleil sur Puget Sound — Glissez près des îles, ferries et porte-conteneurs tandis que les Olympics se teintent de rose dans l'alpenglow. Les croisières du soir offrent des vues sur la skyline de Seattle illuminée contre les silhouettes des montagnes.
Vérification des horaires de ferry pour la traversée vers Olympic plus tard dans le voyage.
Temps tampon et restauration en ville.

visits.text: Make a sweet pit stop at Alabama's Peach Capital, where the whimsical Peach Water Tower rises above Interstate 65 like a giant fruit beckoning travelers to pull over. At Headley's Big Peach farm shop, bins overflow with fragrant just-picked peaches while freezers stock peachy popsicles in multiple mouthwatering flavors. Nearby, Peach Park and Durbin Farms Market compete for visitors with peach cobblers, preserves, and ice cream that capture summer in every spoonful.

Begin your Selma pilgrimage at the Interpretive Center nestled at the foot of the Edmund Pettus Bridge, where rangers and volunteers share the full story of the 1965 Voting Rights marches. Audio-visual displays and artifacts bring those turbulent days to vivid life, from the planning sessions at local churches to the violent confrontation on Bloody Sunday. This marks the official start of the Selma to Montgomery National Historic Trail.

Walk across the Edmund Pettus Bridge, feeling history beneath your feet on the same span where marchers for voting rights were beaten back by state troopers on March 7, 1965. The images of Bloody Sunday, broadcast worldwide, shocked America's conscience and galvanized support for the Voting Rights Act. Two subsequent marches followed, culminating in 25,000 people completing the 54-mile journey to Montgomery's Capitol steps.

Enter the twin-towered Brown Chapel AME Church, the spiritual and strategic headquarters where Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and fellow organizers planned their nonviolent campaign for the ballot. Marchers assembled here before crossing the bridge, and wounded protestors returned here for aid after being tear-gassed and clubbed. The monument to Dr. King at the church entrance honors his pivotal role in the struggle.

Step back into antebellum elegance at Sturdivant Hall, a magnificent Greek Revival mansion built in 1852 that showcases the wealth generated by Alabama's cotton economy. Columned porticos and graceful proportions frame rooms filled with period antiques and fine art, while the old kitchen houses a gift shop brimming with Southern treasures. The manicured gardens offer a peaceful contrast to the weighty history elsewhere in Selma.

activities.text: Drive slowly through Selma's Old Town Historic District, where antebellum mansions line quiet streets shaded by ancient oaks draped in Spanish moss. Though some homes show their age, the architectural grandeur hints at the prosperity this river port once enjoyed as a center for cotton shipping and Confederate manufacturing. Each columned porch and wrought-iron balcony tells a story of the complicated South.

days_plan.itin_title: Alabama Deep South Discovery - Civil Rights, Music Heritage & Gulf Coast Paradise

visits.text: Drive or rail along Turnagain Arm to Seward with mountains and tidal flats.
Kenai Fjords boat tour — tidewater glaciers, whales, puffins, and rugged headlands.

Jour 1: Alaska SeaLife Center - This marine research facility and public aquarium in Seward provides close encounters with Alaska's marine wildlife, including Steller sea lions, harbor seals, sea otters, and seabirds like puffins and murres. The center conducts important research on marine ecosystems and wildlife rehabilitation.

Jour 1: Exit Glacier - The only road-accessible portion of Kenai Fjords National Park features trails leading directly to the face of this actively retreating glacier. The 0.8-mile trail to the glacier face passes markers showing the ice's position in previous years, dramatically illustrating glacial recession. The strenuous Harding Icefield Trail climbs 3,500 feet over 8.2 miles to views of the vast ice field feeding Exit Glacier and dozens of others.

Jour 1: Seward Historic Waterfront - This picturesque port town at the head of Resurrection Bay was established in 1903 as the ocean terminus of the Alaska Railroad. The small boat harbor, galleries, and historic buildings reflect the community's fishing heritage and role as gateway to Kenai Fjords.

Jour 2: Kenai Fjords National Park - This 670,000-acre park protects the Harding Icefield, one of the four largest ice caps in the United States, and the spectacular coastal fjords carved by its glaciers. Tidewater glaciers calving into the sea create a landscape of extraordinary beauty and ecological richness.

Jour 2: Holgate Glacier and Aialik Bay - Full-day cruises venture deep into the park's fjords to witness massive tidewater glaciers actively calving icebergs into the sea. The thunderous crack and splash of ice breaking from glacier faces creates one of nature's most dramatic spectacles.

Jour 2: Northwestern Fjord - Extended cruises reach this remote arm of the park, where multiple glaciers flow from the Harding Icefield and wildlife viewing opportunities multiply with distance from Seward.
Conduire ou prendre le train le long de Turnagain Arm vers Seward avec montagnes et vasières.
Excursion en bateau dans les fjords de Kenai — glaciers de marée, baleines, macareux et caps escarpés.

Jour 1: Resurrection Bay Kayaking - The protected waters of the bay offer excellent paddling with mountain and glacier views, wildlife observation opportunities, and access to remote beaches and coves.

Jour 2: Kenai Fjords Wildlife Cruise - Half and full-day boat tours explore the park's coastal ecosystems, with regular sightings of humpback whales, orcas, sea otters, Steller sea lions, and harbor seals. Seabird colonies host thousands of puffins, cormorants, and kittiwakes on rocky islands and cliffs.

Jour 2: Fishing Charters - The nutrient-rich waters of Resurrection Bay and adjacent Gulf of Alaska support excellent fishing for halibut, salmon (kings, silvers, and sockeye), lingcod, and rockfish throughout the summer season.

visits.text: Walk the hallowed grounds of Shiloh National Military Park, one of the best-preserved Civil War battlefields in America, where nearly 110,000 soldiers clashed over two bloody April days in 1862. This 4,000-acre memorial preserves the site of one of the war's first major conflicts, resulting in 23,746 casualties-more than all previous American wars combined. The 12.7-mile self-guided auto tour stops at 22 significant landmarks, while the museum displays artifacts and tells the human stories behind the staggering statistics.

days_plan.itin_title: Tennessee's Musical Soul & Mountain Majesty - From Memphis Blues to Smoky Mountain Mists

visits.text: Behold Tsé Bitʼaʼí (Shiprock), a dramatic volcanic rock formation rising over 1,500 feet above the surrounding desert plain on Navajo Nation land. This sacred site holds profound spiritual significance to the Navajo people, who consider it a place of great power and cultural importance. The jagged peak and radiating dikes create one of the most distinctive natural landmarks in the American Southwest.

Learn about the geological and cultural significance of this ancient volcanic neck, the eroded remnant of a volcano that erupted approximately 27 million years ago. The formation's English name derives from its resemblance to a 19th-century clipper ship, while Navajo traditions associate it with a great bird that carried their ancestors to safety. Photography from surrounding viewpoints captures the monument's dramatic presence against endless desert skies.

activities.text: Experience the vast landscapes of the Navajo Nation, the largest Native American reservation in the United States, where traditional culture and natural beauty interweave across millions of acres of high desert terrain. Respect for sacred sites and Navajo customs enriches any visit to this remarkable region.

visits.text: Discover Silver City, a historic mining town nestled at the foot of the Mogollon Mountains where Victorian-era architecture houses a thriving arts community. The Western New Mexico University Museum contains one of the world's largest collections of medieval-era Mimbres pottery and other pre-colonization Indigenous artifacts. The Grant County Art Guild Gallery showcases contemporary works by 35 local artists working in diverse media.

Venture into Gila National Forest, the vast mountain wilderness surrounding Silver City where experienced hikers can tackle challenging trails ascending Bear Mountain or connecting to the Continental Divide Trail via Black Peak. The forest encompasses over 3.3 million acres of rugged terrain ranging from desert lowlands to forested peaks exceeding 10,000 feet. Wildlife including elk, black bears, and mountain lions inhabit these remote ranges.

activities.text: Explore downtown Silver City's Bullard Street district, where locally-owned galleries, shops, and studios occupy restored Victorian buildings dating to the town's silver mining heyday. The creative community has transformed this former frontier outpost into a vibrant arts destination while preserving its authentic Western character. Annual arts festivals and studio tours celebrate the town's artistic renaissance.

The Memorial Plaza leads to the Wall of Names, where 40 white marble slabs mark the final resting place of those who chose to fight back. Listen for the haunting wind chimes of the 93-foot Tower of Voices, each of 40 chimes representing a voice silenced but never forgotten.

visits.text: Marvel at the tallest waterfall east of the Mississippi River at Fall Creek Falls State Park, where the namesake cascade plunges 256 feet in a single breathtaking drop. Tennessee's second-largest state park encompasses 56 miles of hiking trails leading to multiple waterfalls including Cane Creek Falls, Rockhouse Falls, and Piney Falls, each offering unique perspectives on the power of water sculpting stone over millennia.

Discover the twin jewels of Rock Island State Park, where Great Falls and Twin Falls reward hikers with stunning cascade views along trails winding through one of Tennessee's most scenic landscapes. The park's nine trails range from moderate to strenuous, offering waterfall chasers multiple perspectives on the Caney Fork River as it tumbles through rocky gorges.

Challenge yourself on the legendary Fiery Gizzard Trail in South Cumberland State Park, named one of America's top 25 hikes by Backpacker Magazine. This strenuous trail traverses dramatic gorges, passes thundering waterfalls, and crosses unique rock formations that showcase the geological wonders of the Cumberland Plateau-a true bucket-list trek for serious hikers.

visits.text: Begin your Appalachian Trail experience at Springer Mountain, the legendary southern terminus of the 2,190-mile footpath stretching to Maine. Georgia's 79-mile section winds through misty forests, wildflower meadows, rhododendron tunnels, and offers spectacular panoramic overlooks. Standing at the bronze plaque marking Mile Zero creates a profound connection to one of America's greatest hiking traditions.

Trek to Blood Mountain, the highest point on Georgia's Appalachian Trail at 4,458 feet, where ancient stone shelter ruins and sweeping ridge views reward determined hikers. The challenging terrain passes through diverse ecosystems supporting black bears, deer, salamanders, and countless songbirds. Backcountry camping sites offer stargazing far from light pollution.

activities.text: Visit the legendary Mountain Crossings outfitter at Neel Gap, the only building the Appalachian Trail passes directly through. The famous 'shoe tree' outside displays worn-out hiking boots left by through-hikers, many containing handwritten notes and memories. Detour to misty Long Creek Falls for a serene waterfall tucked into the forest.

days_plan.itin_title: ROUTE 66 IN 14 DAYS: FROM CHICAGO TO THE PACIFIC

visits.text: Castillo de San Marcos — Explore America's oldest masonry fort constructed 1672-1695 from coquina limestone by Spanish colonial forces. The star-shaped fortress withstood multiple sieges with its unique shell-rock walls that absorbed cannonballs rather than shattering.

St. Augustine Lighthouse — Climb 219 steps up this 1874 lighthouse for panoramic views of America's oldest continuously occupied European settlement. The 50-meter tower's first-order Fresnel lens still guides ships along Florida's northeast coast.

Colonial Quarter — Walk through four centuries of St. Augustine history in this living history museum. Costumed interpreters demonstrate blacksmithing, leather working, and colonial crafts in reconstructed 16th-18th century buildings.

St. George Street — Stroll this pedestrian-only colonial thoroughfare lined with Spanish architecture housing galleries, restaurants, and shops. The brick-paved street retains its historic character with balconies, courtyards, and gas lanterns.

St. Augustine - The Oldest City in America: Founded in 1565, this remarkable city predates the Pilgrims by 55 years. Cobblestone streets wind past architecture spanning five centuries, from Spanish Colonial to Gilded Age grandeur.

Castillo de San Marcos - The Oldest Masonry Fort in the Continental United States: This Spanish fortress, built between 1672 and 1695 using native coquina shell stone, has never been captured despite numerous sieges. The unique shell construction actually absorbed cannonballs rather than shattering.

Oldest Wooden Schoolhouse - Education in Colonial America: Dating to the early 1700s, this remarkably preserved structure offers insight into schooling during Spanish rule, with original cypress and cedar construction still intact.

Castillo de San Marcos — Explorez le plus ancien fort en maçonnerie d'Amérique construit de 1672 à 1695 en calcaire coquina par les forces coloniales espagnoles. La forteresse en forme d'étoile a résisté à de multiples sièges grâce à ses murs uniques en roche coquillière qui absorbaient les boulets de canon plutôt que de se briser.

Phare de St. Augustine — Gravissez 219 marches de ce phare de 1874 pour des vues panoramiques sur la plus ancienne colonie européenne continuellement occupée d'Amérique. La lentille de Fresnel du premier ordre de cette tour de 50 mètres guide encore les navires le long de la côte nord-est de la Floride.

Colonial Quarter — Traversez quatre siècles d'histoire de St. Augustine dans ce musée d'histoire vivante. Des interprètes en costume démontrent la forge, le travail du cuir et l'artisanat colonial dans des bâtiments reconstruits des XVIe-XVIIIe siècles.

St. George Street — Flânez dans cette artère coloniale réservée aux piétons bordée d'architecture espagnole abritant galeries, restaurants et boutiques. La rue pavée de briques conserve son caractère historique avec ses balcons, cours intérieures et lanternes à gaz.

activities.text: Fountain of Youth Archaeological Park — Visit the legendary spring where Ponce de León supposedly searched for eternal youth in 1513. The 15-acre park preserves the Timucua Native American village site and Spanish colonial artifacts.

Ghost tour of historic district — Join an evening walking tour through shadowy streets hearing tales of pirates, soldiers, and spirits haunting America's oldest city. Guides recount 450 years of history in the candlelit colonial quarter.

Sunset at the Old City Gates — Watch the sun set through the reconstructed 1739 entrance gates to the colonial city. The coquina pillars frame views down St. George Street as the historic district glows in golden light.

Hop-On Hop-Off Trolley Tours - Centuries of History at Your Pace: Navigate between dozens of historic sites aboard trolleys that connect the city's Spanish Quarter, lighthouse, fort, and Flagler College-a stunning former luxury hotel.
St. George Street - The Heart of Historic St. Augustine: Stroll this pedestrian-only thoroughfare lined with shops, restaurants, and historic buildings dating back centuries.

Parc archéologique de la Fontaine de Jouvence — Visitez la source légendaire où Ponce de León aurait cherché la jeunesse éternelle en 1513. Le parc de 15 acres préserve le site du village amérindien Timucua et des artefacts coloniaux espagnols.

Visite fantôme du quartier historique — Participez à une visite pédestre nocturne dans les rues ombragées en écoutant des histoires de pirates, soldats et esprits hantant la plus ancienne ville d'Amérique. Les guides racontent 450 ans d'histoire dans le quartier colonial éclairé aux chandelles.

Coucher de soleil aux anciennes portes de la ville — Regardez le soleil se coucher à travers les portes d'entrée reconstruites de 1739 de la ville coloniale. Les piliers en coquina encadrent les vues sur St. George Street tandis que le quartier historique brille d'une lumière dorée.

visits.text: St. Petersburg - The Sunshine City: This bayside community consistently breaks records for consecutive sunny days, combining beach-town relaxation with an increasingly sophisticated arts scene.

The Dalí Museum - The World's Most Comprehensive Salvador Dalí Collection: This striking waterfront museum houses over 2,400 works by the surrealist master, including seven of his 18 monumental 'masterwork' paintings.
St. Pete Murals - An Open-Air Gallery: Over 700 murals transform the city into one of America's largest outdoor art exhibitions, with new works constantly appearing on buildings throughout downtown.
The Don CeSar - The Pink Palace of St. Pete Beach: This iconic 1928 resort, painted its distinctive Pepto-Bismol pink, has hosted everyone from F. Scott Fitzgerald to Franklin D. Roosevelt.
Fort De Soto Park - Five Interconnected Islands of Paradise: This 1,136-acre park on Tampa Bay's southern tip offers camping, fishing, hiking, and some of the most beautiful beaches in Florida.

visits.text: Explore St. Simons Island, the largest of Georgia's Golden Isles, where wide golden beaches, moss-draped oaks, shimmering salt marshes, and charming village atmosphere create quintessential coastal Georgia scenery. The historic lighthouse dating to 1872 offers panoramic views from its tower after climbing 129 steps. Over 30 miles of bike paths wind past tree spirits carved into ancient oaks by local artists.

Visit Fort Frederica National Monument, the substantial ruins of a colonial-era British fortification established in 1736 to defend against Spanish incursion from Florida. The moss-covered walls and archaeological excavations reveal 18th-century military life on the frontier. Cannon's Point Preserve offers hiking through wild maritime forest where salty marsh aromas drift on ocean breezes.

activities.text: Relax on sunlit East Beach, browse boutiques and galleries in the charming Pier Village, and watch spectacular sunsets paint the marshlands in brilliant colors. The island's laid-back atmosphere invites visitors to slow down and embrace the gentle rhythms of Georgia's coast.

visits.text: Return toward Anchorage then north to Talkeetna; clear‑day Denali views possible.

Talkeetna Historic District - This charming frontier village at the confluence of three rivers has served as the traditional base camp for Denali climbers since the early 1900s. The compact Main Street preserves authentic gold rush-era architecture, with original wooden storefronts now housing local artisans and outfitters. Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, the town offers an authentic glimpse into Alaska's pioneering heritage.
Retour vers Anchorage puis nord vers Talkeetna ; vues possibles sur Denali par temps clair.

activities.text: Talkeetna Main Street and river confluence walk.

Denali Flightseeing - Experience breathtaking aerial views of North America's highest peak and the surrounding Alaska Range. Small aircraft circle massive glaciers, navigate between towering granite spires, and offer perspectives of Denali's 20,310-foot summit that few ever witness. Weather permitting, glacier landings provide the opportunity to step onto ancient ice fields.

Susitna River Rafting - Float through pristine wilderness where the Susitna, Talkeetna, and Chulitna rivers converge. These glacially-fed waterways wind through boreal forest with views of the Alaska Range, offering opportunities to spot moose, eagles, and salmon depending on the season.

Talkeetna Zipline Tours - Soar above the Talkeetna River valley on aerial cables stretching through old-growth spruce forest, with panoramic mountain views serving as the backdrop to this elevated wilderness experience.

visits.text: Marvel at Tallulah Gorge, a dramatic 2-mile-long chasm plunging nearly 1,000 feet deep where five magnificent waterfalls cascade over ancient rock formations. A suspension bridge spans the gorge 80 feet above the rushing Tallulah River, providing heart-stopping views of the canyon walls and roaring cascades. Free permits allow adventurous hikers to descend to the gorge floor for an intimate encounter with this geological wonder.

Explore over 20 miles of hiking and biking trails radiating from the gorge rim, each offering different perspectives of the dramatic landscape carved over millennia by rushing waters. The park's historic dam and interpretive center document the area's role in early hydroelectric development. Overlooks along the rim trail provide photographers with stunning compositions of waterfalls and canyon walls.

activities.text: Experience the exhilarating natural waterslide at Sliding Rock, where smooth granite channels visitors into refreshing plunge pools surrounded by moss-covered boulders and echoing canyon walls. The nearby lake beach offers calmer swimming for those seeking relaxation after gorge adventures.

days_plan.itin_title: Georgia Grand Circle: Mountains, Historic Cities and Golden Isles

visits.text: Tampa Bay - Where Theme Parks Meet Championship Sports: This Gulf Coast metropolis combines world-class attractions with a thriving food and drink scene that rivals any city in Florida.

Busch Gardens Tampa Bay - Theme Park Meets World-Class Zoo: This unique combination of African wildlife preserve and thrill ride destination features one of the country's best roller coaster collections alongside remarkable animal habitats.

Historic Ybor City - Tampa's Latin Quarter Since 1885: Once the cigar capital of the world, this National Historic Landmark District preserves Cuban, Spanish, and Italian heritage through architecture, restaurants, and the ongoing cigar-rolling tradition.
Tampa Riverwalk - 2.6 Miles of Waterfront Wonder: This continuous pedestrian path connects downtown museums, parks, restaurants, and attractions along the Hillsborough River and Tampa Bay.

activities.text: Tampa Craft Beer Trail - Florida's Brewing Capital: Pioneering breweries like Cigar City and Coppertail have established Tampa Bay as a craft beer destination, with dozens of taprooms offering local brews.
Tampa Bay Sports - Championship Caliber: Home to the NFL's Buccaneers and NHL's Lightning-both recent champions-the region offers professional sports events year-round.

Florida Unveiled: From Pristine Barrier Islands to Tropical Keys - The Ultimate Sunshine State Adventure

visits.text: Valles Caldera National Preserve — volcanic caldera meadows and elk herds; then north through Española to Taos Pueblo (UNESCO).
Belvédère du Rio Grande Gorge Bridge, High Road to Taos artisans, et promenade historique sur la Plaza.
Valles Caldera National Preserve — prairies de caldeira volcanique et troupeaux d'élans ; puis vers le nord par Española jusqu'à Taos Pueblo (UNESCO).

Experience Taos Pueblo, a UNESCO World Heritage Site with over 1,000 years of continuous habitation, representing one of the oldest continuously inhabited communities in North America. The remarkable multi-story adobe structures, some reaching five stories, have been home to the Tiwa-speaking Puebloan people since before European contact. Visitors can explore the living village and learn about traditions that have survived for a millennium.

Discover the quaint mountain town of Taos, nestled beneath stunning peaks and surrounded by artistic heritage that has attracted creative spirits for over a century. The surrounding Wheeler Peak Wilderness Area offers challenging hiking and skiing opportunities with breathtaking views from New Mexico's highest summit at 13,167 feet.

Visit Taos Pueblo, the UNESCO World Heritage Site that stands as one of the oldest continuously inhabited communities in the world, where Tiwa Puebloan traditions have been preserved for over 1,000 years. The remarkable multi-story adobe structures, some reaching five stories, have housed generations of the Pueblo people since before European contact. Guided tours provide respectful access to this living community and its sacred traditions.

Explore the Millicent Rogers Museum, showcasing over 7,000 artifacts spanning centuries of Native American and Hispanic artistic traditions including jewelry, pottery, textiles, and paintings. The Harwood Museum of Art houses another 6,500 works representing local and regional artists from the 18th century to the present. Together, these institutions reveal why Taos has attracted artists and collectors for generations.

activities.text: Experience the thrill of rafting down the Rio Grande through rugged, wild terrain where the river has carved dramatic gorges through the volcanic landscape. Outfitters offer trips ranging from gentle floats to challenging whitewater adventures through some of the most spectacular canyon scenery in the Southwest. The Rio Grande del Norte National Monument protects this remarkable landscape for future generations.

Stand at the Rio Grande Gorge Bridge, where the dramatic chasm plunges 650 feet below the roadway, creating one of the most photographed scenic viewpoints in New Mexico. The gorge provides spectacular photo opportunities, particularly at sunrise and sunset when shadows emphasize the depth and texture of the volcanic rock walls. Trails descend into the gorge for closer exploration of this geological wonder.

Take a tour of the Earthships community near Taos Mesa, a collection of self-sustaining, off-grid dwellings constructed from recycled materials that have attracted international attention for sustainable living innovation. These distinctive structures generate their own electricity, collect water, and maintain comfortable temperatures year-round without conventional utilities. The community demonstrates practical applications of radical environmental design.

visits.text: Kayak exploration of the mangroves and coastal bird watching.

activities.text: Bike ride between the beaches and the sanctuary along the Key Largo coast.

days_plan.itin_title: ONE-WEEK ADVENTURE IN THE FLORIDA KEYS – FROM KEY LARGO TO KEY WEST

visits.text: Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park — Peer into this narrow gorge plunging 823 meters where the Gunnison River carved through 2-billion-year-old Precambrian rock. Sheer cliffs create one of North America's most dramatic canyons at only 335 meters wide at the rim.

Telluride Historic District — Walk through this Victorian mining town nestled in a box canyon at 2,667 meters elevation. The entire town is a National Historic Landmark with colorful buildings lining Colorado Avenue beneath 4,000-meter peaks.

Bridal Veil Falls — Hike or drive to Colorado's tallest free-falling waterfall plunging 111 meters over a cliff face. The restored 1907 hydroelectric plant perches at the top while views encompass the San Juan Mountains.

New Sheridan Hotel — Visit this 1895 hotel where William Jennings Bryan delivered his famous Cross of Gold speech from the bar. The restored property maintains its Victorian grandeur with period furnishings and mountain views.

Parc national Black Canyon of the Gunnison — Contemplez cette gorge étroite plongeant de 823 mètres où la rivière Gunnison s'est taillé un passage dans la roche précambrienne vieille de 2 milliards d'années. Des falaises abruptes créent l'un des canyons les plus spectaculaires d'Amérique du Nord, large de seulement 335 mètres au bord.

District historique de Telluride — Promenez-vous dans cette ville minière victorienne nichée dans un canyon en cul-de-sac à 2 667 mètres d'altitude. La ville entière est un monument historique national avec des bâtiments colorés alignés sur Colorado Avenue sous des pics de 4 000 mètres.

Bridal Veil Falls — Randonnez ou conduisez jusqu'à la plus haute chute d'eau en chute libre du Colorado, plongeant de 111 mètres sur une paroi rocheuse. La centrale hydroélectrique restaurée de 1907 se perche au sommet tandis que les vues embrassent les montagnes San Juan.

New Sheridan Hotel — Visitez cet hôtel de 1895 où William Jennings Bryan a prononcé son célèbre discours Cross of Gold depuis le bar. La propriété restaurée conserve sa grandeur victorienne avec du mobilier d'époque et des vues sur les montagnes.

activities.text: Free gondola ride — Glide 3.7 kilometers between Telluride and Mountain Village in North America's longest free public transportation system. The 13-minute journey offers spectacular views over the valley and surrounding peaks.

Mountain Village exploration — Stroll through this European-style resort village at 2,957 meters featuring ski-in/ski-out lodging, restaurants, and mountain activities. The planned development contrasts with historic Telluride below.

Sunset at Wilson Peak — Watch alpenglow illuminate this 4,341-meter peak featured on Coors beer cans. The distinctive pyramid shape glows pink and orange during sunset, creating unforgettable mountain photography opportunities.

Trajet en gondole gratuit — Glissez sur 3,7 kilomètres entre Telluride et Mountain Village dans le plus long système de transport public gratuit d'Amérique du Nord. Le voyage de 13 minutes offre des vues spectaculaires sur la vallée et les sommets environnants.

Exploration de Mountain Village — Promenez-vous dans ce village de station de style européen à 2 957 mètres d'altitude offrant des hébergements ski aux pieds, des restaurants et des activités de montagne. Le développement planifié contraste avec le Telluride historique en contrebas.

Coucher de soleil au Wilson Peak — Regardez l'alpenglow illuminer ce pic de 4 341 mètres figurant sur les canettes de bière Coors. La forme pyramidale distinctive rougeoie en rose et orange pendant le coucher de soleil, créant des opportunités photographiques de montagne inoubliables.

visits.text: Temecula Valley Wine Country - Southern California's Napa: Nearly 50 wineries grow over 30 varietals in this warm-climate region, producing distinctive wines that have earned national recognition. Rolling hills dotted with oaks create a surprisingly Tuscan atmosphere.

Old Town Temecula - The Real Old West: This six-block historic district preserves 1880s wooden storefronts where cowboys once hitched their horses. Today, antique shops, restaurants, and wine tasting rooms fill the authentic buildings.

Temecula Valley Balloon & Wine Festival - Rise Above the Vines: This annual June event sends dozens of colorful hot air balloons floating over wine country, combining morning flights with wine tastings and live entertainment.

visits.text: Kansas River towns — Wamego detour possible; Topeka State Capitol tour and Brown v. Board of Education NHS for civil rights history.
Topeka - Where American History Changed Forever: Kansas's capital city preserves one of the most significant sites in the Civil Rights movement alongside stunning state architecture.

Brown v. Board of Education National Historic Site - The School That Changed America: The former Monroe Elementary School, where the landmark 1954 Supreme Court desegregation case originated, now serves as a powerful museum with a restored kindergarten classroom, compelling photographs, videos, and ranger-led programs explaining this watershed moment.

Brown v. Board Legacy Mural - 130 Feet of Civil Rights History: Directly across from Monroe Elementary, this massive mural depicts the ongoing legacy of the Supreme Court decision that ended legal segregation in American schools.

Kansas State Capitol - Taller Than Washington's Dome: This magnificent structure soars 17 feet higher than the U.S. Capitol in Washington, D.C., featuring an inner dome with 256 glass panels and a 900-pound chandelier that dazzles visitors who tilt their heads upward.

Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore — Pierce Stocking Scenic Drive’s overlooks reveal a 140‑meter drop to Lake Michigan; glacially sculpted perched dunes and Manitou island vistas.
Dune Climb — Expansive sand ramp where wind‑formed ridges meet a jack‑pine backcountry; stay on marked routes to protect fragile vegetation.
Glen Haven Historic Village — Restored 19th‑century lifesaving station, blacksmith shop, and general store illuminating Great Lakes maritime heritage.
Return to Traverse City via Petoskey and Charlevoix’s stone‑lined harbors; browse historic downtowns built on 19th‑century timber and shipping.

visits.text: Soak in the therapeutic hot springs of Truth or Consequences, a town whose unusual name dates to a 1950 radio quiz show promotion but whose healing waters have attracted visitors for centuries. The mineral-rich thermal pools scattered throughout the downtown area offer the least crowded and most affordable hot spring experiences in New Mexico. Multiple facilities provide options ranging from rustic to luxurious soaking environments.

Explore Elephant Butte Lake State Park north of town, New Mexico's largest reservoir offering excellent opportunities for hiking, biking, boating, and water sports. The lake's vast expanse and surrounding desert mountains create dramatic landscapes for outdoor recreation. The area serves as a convenient base for exploring the wild terrain of nearby Apache Kid Wilderness.

activities.text: Experience the Rio Grande riverside hot springs where thermal waters emerge directly beside the river, creating unique soaking opportunities that combine natural settings with healing mineral content. The town's relaxed atmosphere encourages extended stays focused on rest, relaxation, and rejuvenation. Local wellness practitioners complement the natural springs with massage and therapeutic services.

visits.text: Escape to Tybee Island, Savannah's laid-back beach retreat where wide sandy shores, rolling dunes, and tranquil marshlands create a carefree coastal atmosphere. The historic lighthouse, Georgia's oldest and tallest, has guided mariners since 1736 and offers panoramic views from its observation deck after climbing 178 steps. The island maintains nostalgic beach-town charm with colorful cottages and relaxed local culture.

Explore the imposing Fort Pulaski National Monument, a masterpiece of 19th-century military engineering whose massive brick walls were breached by rifled cannon during the Civil War, forever changing the course of warfare. The moated fortification and surrounding marshlands offer walking trails rich with birdlife and historical significance. Interpretive programs bring the fort's dramatic history to life.

activities.text: Swim and sunbathe at lively South Beach, spot dolphins offshore, and watch pelicans diving for fish as the sun sets over the Atlantic. The Tybee Pier and Pavilion area buzzes with activity while quieter stretches of shore provide peaceful escapes. Over 200 bird species make this island a rewarding destination for wildlife observation throughout the year.

days_plan.itin_title: Deep Louisiana: jazz, Creole history & expeditions in the bayous

visits.text: Jour 1: Worthington Glacier State Recreation Site - Located along Thompson Pass at 2,800 feet elevation, this glacier flows down from the Chugach Mountains to within easy viewing distance of the Richardson Highway. A paved trail leads to observation platforms, while more adventurous visitors can hike the two-mile Worthington Glacier Trail for closer access to the ice.

Jour 1: Bridal Veil Falls - This spectacular 900-foot cascade plunges down sheer cliffs along Keystone Canyon, visible from roadside pullouts and accessible via a mile-long trail to an overlook. The waterfall is most impressive during spring snowmelt and after summer rains.

Jour 1: Keystone Canyon - The Richardson Highway threads through this dramatic gorge carved by the Lowe River, with towering rock walls and multiple waterfalls creating one of Alaska's most scenic drives. Historic remnants of the failed Trans-Alaska Railway attempt are visible along the canyon walls.

Jour 2: Valdez Harbor and Waterfront - This ice-free port at the head of a fjord serves as the terminus of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline and a major fishing harbor. The downtown area rebuilt after the 1964 earthquake offers views of surrounding peaks rising directly from the water.

Jour 2: Prince William Sound - This island-studded waterway encompasses 15,000 square miles of protected waters, tidewater glaciers, and abundant marine wildlife. The sound's deep fjords and sheltered bays create ideal conditions for viewing sea otters, seals, sea lions, and whales.

activities.text: Jour 1: Thompson Pass Scenic Drive - The approach to Valdez crosses this 2,678-foot pass through the Chugach Mountains, an area receiving some of North America's highest snowfall totals. In summer, alpine meadows burst with wildflowers while glaciers cling to surrounding peaks.

Jour 2: Glacier Cruise - Day cruises venture into Columbia Bay to witness Columbia Glacier, one of Alaska's largest tidewater glaciers. These journeys navigate through floating icebergs while naturalists explain glacial geology and point out wildlife including puffins, kittiwakes, and marine mammals.

Jour 2: Sea Kayaking - Guided paddling excursions explore the fjords and bays surrounding Valdez, offering intimate access to marine ecosystems inaccessible by larger vessels. Multi-day expeditions reach remote glaciers and camping beaches.

Jour 2: Wildlife Viewing - Prince William Sound's nutrient-rich waters support abundant marine life, with sea otters, harbor seals, Steller sea lions, humpback whales, and orcas regularly observed. Seabird colonies host thousands of puffins, cormorants, and eagles.

visits.text: Virginia City — Step into this authentically preserved 1860s mining boomtown perched on Mount Davidson's slopes. The National Historic Landmark preserves boardwalks, Victorian buildings, and saloons from when Comstock Lode silver discovery created Nevada Territory.

The Way It Was Museum — Explore mining equipment, minerals, and artifacts explaining how the Comstock Lode produced 500 million dollars in silver and gold. The museum occupies the fourth floor of the 1876 Knights of Pythias building.

Chollar Mine — Descend into a real silver mine with original 1860s square-set timbering still supporting tunnels. Guided tours explain mining techniques that extracted precious metals from 300 meters underground.

St. Mary in the Mountains Catholic Church — Visit this 1876 Gothic Revival church built with mining wealth featuring Italian marble and stained glass. The cathedral replaced an earlier church destroyed in the Great Fire of 1875.

activities.text: C Street walking tour — Stroll the main street lined with saloons, shops, and museums occupying original 1860s buildings. Wooden boardwalks and Victorian storefronts recreate Wild West atmosphere.
Virginia & Truckee Railroad ride — Board vintage steam trains running the historic route built in 1869 to haul Comstock ore. The scenic journey passes mining ruins with mountain views.
Saloon experience — Sample local beers at authentic Old West saloons with swinging doors and antique bars. Some establishments maintain 1860s character serving spirits to modern visitors.

Mississippi River Bluffs - Massive limestone cliffs rising dramatically along the mighty Mississippi, offering spectacular viewpoints and hiking opportunities.
Viroqua - Charming creative town known for its organic farms, artisan shops, and thriving local food scene in the heart of the Driftless region.

activities.text: Kayaking the winding Kickapoo River through the Driftless Area's unique unglaciated landscape of towering bluffs and hidden valleys.

visits.text: Washington Island - Remote island accessible by ferry through Death's Door strait, known for its Scandinavian heritage and peaceful atmosphere.
Stavkirke Church - Striking wooden stave church built in traditional Norwegian style, a unique architectural gem in the Wisconsin wilderness.
Schoolhouse Beach - Unique beach covered entirely in smooth white limestone stones rather than sand, perfect for stone-skipping and beachcombing.
Nicolet Beach - Family-friendly sandy beach on the Door Peninsula with calm, shallow waters and stunning sunset views.
Rock Island State Park - Wisconsin's most remote state park, accessible only by ferry, featuring the historic Pottawatomie Lighthouse and pristine wilderness beaches.

visits.text: Explore picturesque Waynesville, sandwiched between the Great Smoky Mountains and the Blue Ridge Mountains. This charming little town in Haywood County captivates visitors with sublime mountain views and a welcoming atmosphere that embodies the spirit of Southern Appalachian hospitality.

Catch an entertaining live performance at Haywood Arts Regional Theater, where talented local and regional artists showcase their skills. This celebrated venue brings cultural enrichment to the mountain community and offers visitors an authentic taste of Appalachian arts and entertainment.

activities.text: Experience downtown Waynesville's bustling atmosphere featuring an eclectic mix of galleries, antique shops, and local boutiques. Visit Haywood's Historic Farmers Market to meet hospitable locals, sample fresh farm produce, and discover unique heritage crafts that make perfect mementos of your mountain visit.

days_plan.itin_title: IOWA ROAD TRIP - BEAUTIFUL PLACES

visits.text: Glacier National Park — Enter this 4,100-square-kilometer wilderness preserving pristine ecosystems from prairie to alpine peaks. The Crown of the Continent features 700 lakes, 25 active glaciers, and abundant wildlife including grizzlies, wolves, and mountain goats.

Going-to-the-Sun Road — Drive this engineering marvel crossing the Continental Divide at 2,026-meter Logan Pass. The 80-kilometer scenic road completed in 1932 hugs cliff faces with stunning glacier and valley views.

Lake McDonald — Photograph the park's largest lake stretching 16 kilometers with mountains reflected in pristine waters. The glacially-carved lake reaches 141 meters deep surrounded by old-growth cedar and hemlock forests.

Trail of the Cedars — Walk this wheelchair-accessible boardwalk through ancient rainforest featuring 500-year-old western red cedars. The 1.1-kilometer loop crosses Avalanche Creek on a suspension bridge.

Logan Pass — Hike from the Continental Divide summit where snow persists into July. The alpine visitor center offers exhibits and access to Hidden Lake Trail through wildflower meadows frequented by mountain goats.
Hidden Lake Overlook — Trek 4.8 kilometers roundtrip to dramatic views of turquoise Hidden Lake surrounded by peaks. The trail crosses alpine tundra revealing bighorn sheep and hoary marmots.
Jackson Glacier Overlook — View one of Glacier's most accessible glaciers from this roadside pullout. The ice field has receded significantly but remains impressive against the Continental Divide.
St. Mary Falls — Hike 2.6 kilometers through forest to this 10-meter waterfall cascading over bedrock. The trail follows Rose Creek through wildflower meadows with mountain views.

Lewis and Clark Caverns State Park — Tour Montana's largest known limestone cavern featuring stalactites, stalagmites, and helictites. The 90-minute guided walk descends into chambers carved by water over millions of years.
Gates of the Mountains — Boat through this section of the Missouri River where limestone cliffs rise 370 meters. Lewis and Clark named the formation in 1805 during their expedition upriver.
Helena historic downtown — Explore Montana's capital featuring Victorian architecture from gold rush prosperity. Last Chance Gulch preserves 1880s buildings housing shops and restaurants.

activities.text: Wildlife watching — Scan meadows and roadside for grizzly bears, black bears, bighorn sheep, and mountain goats. Early morning and evening offer best viewing opportunities along Going-to-the-Sun Road.
Apgar Village exploration — Browse visitor center exhibits, rent boats, and dine at this lakeside village. The park's west entrance hub offers services and lake access.
Scenic boat tour — Cruise historic wooden boats across pristine lakes hearing park history and geology from naturalist guides. Tours operate on Lake McDonald and St. Mary Lake.
Evening ranger program — Attend talks about grizzly bears, glaciers, or night skies at park amphitheaters. Rangers share ecological knowledge and conservation challenges.
Huckleberry treats — Sample Montana's signature berry in ice cream, pie, or jam at park lodges. Wild huckleberries ripen in late summer throughout Glacier's forests.
Scenic drive return — Navigate mountain passes and valleys back to Glacier through heart of the Rockies. The journey showcases Montana's vast wilderness and big sky.
Farewell Montana dinner — Celebrate the journey with bison ribeye or grilled trout at a mountain lodge. Montana cuisine emphasizes wild game and locally raised meats.

visits.text: West Palm Beach - Florida's Emerging Cultural Capital: This rapidly developing city has cultivated world-class dining, entertainment venues, and high-end shopping while maintaining easy access to pristine Atlantic beaches.

Palm Beach - Billionaire's Row: Across the Intracoastal Waterway, Palm Beach proper showcases some of America's most valuable real estate, with beachfront mansions owned by the nation's wealthiest families.

John D. MacArthur Beach State Park - Preserved Paradise: This barrier island park protects one of the last remaining undeveloped stretches of the Palm Beach coast, with hiking trails, kayaking, and swimming on a pristine Atlantic beach.

Norton Museum of Art - World-Class Collection in the Tropics: This recently expanded museum houses significant European, American, and Chinese art collections in stunning galleries designed for natural light.

activities.text: Jupiter - Palm Beach's Best-Kept Secret: This small northern town offers outstanding beaches, historic lighthouse tours, and a laid-back atmosphere that contrasts with Palm Beach's formality.
Delray Beach and Boca Raton - Atlantic Avenue Strolling: These neighboring beach communities offer vibrant downtown districts filled with restaurants, boutiques, and galleries steps from the ocean.

visits.text: Discover the understated elegance of Westerly, a charming waterfront community first settled in 1661 where a vibrant downtown, pristine beaches, and rich textile heritage combine to create one of Rhode Island's most appealing coastal retreats. This picturesque town has quietly attracted notable residents seeking the perfect balance of New England charm and Atlantic splendor, with tree-lined streets opening onto stunning beach vistas and a walkable downtown filled with local shops and galleries.

activities.text: Explore Westerly's beautiful beaches on foot or by bicycle, discovering hidden coves, seaside parks, and the stunning Watch Hill neighborhood where the iconic Flying Horse Carousel, the oldest operating carousel in America, has delighted children since 1867.

days_plan.itin_title: Rhode Island's Gilded Shores & Colonial Treasures - America's Smallest State, Grandest Discoveries

visits.text: Experience White Sands National Park, where the world's largest gypsum dune field creates a surreal landscape of brilliant white waves stretching across 275 square miles of the Tularosa Basin. The pristine white dunes, constantly shifting with the wind, provide an otherworldly environment unlike anywhere else on Earth. This rare ecosystem supports uniquely adapted plants and animals found nowhere else.

Walk the Interdune Boardwalk and Dune Life Nature Trail to discover how life persists in this seemingly barren landscape of pure white gypsum crystals. Interpretive signs explain the geological processes that created this remarkable feature and the adaptations that allow plants and animals to survive in such an extreme environment.

Experience White Sands National Park, where 275 square miles of brilliant white gypsum dunes create one of the most extraordinary landscapes on Earth. The crystalline sand formations shift constantly with the wind, creating an ever-changing terrain of pristine white waves rolling across the Tularosa Basin. This rare ecosystem supports uniquely adapted plants and animals found nowhere else, including species that have evolved white coloration to match their surroundings.

Hike the Interdune Boardwalk and Dune Life Nature Trail to discover how life persists in this seemingly barren landscape of pure white gypsum crystals. The trails reveal the surprising biodiversity hidden within the dune fields and explain the geological processes that created this natural wonder. The stark white landscape against deep blue desert skies creates unforgettable visual experiences.

activities.text: Sled down the pristine dunes using specially designed discs available at the visitor center, creating exhilarating descents through powdery white sand. Sunset transforms the white sands into a canvas of pink, orange, and purple hues, offering photographers extraordinary opportunities for capturing desert magic. Camping permits allow overnight stays for experiencing full moons and stargazing in one of America's darkest locations.

visits.text: Wichita - Kansas's Cultural and Culinary Capital: Five culturally rich museums line the Arkansas River, connected by a riverfront walkway that makes exploring this diverse city a pleasure.
Old Cowtown Museum - Wichita's Frontier Days Brought to Life: Costumed actors recapture the city's Wild West heritage in this living history museum, complete with period buildings and demonstrations.
Exploration Place - 10,000+ Works and 1950s Kansas in Miniature: Interactive exhibits include a miniature version of 1950s Kansas with more than 50 animations, bringing mid-century America to life.
Wichita Art Museum - American Art on the Arkansas: Over 10,000 works of American art fill this riverside institution, one of the largest art museums in the Great Plains.

Keeper of the Plains - 44 Feet of Iconic Sculpture: Local artist Blackbear Bosin's dramatic steel sculpture rises at the confluence of the Arkansas and Little Arkansas rivers, illuminated nightly by the Ring of Fire.

Mid-America All-Indian Museum - Native Heritage on Display: More works by Blackbear Bosin and extensive collections celebrating Native American art and culture await visitors to this riverside institution.

Botanica Wichita - 30+ Themed Gardens Open Year-Round: Sculptures, water features, 4,000 plant species, and a restored 1949 carousel accent this botanical garden that culminates annually with 2 million holiday lights.

activities.text: Arkansas River Walk - Connect Wichita's Cultural Treasures: Stroll, bike, or jog along the riverfront pathway linking museums, sculptures, and green spaces.

Bartlett Arboretum in Belle Plaine - A Prairie Rarity Flourishes: Thirty minutes south of Wichita, this century-old wooded haven hosts events beginning each April with Art at the Arb amid 40,000 tulips.

days_plan.itin_title: Kansas Unveiled: From Tallgrass Prairies to Space Exploration - Discovering America's Heartland

visits.text: Celebrate baseball's purest form at the World of Little League Museum in Williamsport, birthplace of the beloved youth sports organization. Journey through a six-inning self-guided tour showcasing artifacts, photographs, and interactive exhibits tracing Little League's growth from a single Pennsylvania league in 1939 to a global phenomenon reaching millions of children. Time your visit for August to catch the Little League World Series championship games.

Pedal through the spectacular Pine Creek Gorge, Pennsylvania's 'Grand Canyon,' on the 62-mile Pine Creek Rail Trail. Named one of the world's greatest bike routes, this gentle converted railroad bed follows the gorge floor beneath 1,450-foot canyon walls draped in virgin hemlock and towering white pine. The trail suits all skill levels with its barely perceptible grade.

days_plan.itin_title: Pennsylvania Heritage Trail - Where American History Meets Natural Splendor

visits.text: Stroll along the historic Riverwalk in downtown Wilmington, a picturesque waterfront promenade stretching along the Cape Fear River. This charming walkway winds through the city's beautifully preserved historic district, offering stunning river views, unique shops, and glimpses of antebellum architecture. The Riverwalk perfectly captures the essence of Southern coastal charm.

activities.text: Explore Wilmington's historic downtown district, where centuries-old buildings house boutiques, galleries, and eateries along tree-lined streets. The city's rich maritime heritage and well-preserved architecture make it one of North Carolina's most photogenic destinations. Take time to admire the blend of antebellum mansions and waterfront charm that defines this coastal gem.

days_plan.itin_title: North Carolina Discovery: From Coastal Heritage to Blue Ridge Peaks

visits.text: Wilson Lake - The Clearest Lake in Kansas: Red sandstone cliffs and pillars interrupt the shoreline of this remarkably clear reservoir, creating scenery more reminiscent of the Southwest than the Great Plains.

Wilson State Park - Where Smoky Hills Meet Crystal Waters: Lake lovers fish, paddle, boat, and swim while mountain bikers conquer the 25-mile Switchgrass Trail that snakes through canyons carved into the surrounding Smoky Hills.

activities.text: Switchgrass Trail - 25 Miles of Mountain Biking Adventure: This challenging trail system winds through Smoky Hills canyons, offering technical terrain and scenic views rarely associated with Kansas.

Cheney Lake Sailing - Kansas's Premier Wind Sports Destination: Steady prairie breezes have made this lake one of the nation's top sailing and windsurfing destinations, drawing a dedicated seafaring following.

days_plan.itin_title: Kansas Unveiled: From Tallgrass Prairies to Space Exploration - Discovering America's Heartland
Kansas Unveiled: From Tallgrass Prairies to Space Exploration - Discovering America's Heartland

visits.text: New England Air Museum - The Largest Aviation Collection in the Northeast: Explore an extraordinary assemblage of aircraft, helicopters, engines, and memorabilia spanning the entire history of flight. Highlights include the oldest surviving aircraft in America (a hot air balloon basket) and the oldest Connecticut-constructed airplane.

Historic Aircraft Collection - From Pioneers to Jets: Walk among vintage fighters, bombers, and experimental aircraft in massive hangars, with knowledgeable volunteer docents-many former pilots and aviation professionals-ready to share stories behind each machine.

activities.text: Redbird Flight Simulator - Take the Controls: Experience the thrill of piloting through this realistic simulator, while younger visitors can build paper airplanes and participate in family-friendly aviation scavenger hunts throughout the facility.

visits.text: Wisconsin River Boat Cruise - Scenic cruise past dramatic sculpted sandstone cliffs and rock formations carved over millennia by the Wisconsin River.
Devil's Lake State Park - Wisconsin's most popular state park featuring 500-foot quartzite bluffs rising above a pristine glacial lake. Excellent hiking on the East and West Bluff trails.
Tommy Bartlett Exploratory - Interactive science museum with hands-on exhibits exploring physics, space, and natural phenomena.
Noah's Ark Waterpark - America's largest waterpark spanning 70 acres with over 80 attractions and water slides.
Mt. Olympus Water & Theme Park - Massive entertainment complex combining waterpark thrills with roller coasters and go-karts.

days_plan.itin_title: MINNESOTA -THE BEST PLACES !

visits.text: Columbia River Gorge — Cross this dramatic 1,200-meter-deep canyon where the Columbia River cuts through the Cascade Range. The 130-kilometer gorge creates the only sea-level route through the mountains, featuring over 77 waterfalls.

Multnomah Falls — Admire Oregon's tallest waterfall plunging 189 meters in two major tiers connected by the historic Benson Bridge built in 1914. The iconic cascade attracts over 2 million visitors annually to its easily accessible viewing platform.

Maryhill Museum of Art — Explore this eclectic collection housed in a 1914 mansion overlooking the Columbia River. Holdings include European paintings, Auguste Rodin sculptures, Native American artifacts, and Queen Marie of Romania's furnishings.

Yakima Valley wine country — Drive through Washington's premier wine region producing 40% of the state's grapes. The rain shadow of the Cascades creates ideal conditions for Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, and Chardonnay.

Columbia River Gorge — Traversez ce canyon spectaculaire de 1 200 mètres de profondeur où la Columbia River traverse la chaîne des Cascades. Cette gorge de 130 kilomètres crée la seule route au niveau de la mer à travers les montagnes, avec plus de 77 chutes d'eau.

Multnomah Falls — Admirez la plus haute chute d'eau de l'Oregon qui plonge sur 189 mètres en deux niveaux principaux reliés par l'historique Benson Bridge construit en 1914. Cette cascade emblématique attire plus de 2 millions de visiteurs annuellement vers sa plateforme d'observation facilement accessible.

Maryhill Museum of Art — Explorez cette collection éclectique abritée dans un manoir de 1914 surplombant la Columbia River. Les collections comprennent des peintures européennes, des sculptures d'Auguste Rodin, des artefacts amérindiens et l'ameublement de la reine Marie de Roumanie.

Région viticole de Yakima Valley — Conduisez à travers la première région viticole de Washington produisant 40% des raisins de l'État. L'ombre pluviométrique des Cascades crée des conditions idéales pour le Cabernet Sauvignon, le Merlot et le Chardonnay.

activities.text: Wine tasting tour — Visit family-owned wineries and tasting rooms sampling award-winning Washington wines. Many vineyards offer tours explaining viticulture practices and the valley's unique terroir.

Historic Highway 14 drive — Navigate this scenic route along the Columbia's north bank past basalt cliffs, orchards, and Native American fishing sites. The highway offers dramatic gorge views and access to small riverside communities.

Farm-to-table dinner — Savor cuisine featuring Yakima Valley produce including hops, apples, cherries, and wine. The agricultural region supplies ingredients to restaurants throughout the Pacific Northwest.

Tour de dégustation de vins — Visitez des vignobles familiaux et des salles de dégustation pour goûter des vins primés de Washington. Beaucoup de vignobles offrent des tours expliquant les pratiques viticoles et le terroir unique de la vallée.

Conduite sur l'Historic Highway 14 — Naviguez cette route panoramique le long de la rive nord de la Columbia past des falaises de basalte, des vergers et des sites de pêche amérindiens. L'autoroute offre des vues spectaculaires sur la gorge et l'accès aux petites communautés riveraines.

Dîner de la ferme à la table — Savourez une cuisine mettant en vedette les produits de Yakima Valley incluant le houblon, les pommes, les cerises et le vin. La région agricole fournit des ingrédients aux restaurants de tout le Pacific Northwest.

days_plan.itin_title: WASHINGTON: FROM SEATTLE'S COFFEE CULTURE TO MOUNT RAINIER'S GLACIERS

visits.text: Spend a whimsical night inside a giant shoe at the Haines Shoe House, a 25-foot-tall footwear-shaped building constructed in 1948 by eccentric shoe magnate Mahlon Haines as a promotional gimmick. Now converted into a vacation rental, this roadside Americana landmark features three bedrooms and offers one of Pennsylvania's most unique overnight experiences, proving that if the shoe fits, you can actually sleep in it.

days_plan.itin_title: Pennsylvania Heritage Trail - Where American History Meets Natural Splendor

visits.text: Explore York's traditional Southern town center, where the historic York County Courthouse and prominent commercial buildings line streets that retain their 19th-century character. As part of South Carolina's Olde English District, the town connects to important Revolutionary War history. The McCelvey Center, housed in a handsome brick building, serves as a Southern Revolutionary War Institute with exhibits and programs.

activities.text: Enjoy the outdoors at Anne Springs Close Greenway, an expansive natural area well-suited for quiet afternoon hikes, horseback riding, and nature observation. The greenway's trails wind through diverse habitats providing peaceful escapes from busier destinations. York's combination of history and natural beauty offers a fitting conclusion to a South Carolina journey.

days_plan.itin_title: South Carolina Grand Tour: Coastal Elegance to Mountain Serenity

visits.text: Yosemite National Park - America's Cathedral of Stone and Water: Sheer granite walls rise 3,000 feet from the valley floor as waterfalls plunge from heights that dwarf skyscrapers. This UNESCO World Heritage Site inspired the conservation movement and continues to humble millions of annual visitors.

El Capitan - The World's Most Famous Big Wall: This 3,000-foot vertical granite monolith draws elite climbers from around the globe attempting multi-day ascents of routes like The Nose. Even from the valley floor, watching climbers as tiny specks on the face is mesmerizing.

Half Dome - Yosemite's Iconic Sentinel: This distinctive granite dome, cleaved as if by a giant's axe, rises 4,737 feet above the valley floor. The cables route to the summit remains one of America's most sought-after hiking achievements.

Yosemite Falls - North America's Tallest Waterfall: Water plunges 2,425 feet in three tiers, creating a spectacle visible from throughout Yosemite Valley. Peak flow occurs in May and June when snowmelt transforms the falls into a thundering curtain of white.

activities.text: Tunnel View - The Most Photographed Vista in America: This overlook presents El Capitan, Half Dome, and Bridalveil Fall in a single sweeping panorama that has graced countless postcards, calendars, and desktop backgrounds.

Glacier Point - Stand 3,214 Feet Above the Valley: This dramatic overlook provides bird's-eye views of Yosemite's greatest hits, with Half Dome at eye level and the High Sierra stretching to the horizon.
Mariposa Grove - Walk Among Giant Sequoias: Over 500 mature giant sequoias populate this ancient forest, including the 1,800-year-old Grizzly Giant with its 96-foot circumference.
